PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Community Youth Support Scheme
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That a need exists within the community for the Community Youth Support Schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government not remove any funds for the Community Youth Support Schemes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron,Mr Charles,Mrs Darling and Mr Holding.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament as assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Their anger and condemnation at the Fraser Government's decision to abolish all Community Youth Support Schemes on 31 October 1981.
Further they denounce the decision for the disastrous effects it will have on growing numbers of unemployed young people around Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government immediately and fully reverse its decision and restore complete funding to the Community Youth Support Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: DUFFY; HOWE; KENT; MILDREN; MILTON; PEACOCK; THEOPHANOUS
PETITION.NAMEIDS: 6G4; EH4; PH4; AI4; DI4; MI4; QJ4
PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That the serious youth unemployment problem is a direct result of the community's failure to create sufficient jobs.

In these circumstances the decision to abolish Community Youth Support Schemes (CYSS) is a socially retrogressive step. The CYSS Projects provide valuable support services and work training for many young unemployed.

We the undersigned are concerned that the closure of CYSS Projects may lead young unemployed to become involved in anti-social behaviour such as crime, vandalism, prostitution, rebellious behaviour and mob action. There is the even more frightening prospect that many more young people will give up hope of obtaining a job, become idle and even contemplate suicide.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government reverse its decision to abolish CYSS Projects and provide sufficient funds to enable the various CYSS centres to continue their valuable work with the young unemployed in the future.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Duffy,Mr Howe,Mr Kent,Mr Mildren,Mr Milton,Mr Peacock and Dr Theophanous.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Ballarat respectfully showeth:

(i) that the action of the Government in terminating the Community Youth Support Scheme will have serious effects upon the life possibilities of a significant number of young people who, through circumstances totally outside their control, are not able to find any form of paid employment,

(ii) that the action of the Government fails to understand that many unemployed youth do not fit into the retraining initiatives proposed and that part of the need within the total context of school-to-work transition is to have support structures based around the Community Youth Support Scheme model,

(iii) that the failure to provide such supports will place many young people in a position of high vulnerability to crime, violence, vandalism, drug abuse, and even suicide, and that the incidence of homelessness and family breakdown will be further aggravated.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government give immediate attention to the re-instatement of the Community Youth Support Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child,Mr Hawke and Mr Mildren.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the North West Coast of Tasmania hereby humbly pleads:
That the Federal Government reverse the decision to cease funding to the Community Youth Support Schemes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ARMITAGE; CHARLES; HOLDING; HURFORD; JACOBI; KENT; SCOTT
PETITION.NAMEIDS: Q07; GF4; CH4; AV4; CV4; PH4; 7J4
PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the proposed changes to assistance to the passenger motor vehicle and components industries after 1984 shall lead to the collapse of the vehicle manufacturing industry in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the industries assistance commission report be not given effect.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Armitage,Mr Charles,Mr Holding,Mr Hurford,Mr Jacobi,Mr Kent and Mr Scott.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEAZLEY; CHARLES; DUFFY; KENT; MILDREN; MILTON; MORRIS
PETITION.NAMEIDS: PE4; GF4; 6G4; PH4; AI4; DI4; HI4
PETITION.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans-Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans-Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines would inevitably result in:
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans-Australia Airlines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley,Mr Charles,Mr Duffy,Mr Kent,Mr Mildren,Mr Milton and Mr Morris.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is increasing Interest Rates on Home Mortgage Loans without due concern for its impact on the general community and ask that the Government re-consider its attitude to Low and Middle income earners.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert any further effects of increases in interest rates on Home Mortgage Loans which cause Financial, Social and Psychological pressures on families.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley,Mr Duffy,Mr Mildren and Mr Milton.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The proposal to introduce fees for higher and second degrees will mean that access to post-graduate and recurrent education will be limited to the rich; Australian research and ability to cope with technological change will suffer; this proposal must be seen as a step in the direction of the introduction of fees for all tertiary students.

2. The proposed introduction of a loans scheme for students will mean graduating with a heavy debt or being denied a tertiary education if loans are refused because a student is seen as a ''poor risk'' (particularly affecting women and those doing non-vocational courses); only the rich will be able to get a tertiary education without course restrictions and the burden of indebtedness.

3. In regard to the proposal to restrict eligibility for TEAS and the foreshadowing of reviewing TEAS levels only in the light of the availability of loans, it should be noted that any further downgrading of TEAS, which is already inadequate, can only further limit access to education.

4. The proposed restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance to those needing qualifications for employment will severely restrict access to a full high school education and necessary bridging education to tertiary education for those who left school early.

5. The proposal not to fund 30 Colleges of Advanced Education if they are not rationalised is an attack on teacher education. This attack will create teacher shortages in the mid 1980s, restrict access to education now and endanger the future quality of teaching available to Australian children.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
(i) post-secondary tuition fees not be introduced for any courses or for any category of students;
(ii) that the TEAS scheme be extended so as to more fully meet the real financial needs of students.
(iii) that a comprehensive loans scheme not be introduced.
(iv) that there be no restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance.
(v) that the proposal not to fund 30 CAEs unless they are rationalised be rescinded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles and Mrs Darling.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) The financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.

(ii) The imposition of post-secondary tuition fees of comparable levels to those imposed prior to 1971 would force many currently enrolled students to discontinue their studies and deter many persons willing and able at present to undertake post-secondary study from doing so.

(iii) Those students and potential students from social groups currently under-represented and disadvantaged in the post-secondary education system would be most severely affected by the reintroduction of fees for post-secondary education.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any courses or for any category of students
2. the visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately
3. the Minister of Education immediately clarify the government's attitude to the re-introduction of post-secondary tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilisers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is not fulfilling its responsibility in ensuring an adequate standard of living for all Australians, which is causing untold hardship on relief agencies' limited resources, and require the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:
1. That the Commonwealth Government raise the level of all pensions and benefits at least to the poverty line.
2. That the Commonwealth Government reconsider its recent decisions in relation to the health system and cuts to Commonwealth activity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert further poverty and suffering in our community by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Community Kindergartens
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That community kindergartens perform indispensable services in the preparation of children for education:
That, without sufficient Federal and State Government funding, community kindergartens will be placed beyond the economic reach of many families, to the disadvantage of their children;

That the Commonwealth Government's contribution to the funding of community kindergartens has decreased greatly in recent years, causing concern among parents and those concerned with children's education.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government's support for funding of community kindergartens be restored to 1976 funding levels, ie., 75 per cent of total approved wages for kindergarten staff.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pancrease: Australian Drug Evaluation Committee
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That tests performed at the Royal Childrens Hospital, Brisbane, indicate that the drug, pancrease, can provide significant relief and assistance to sufferers of cystic fibrosis.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will require the processing of the drug, pancrease, by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee of the Department of Health, as a matter of high priority.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That public investment in tertiary education in the form of Federal Government funding is an investment in Australia's future and enables Australia to meet the demands of technological innovation;
That grave concern has been generated as a result of the Government's decisions to:
(a) abolish the education and research and development committee,
(b) terminate special support for educational research,
(c) scale down in-house and contracted research activities of the Department of Education,
(d) scale down participation in international education activities, particularly UNESCO and OECD,
(e) further tighten already restrictive eligibility guidelines for TEAS,
(f) supplement TEAS assistance by means of a loans scheme,
(g) phase in tuition fees for students undertaking degrees and diplomas subsequent to an initial tertiary qualification,
(h) reduce grants to universities and colleges to take account of fee income,
(i) completely abolish 30 colleges of advanced education, and
(j) scale down various engineering schools in colleges of advanced education around Australia;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will rescind these regressive decisions and desist from obvious attempts to pave the way for a complete re-introduction of tertiary fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Navigation Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That general aviation should make a reasonable contribution to the costs incurred by Transport Australia in servicing general aviation;
That Transport Australia has not correctly identified the costs relevant to general aviation;
That the cost recovery recommendations of the general aviation study prepared by the Bureau of Transport Economics are neither equitable nor efficient;
That the general aviation study recommendations would increase air navigation charges to an intolerable level causing widespread bankruptcy and unemployment.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Government will reject the recommendations of the general aviation study report in relation to substantial increases to general aviation's air navigation charges.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services: Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we strongly condemn any action taken by the Federal Government which will lead to the destruction of the free hospital and medical services of the State of Queensland.
And your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Parliament reject the proposed health cost sharing arrangements between the Commonwealth and the State governments and guarantee the maintenance of the present scheme whereby all Queenslanders who wish to avail themselves of these services may do so.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Australians' dream and tradition of owning their own homes is fast becoming an unattainable goal as the government imposed credit squeeze limits available housing finance, and as the government imposed hike in interest rates forces many home buyers and potential home buyers out of the housing market:

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will take those initiatives which will result in greater availability of funds for lending institutions to lend home loans and reduce pressure on banks and other lending institutions and thereby reverse the trend of spiralling interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Overseas Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That Australia, as an affluent and developed nation, should be able to expend more of its resources on the alleviation of human suffering and deprivation in other less developed countries.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will:
increase overseas aid to 0.7 per cent of Australia's G.N.P.
increase to 4 per cent the proportion of overseas aid channeled through recognised non-government organisations such as world vision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Women's Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That women's refuges have provided on a 24 hour day basis emergency accommodation, child care, financial aid, moral support, legal advice and guidance in dealing with government departments for over 13,000 women and children in the past year at a cost to the national government substantially less than $4 million which is half the cost of holding the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Australia later this year.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will not proceed with its stated intention to withdraw from funding women's refuges and pass this responsibility to ill-equipped and sometimes unsympathetic State governments and will increase Federal funding levels for women's refuges.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the amount of permissable extra private income before the age and invalid pensions is reduced was last increased in September, 1972, and that a relaxation of the means test is long overdue.
And your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Government will increase the means test for pensions to the same relative level as applied in 1972, taking into account increases in the cost of living in excess of 100 per cent.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Telephone Concession
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That pensioners are reliant on their telephones for emergencies, that the means test applied to telephone concessions for pensioners is too restrictive, and that the amount of the concession on telephone rental is minimal.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Government will relax the pensioner telephone concession means test and increase the telephone concession to 50 per cent of telephone rental charges.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That retired low and middle income superannuants are disadvantaged by:
(a) Inflation
(b) Double Taxation, and
(c) Low means test for the aged pension
(2) That the age pension means test has not been increased since September 1972.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will increase the means test for all pensions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That it is unfair and discriminatory to make cost of living adjustments to fortnightly payments of Commonwealth Superannuation on an annual basis, while most other members of the Australian community receive twice yearly adjustments to their income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will end this anomalous practice by instituting twice yearly adjustments for Commonwealth Superannuees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Social Security
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That concern has been generated by the Government's decision to cut back expenditure in the Department of Social Security as outlined in the report of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Government Functions, i.e., by reducing the rate of expansion of regional offices of the Department of Social Security, confining social work activity to that relating to Departmental Functions, scaling down the social welfare division of the Department.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will rescind these decisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Government and Telecom management have presided over the deliberate scaling down of Australia's telegram services, to the disadvantage of those poorer people in the community who cannot afford telex or telephone facilities and rely on the telegram service in time of emergency:

That the Government and Telecom management have undermined the telegram service by increasing the unit cost of telegrams by over 130 per cent in four years with the result that the use of telegrams as a form of communication has fallen by approximately 60 per cent in that time.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government and Telecom management retain the telegram service at a standard and cost that will not disadvantage the ordinary citizen.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sand mining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology or environment.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the list of the Australian Heritage Commission and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, take into consideration the protection of the Island.
3. That the Queensland Government has recently approved sand mining on Moreton Island against the advice of conservationists.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Federal Government to refuse requests for export permits covering mineral sand products mined from Moreton Island.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the basic rate of pensions and rent allowance is not sufficient to meet present day needs.
In light of the 20 per cent increase in MPs salaries pensioners are being unfairly treated.
Therefore, your petitioners urge that:
1. Basic rate of pension be increased to 30 per cent of the average weekly earnings.
2. Rent allowance be increased from present $5.00 weekly to $20.00 weekly.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. Because of an anomaly in tax rates a single income family pays nearly $10 a week more tax than a dual income family earning the same total amount.
2. Family allowances established in 1976 have not been increased since then, yet over the same period living costs have increased by nearly 60 per cent.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that:
The Parliament should act-
1. To restore the lost value of family allowances and to index them for future price rises.
2. To increase the spouse rebate from $830 to $1,342 per year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That many Australians will be financially disadvantaged by the health changes proposed by the Federal Government, especially the withdrawal of Commonwealth medical benefits for the uninsured, and the introduction of a means test for free public hospital care;
That the health insurance changes promote inequity, inefficiency and lack of universal coverage;
That the public hospital system and community health programs will be financially disadvantaged by the abdication of Commonwealth responsibility and funding.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will take all steps necessary to reintroduce a system of health care based on ability to pay, and access to health care based on medical need.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

We, the people who have signed this petition ask all parties, Labor, Liberal, Democrats and others, to stop the latest increase in taxes and the forever increases in taxes which hit all people of the country of Australia in all goods and consumer goods and we call for a referendum on taxes and interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Women's Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia/New South Wales respectfully showeth:
That many thousands of women and children in the Australian community who use the services of Women's Refuges, Rape Crisis Centre and Women's Health Centres:

1. Express their concern at the decision of the Federal Government to pass to the States, the responsibility of funding those essential services because of the poor record already demonstrated by some States;
2. Call on the Federal Government to reverse that decision;
3. Request that the Government ensure that there is one department which will administer all funds for the above under the heading of Women's Services;
4. Propose that future funding should be on a guaranteed triennial basis which must take into account inflation and indexation rises;

5. Request definite government policy commitment to a substantial injection of funds to consolidate existing services and develop new ones. That such funds be distributed in such a way as to insure equitable national distribution of these resources.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectively showeth:
1. Our grievance that taxation on interest earned in Bank and Building Society Savings Accounts is thus a law and-
2. Our grievance that interest charged on home mortgage loans is not at this time, an allowable taxation deduction.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should:
1. Allow interest earned in Bank and Building Society Savings Accounts-to the approximate amount of $500 (five hundred dollars)-to be not counted as taxable income.

2. Deem that interest-to the approximate amount of $1,000 (one thousand dollars)-charged on home mortgage loans be an allowable taxation deduction. This is only applicable on the private home of the taxpayer, and not on any investment properties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Maranoa respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade postal and mail services throughout Australia, will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by:
downgrading a large number of official post offices;
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
reducing the number of street posting boxes;
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices;
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the Postal and Mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Lilley respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade postal and mail services throughout Australia, will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by:
downgrading a large number of official post offices;
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
reducing the number of street posting boxes;
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices;
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the postal and mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Commission: Melbourne Show Band
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that:

As regular viewers and listeners of the ABC Melbourne Show Band we were disappointed to learn of the dismissal of seventeen members of this outstanding orchestra. We have had a great deal of pleasure over the past eight years viewing and listening to this band's fine music. It is the only full time light orchestra in Australia and we are disgusted to think that such talented musicians should be dismissed in this manner.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to rescind this decision and make more money available for the continuance of the full show band.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned members of parents and citizens associations respectfully showeth:

That retention of the Schools Commission and the Curriculum Development Centre in their present forms is essential for the balanced and progressive allocation of educational resources and facilities in the Australian community;

That serious concern has been generated by the Government's decision to reduce the involvement of the Schools Commission in program administration in the States, and the collection of information; its decision to alter the basis for providing subsidies for school buildings and other capital facilities; and the abolition of the Curriculum Development Centre.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Government will reverse these decisions to ensure the continuation of the positive role of the Schools Commission in the assessment of needs and initiatives in education and the continued functioning of the Curriculum Development Centre.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Macquarie respectfully showeth:
That we consider the removal of local call conditions for telephone calls between Katoomba and Springwood is adversely affecting families, business concerns and employment in the area.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government direct Telecom Australia to restore traditional local call conditions between these centres.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House is of the opinion that a select committee of the House of Representatives should be established forthwith to publicly inquire into and report on:
(1) the failure of the Minister for Transport to ensure that sufficient departmental personnel are available to maintain regular and normal operation of airports under his administration;

(2) the impact on the provision of air services in Australia of the random and regular denial of access to airports to air service operators with particular reference to Brisbane and Queensland airports; and

(3) the impact on and deferral of tourist industry development projects arising from the unavailability of access to major airports during normal operational hours due to the unavailability of Department of Transport personnel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) deplores the Fraser Government's action in abolishing the long standing discretionary power of the States to determine which national road construction projects should be constructed by public road authorities;
(2) condemns the Liberal and Country Parties of New South Wales for their support of this action;
(3) regrets the job insecurity, added unemployment and inefficiencies being created by the Fraser Government's roads policy particularly in country towns; and
(4) calls on the Minister for Transport to initiate urgent legislation for the restoration of the States discretionary powers in respect of the construction of national roads projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It is supplementary to a question that was asked of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the Senate and similar questions I have asked of the Minister for Administrative Services in this place. Noting that there is some real concern on the part of the Government as to whether having State and Federal enrolment cards at polling places during the National Aboriginal Conference elections may infringe that section of the legislation which makes it an offence to interfere or attempt to interfere with the free exercise by an Aboriginal of his or her choice whether to enrol, I ask whether the Government holds the same real concern for the fact that failing to provide enrolment information and cards at NAC polling places might constitute an infringement of the same legislation because it interferes with the free exercise by an Aboriginal of his or her choice whether to enrol?

—For the honourable member's benefit I will take the question on notice so that I may refer it to my colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to see whether the answer relates to the one that apparently the Minister has already given in another place.

—Is the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Health aware of a hospital operating at Arncliffe in Sydney by a group known as Population Services International (Australasia) Ltd? Does this hospital receive Commonwealth benefits? Is the Minister aware of allegations that this hospital is used for the termination of pregnancies? Does the Minister have any details regarding the ownership and operation of this establishment?

—The answer to the first three questions is yes. I am informed that the shareholders of the company are I. Cassidy, Dr Barry Cassidy and Michael Joseph Kissane, solicitor. The solicitors are Walker, Kissane and Plummer of 179 Beamish Street, Campsie, and the auditor is M. L. Walker, 4 Dinjerra Crescent, Oatley. I am aware of the company's advertisements appearing in the commercial sections of the Sydney telephone directory.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister for Industrial Relations undertake to protect the confidentiality of communications between his Department and employers in the building construction industry in relation to the proposed application for deregistration of the Builders Labourers Federation? Has Costain Australia Ltd complained to the Minister about the breach of this undertaking by the Minister? Is one of the Minister's grounds for this proposed application that the BLF, in the industrial field, acts improperly, will not adhere to agreements and cannot be trusted?

QUESTION.PARA: Mr Hawke continuing his question-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The question, using terms of the kind it does, is out of order. I will not permit a question to attack any other member of the House in such a fashion. Additionally, I think the Minister may have indicated that the deregistration proceedings had been instituted before the court. I ask the Minister whether it is so that proceedings have been instituted?
—No, Mr Speaker, not the deregistration proceedings. The royal commission has commenced its work.
—The honourable gentleman will have to rephrase his question if he wants it to be in order.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. I had already asked the Minister three questions to which there was no objection. I am content to leave the question at that point.
—I will allow that course.

—When I answered a question in the House on Tuesday, the Opposition sought the tabling and then the incorporation in Hansard of the written advice from a senior officer of the Attorney-General's Department to the Attorney-General. In response to the request of the Opposition, that document was incorporated in Hansard. The action that has been taken by the BLF against Costain is despicable action. It is despicable industrial behaviour typical of the kind of action that has become commonplace in Victoria.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The answer given by the Minister is not relevant to the question. I remind you, sir, of what the questions are: Firstly, did the Minister give an undertaking to the building construction industry? Secondly, has Costain complained about the breach of undertaking? I ask you, Mr Speaker, how is what the Minister saying about the action of the BLF relevant to those questions? It simply is not relevant. I repeat the questions: Did the Minister give an undertaking and has there been a complaint? What the BLF may or may not be doing has no relevance to those two questions.
—There is no point of order.
—Rafferty's rules!
—I require the honourable member for Wills to withdraw that reflection on the Chair.
—Mr Speaker, I withdraw.
—I call the Minister.

—As I was saying, the kind of action we have seen the BLF take against Costain is typical of the kind of industrial behaviour which has caused so much havoc in Victoria and other States around Australia. Costain has been in touch with me about the action taken by the BLF. I am meeting Costain in Sydney this morning. I take the matter very seriously. The BLF, trying to be smart on what it calls a tit for tat basis, can do so much harm to this company. I expect after the discussions that I have with Costain this morning we will be able to do something to deal with the BLF. I add that there are many companies which necessarily will be named in the papers to be lodged in the court in regard to deregistration. I wonder whether what we have seen from the BLF up to now is a forerunner of what the BLF might attempt to do against all those companies which are prepared to come forward and give evidence in relation to the conduct of that union.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: COMMONWEALTH DROUGHT RELIEF

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industry. Has the Commonwealth Government provided any funding for drought relief in New South Wales in the last financial year?

—The very severe drought that eastern States have suffered over recent months fortunately has diminished although parts of New South Wales currently are still under drought. New South Wales has quite a remarkable story in respect of drought assistance. At one stage during the very severe drought months earlier I had to bait the New South Wales Premier to give any drought assistance at all. All I wanted him to do was to match the generous assistance being given in Queensland for carriage of stock, fodder and water and assistance in the form of carry-on loans to farmers and small business. Mr Wran was not prepared to do that and he took his time in giving any assistance at all. Finally, by some miracle, he produced a $40m drought plan that we have yet to see even today. He said he had $40m to spend on drought assistance. It is interesting to note that in the election campaign in New South Wales, the Premier is claiming that New South Wales spent $70m on drought relief.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. As a result of the decisions taken by this Parliament, there is a restriction on the use of the broadcasting media to deal with election items. Although clearly the privileges of this Parliament cover us from that restriction, it seems to me to be a gross abuse of privilege for Ministers of the Crown, knowing there is a restriction on every other segment of the electronic broadcasting media in dealing with election material, to use the broadcast of this House during Question Time to make statements which are prohibited on every other part of that media. I suggest, sir, that you as Speaker should indicate to the House that on this matter, having regard to the general restrictions which the Parliament has imposed on all other levels of the electronic media, there is a moral obligation on the Parliament, and on Ministers particularly, to comply with the laws which the Parliament insists every other section of the broadcast communication industry has to comply with.

—There is no point of order. I understand the point made by the honourable gentleman. I most certainly would not take or counsel any action in this House which in any way represented a barrier to free discussion in this House on all matters of national and public importance. The only exceptions are cases where the sub judice rule would be prejudiced. I would not in any way in any circumstances reduce the capacity of this Parliament to speak on national issues.
—The fact is that the Wran plan for spending $40m never eventuated. It was simply, to use the expression of my colleague the Treasurer yesterday, political grandstanding of the worst kind.

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I recently put some questions on notice about drought relief in the various States and the answer I got was that this was properly a matter for the States. The Minister today was asked a direct question--
—There is no point of order, and the honourable gentleman knows that.

—That is the burden of my complaint: It is properly a matter for the States. The Premier of New South Wales has totally neglected his responsibility. The country people of New South Wales will thank the honourable member for the intervention. I do not think Premier Wran will.

—The Minister will resume his seat. I ask honourable members on the Opposition benches to be silent while the answer is being given. The proceedings of the House cannot go on if the person who has the call cannot be heard.
—The Minister is making a farce of Question Time.
—The honourable member for Wills will remain silent. The House managed for many years before the honourable member for Wills came. I call the Minister for Primary Industry to resume his answer.

—The facts are that the Premier of New South Wales never honoured his obligations under the $40m program. He now claims a $70m program in his advertisements around the countryside. Just so that the facts are on the record--
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat.
—They do not like the truth.
—We have only one sitting day before the election. Let us get through this one sitting day in reasonable calm. I will call the Minister when the House is silent.

—So that the facts are on the record, let us be clear where this election advertisement of a $70m program leaves the Premier of New South Wales. The total drought relief expenditure in New South Wales this year was $64.7m. Of this, the Commonwealth contributed $42.4m and the New South Wales Government a miserable $22.3m. For the Premier of New South Wales to go around the countryside skiting about his assistance for drought when I had to drag him to the barrier on every issue--
—Order! The Minister will remain relevant to the question. The question dealt with the expenditure by the Commonwealth.

—Mr Speaker, with great respect, this is very relevant; this is drought, advertisements about drought and drought aid. I had to drag him to the barrier on every issue-on drought aid, on carriage for fodder, freight fodder assistance, freight assistance for water--

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. The Minister is abusing your direction to remain relevant to the question. The issue is a political one raised by him of this Government buying into the State election in New South Wales when everyone in Australia knows it is going to be Wran on Saturday.
—I ask the Minister to remain relevant to the question.
—The facts of the matter are that Mr Wran has misled the country people of New South Wales on this issue and they ought to know about it; they need to know about it.

—I ask a question of the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer to the notorious Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd scandal. Can the Minister state when the Australian Federal Police commenced their investigations into this scandal, the date on which they submitted the report on their investigations to the Government, the processes that report has been through since, in particular the periods when other Ministers and/or departments have had access to this report and the reasons why they would have and the manner in which they dealt with that report? In particular, will he state whether and, if so, when the present Minister for Primary Industry, and indeed his predecessor, had any access to this report, the status of that access and the way in which they dealt with the report?

—I cannot give answers to the specific questions relating to dates. However, I am quite willing to find those out for the Leader of the Opposition and let him know. As to the progress of any police investigation, I can assure the House that any matters that are referred to the Police Commissioner will be progressed to the ultimate by the Commissioner. All allegations will be investigated and appropriate action taken.

—My question is to the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. Is the Minister aware of concern being expressed by members of the softwood timber industry, particularly the South Australian members, regarding imports of North American timber known as SPF? Firstly, can the Minister inform the House whether the Industrial Assistance Commission report on the timber industry has been given to the Government and, if so, when will it be considered? Secondly, have the allegations of dumping been brought to his attention, and has an inquiry been undertaken into those allegations? If so, will he ensure that sufficient resources are committed to the inquiry so that this matter can be handled expeditiously to ensure that our industry is protected from such dumping?

—The matter raised by the honourable member for Barker was subject to inquiry through my Department in July of this year by way of a dumping complaint. In the meantime, the IAC report on the timber industry as a whole has recently been received by the Government and a decision will be made. I know that the honourable member's electorate is one of the main areas of softwood production and I can understand his concern. Certainly the Government is very aware of this matter.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. I refer to the fact that last week in the absence of the right honourable gentleman I asked a question of the Minister for Foreign Affairs relating to the death of Tony Joyce who, the right honourable gentleman will recall, was fatally wounded while in police custody in Zambia some 21 months ago. I might remind the right honourable gentleman that his Minister advised me that it was unlikely that there would be any satisfactory explanation of the tragic death of Joyce but if any information became available the Parliament would be informed after consultation with members of the family of the late Mr Joyce. I ask the right honourable gentleman: Is there anything further to add to that report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is some information that I can give the honourable gentleman. The honourable gentleman will know from earlier indications that have been given in the Parliament since Tony Joyce was shot in November of 1979 that representations to the Zambian Government have been made on a number of occasions. I wrote to President Kaunda on the day on which news of the shooting was received seeking information. Subsequently, the Acting Foreign Minister wrote to his Zambian counterpart to establish the outcome of investigations undertaken by the Zambian authorities. Tony Joyce was a fine man and a credit to his profession. His death was a great loss. We were all concerned, naturally, to know how and why this tragedy occurred. Earlier this year President Kaunda wrote to me personally about the matter. The President pointed out that Zambia was under attack at this time from Rhodesia. As a result Zambian military and security units were deployed to guard economic and strategically important installations throughout the country, working under highly explosive and very difficult conditions. Movement within the country was restricted and under security control. Investigations conducted by Zambia have not identified the individual or individuals responsible for the shooting. There are different accounts of what happened. It seems unlikely, because of the difficulty and uncertain circumstances prevailing at the time, that the issue will ever be fully resolved.

ANSWER.PARA: In his letter to me President Kaunda very sincerely expressed his regret that Tony Joyce, who was merely carrying out his normal duties, was caught up in this unfortunate situation and lost his life on Zambian soil. I spoke to Mrs Joyce at the time of Tony Joyce's death and conveyed the Australian Government's condolences and my deep personal regret. Since I received President Kaunda's letter I have spoken to Mrs Joyce again and conveyed the sentiments expressed by the President. Tony Joyce's death has been a matter of great sorrow for his family and his friends and I am sure that all honourable members would join with me in expressing again our sincere sympathy to Mrs Joyce.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, in view of your earlier ruling, I ask: Can the Minister for Industry and Commerce advise the House, from information available to him, whether any State is leading in Australia's industrial recovery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can inform the House that the recent manufacturing industry recovery which has been noticeable in the economy is broad-based and nation-wide. Nevertheless, industrial unrest and duress by some trade unions will very adversely affect industry confidence and the capacity of industry to plan ahead. I must say that the notorious strike record in New South Wales does little to sustain that confidence. It is a matter of fact that Sydney today is the strike capital of Australia. The Premier of New South Wales cannot stand aside from responsibility for that sorry record. New South Wales, under its present Government, is leading the rest of Australia in industrial disputes. In the first five months of this year almost 60 per cent of the working days lost throughout Australia were lost directly in New South Wales. In the recent week the fact that not one tonne of coal was exported from New South Wales is typical--

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I realise that in the past you have not ruled that Ministers' answers have to be strictly relevant to the questions asked. However, this question specifically dealt with whether any particular State was leading a manufacturing recovery. I would have thought that an answer to such a question would involve a discussion of the statistics of production. What we are getting is a discussion of days lost through strikes, which is a completely extraneous matter to that question.
—I think the only irrelevancy is that the Minister was asked whether any State was leading. He was explaining that one State is not leading. That seems relevant.

—Industrial unrest is obviously very relevant to the recovery which has been taking place in the Australian economy. The record in New South Wales encourages international buyers to seek to diversify increasingly their sources of supply. Such disputes not only affect Australia's international market reputation but also destroy industry's capacity to employ people on a long term basis. The simple fact is that the Wran Government has demonstrated its total absence of concern for those who are unemployed and its incapacity to establish an economic climate--
—The right honourable gentleman will resume his seat. If the noise continues I will suggest to the Prime Minister that he ask that questions be put on the Notice Paper.
—The strike record in New South Wales indicates, quite clearly, the total failure by the Wran administration to develop there an economic environment in which industry can plan ahead with confidence.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications. I refer him to the Australian Telecommunications Commission's recently released document entitled 'Service and Business Outlook 1981-82'. Has his attention been drawn to Telecom Australia's forecast overall increase in business of 13 per cent during the current year with a planned increase in productivity of 7 per cent? In the circumstances, will staff reductions imposed by Telecom as a result of the Government's restraints and inadequate borrowing levels imposed on Telecom by his Government result in increased delays in providing services, increasing congestion and an increased level of unsatisfied demands for new services? What action does the Government intend to take to overcome these deficiencies which have been caused by his Government's past and present policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for the question. The extent to which the improved borrowing program of Telecom has enabled it to launch by far the largest capital expenditure program ever undertaken by that organisation needs to be recognised. The amount of money available to the Telecommunications Commission this year is obviously a significant increase on the amount that was available last year. It is an amount which will enable Telecom, by judicious use of its funds, to provide for the reasonable expanding needs of the communications requirements in the telecommunications field throughout the nation. In addition, of course, the Commonwealth will shortly announce the terms and membership of an inquiry into the services of Telecom designed specifically to extend its capacity to provide services by, I hope, utilising the private sector to a greater degree. Certainly it seems that in the inter-connect or the add-on market, where there are many new technological devices capable of facilitating communications, there is a role that the private sector can play. It is my view that with that there will also be a significant increase in Telecom's ability to meet the requirements of the Australian people.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that there are a few areas where there are either problems in obtaining an early phone connection or in achieving access to a distant exchange because of the volume of traffic. I instance, for example, the Gold Coast, northern New South Wales, the western suburbs of Sydney towards Penrith and the coastal areas of Queensland where Telecom significantly has provided an increase on funds that were provided last year. I believe Telecom should be able both to reduce the necessary time for telephone connections and meet the requirements of the Australian people. I believe there are significant problems in some areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point or order. The Minister is deliberately misleading the House. An answer has been received by a gentleman in another place that, statistically, shows that what the Minister in now putting to the House is completely incorrect.
—Order! The honourable member for Melbourne will withdraw the words 'deliberately misleading'.
—Oh my God.
—The honourable member for Melbourne will withdraw.
—I will withdraw it.
—The honourable gentleman will stand and withdraw.
—And salute.
—The honourable gentleman will stand and withdraw the allegation.
—I have just done it. I do not propose to do any more.
—The honourable gentleman will stand and withdraw the allegation.
—I have already withdrawn.
—I did not hear the honourable gentleman withdraw. I ask the honourable gentleman to withdraw.
—I wish to raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. Hansard will record--
—Order! The honourable member for Hunter will resume his seat.
—Mr Speaker, may I intervene on behalf of the honourable member for Melbourne. I did hear him quite distinctly say: 'I withdraw'. I vouch for that.
—If the honourable member for Melbourne would pay the courtesy to the Chair of standing when addressing the Chair--

—Be quiet, please. If the honourable gentleman would show courtesy to the Chair by standing when speaking to the Chair I would be able to hear, presumably, what the honourable gentleman says. On the basis of the intervention by the Minister for Defence, I accept that he did say that he withdraws. I ask the honourable member for Melbourne, in future, to be courteous by standing.
—I withdrew on one occasion; I do not propose to do it again.

—The capital program for the Telecommunications Commission this year is $1,265m. That is an enormous program. I believe that in a program of that size there is an adequate capacity for the Telecommunications Commission to meet the requirements of the Australian people. Nonetheless, I share the feelings of most honourable members that there are areas where productivity and performance within Telecom can be improved. I trust that that will be done.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEFENCE INTEGRATED SECURE COMMUNICATIONS NETWORK PROJECT

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. Have any alterations or amendments been made to the Minister's statement relating to the reissue of tender documents for the Defence Integrated Secure Communications Network project in which it is stated that tenders will be restricted to firms in Australia, Britain, Canada and the United States? Does this restriction exclude the prime tenderer's alternative contractor, which was based in Denmark? Does it also exclude at least two other of the final tenderers on the previous occasion because partial or significant contractors were located in Sweden or other European countries? Will the Minister, as a matter of urgency, have a clearly definitive statement prepared on the sources which will be available and setting out whether the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation area is included, as I understand certain Department of Defence officials are alleging, or whether only firms within the restricted area stated by the Minister in this statement are, in fact, included?

—The honourable gentleman will appreciate that in the field of this character of communications security is of the utmost importance. All consideration is directed to that. My understanding is that any tender from those countries that fall within what I may describe as the NATO group will be accepted.
—They are not in your list.

—I am indebted to the honourable gentleman for reminding me of what looms as an ambiguity. Tenders that come from the area described as the Australia, New Zealand, United States and United Kingdom group will be accepted also. Having acknowledged what appears as an ambiguity, I will make sure that that ambiguity is removed.
—So Sweden is excluded?
—Yes.
—Can the Treasurer say that the great Australian dream of home ownership is disappearing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —If one looks at objective and independent measurements which have recently become available of the level of home ownership, the answer to that question would have to be a resounding no. The research department of the Reserve Bank of Australia has carried out a survey. On occasions the Reserve Bank is not reluctant to disagree publicly with the Government if it thinks it ought to do so. The latest Reserve Bank statistical bulletin for August 1981 contains the results of that survey, which indicate that by 1980 the level of home ownership in Australia had reached 71.6 per cent, having risen from 66.7 per cent in 1976. That figure of 71.6 per cent compares with Canada, 62 per cent; England and Wales, 50.1 per cent; France, 47.1 per cent; Switzerland, 28.5 per cent; Sweden, often invoked with affection on the other side of the House, 38.9 per cent; the United States of America, 64.8 per cent and West Germany, 33.5 per cent. I think those figures indicate that home ownership is very much alive in Australia and doing a great deal better than in the rest of the Western world. Having said that I do not for a moment disguise the difficulty that many Australians are experiencing at the present time as a consequence of higher interest rates so far as their housing repayments are concerned. Without using extravagant language I think it is fair to say that there are some hopeful signs that we have started to turn the corner on the interest rate front. There has been greater activity so far as the sale of Commonwealth bonds in recent days is concerned. Information to be released in the normal fashion by the monetary authorities this afternoon will confirm that.

ANSWER.PARA: I am very pleased to inform the House-I am delighted in fact-that there is no evidence to suggest that the level of home ownership in my home State of New South Wales is any lower than it is anywhere else in Australia. There is a very good reason for that. The authority for that reason is none other than the Premier of New South Wales. Does the House know what he said? The reason for it is very simple. In a speech in 1977 the Premier of New South Wales stated an obvious fact. I agree with him 100 per cent. He stated:
As a State Government, we do not possess the economic powers which determine the level of business activity, of unemployment or inflation.
All the weapons of economic management are in the hands of the Federal Government.
The judicious use of those weapons has produced a high level of home ownership in New South Wales and throughout Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO THE AUSTRALIAN MEAT INDUSTRY: TERMS OF REFERENCE

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister explain to the House why the terms of reference of the royal commission of inquiry into the Australian meat industry exclude findings as to impropriety, including impropriety by Ministers or public servants, when the terms of reference of the McGregor Royal Commission of inquiry into matters in relation to electoral redistribution in Queensland in 1977 enabled findings as to breaches of the law or impropriety and the terms of reference of the Winneke Royal Commission into the Activities of the Australian Building Construction and Employees' and Builders Labourers' Federation focused on illegality, corruption or impropriety of alleged activities. What is the reason for this significant difference?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The major thrust of all the allegations that have been made has concerned corruption. Allegations have not been made to me, that I am aware of, in relation to illegality. As I understand it the terms of reference cover adequately the types of allegations that have been made so that the royal commissioner is not prejudiced in any way in bringing down his report. I point out in addition that the Victorian Government has mirrored the terms of reference set by the Federal Government even though earlier-I have read this in Press reports-it was seeking to widen the terms of reference. But in point of fact when the matter was put to study by the Victorian Government's own law authorities they were satisfied with the terms of reference that were to be put down by the Commonwealth. At this point of time the Commonwealth and Victoria have mirror terms of reference for the royal commission.

ANSWER.PARA: I make the point also that, whilst I have heard words of comfort from Queensland and New South Wales about co-operation, we have not yet received, as far as I am aware, any confirmation as to what action Queensland will take in respect of the royal commission. We have received nothing from New South Wales either. I expect to receive nothing anyway from New South Wales until after next Saturday when the Premier will probably back off further than he has so far even in terms of co-operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then you've been wasting your time.
—We used to call the last honourable member for Wills a windbag; the present honourable member makes him look like a silent monk.
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat. I call the honourable member for Maribyrnong.
—I refer the Minister for Trade and Resources to the forecast by a group of uranium producers, including--
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I have not yet finished.
—I asked the Minister to resume his seat. I thought that he had concluded his answer.
—No, I have not finished.
—If he has not concluded, I call him again.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. You have called the honourable member for Maribyrnong. You have made it a practice in the past, having called a member, of proceeding to allow that member--
—That is on questions, not answers, with great respect.
—The Minister for Primary Industry will resume his seat. The Leader of the Opposition is making a point of order. What is the point of order?

—Very simply, the point of order is that in the past you have made it clear that, having called a member to allow him to proceed with making a point to this House, that member has the floor and you should not deviate from that. You have called the honourable member for Maribyrnong and you have deviated from your past practice. You are allowing the Minister to complete his answer. The Minister is only regurgitating what he has said half a dozen times.

—I am not deviating from past practice. I thought the Minister had finished, but now I learn that he had not. As a matter of common courtesy, I call the Minister to continue his answer and draw it to a conclusion.
—If the royal commissioner wishes at any time to widen the terms of reference because of something he finds during the inquiry, that will be considered immediately by the Government.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on notice.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. Once you have agreed to place on notice further questions to the Government, is it still competent for me to ask a question of you about Standing Orders?
—Yes. I will permit the honourable gentleman to do that.

—Mr Speaker, is any work being done anywhere in the Parliament at present, in Standing Orders committees or some other similar reform committee, to change the rules so that we do not have a repetition of the abuse of Question Time that we have witnessed in this chamber today from Government members and Ministers?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman used the term 'abuse of Question Time'. I do not think he is entitled to use that term because the Standing Orders are being complied with. As the honourable gentleman quite correctly observed at the commencement, it is the Standing Orders that require amendment. Therefore I do not regard it as a reflection on me, although it could be so interpreted from the words used by the honourable member for Adelaide. Many of the Standing Orders should be changed. Indeed, the Standing Orders Committee has met and reported to this House, not on this specific issue but on other issues, and the reports of the Standing Orders Committee just have not been dealt with. A number of reforms of the Standing Orders should be bought into account, and one of them is the question of relevancy. A more stringent definition of relevancy may be considered by the Standing Orders Committee.

INTERJECT.PARA: While I am on this topic, another matter which disturbs me is that petitions are read at the commencement of the sitting. During anything from five to 12 minutes of petition time there is constant noise and conversation which I think should not occur but under the Standing Orders I have no power to prevent it occurring. A lot of issues should be considered by the Standing Orders Committee. If it were approached on a strictly non-party basis we could have advantage in a reform of the Standing Orders. The period I have been here has demonstrated to me that whoever is in government-during the period I have been here there has been government from both sides of the House-there is always an attitude towards the Standing Orders which relates to the particular position of the person at the time, whether he is on the opposition side or on the government side. It is remarkable how quickly attitudes change with a change from one side of the House to the other.

If the honourable gentleman wishes to pursue the matter with his own party and with the representatives of the Standing Orders Committee, I certainly would be glad to hear suggestions from the Opposition in relation to Standing Orders. Likewise, I would be very happy to hear suggestions from the Government. I will at all times stand ready to call a meeting of the Standing Orders Committee for the purpose of considering them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I express sympathy for the difficulty of your position because of, firstly, the limitations in the Standing Orders and, secondly, some deficiencies in the general conduct which cannot be provided for under Standing Orders. There is a need, as there is outside in the community, in relation to ethical or proper conduct for people to accept that there are certain standards of obligation. I cannot help contrast what I saw on some recent visits to the House of Commons, where a genuine effort is made to respond to questions with relevant information, with the procedures here. I will refer very quickly to a General Business item I have on the Notice Paper that goes to the very heart of this matter. I say to you, Mr Speaker, seriously that it seems to me that there was a sort of Gilbert and Sullivan quality to the whole atmosphere this morning. It is not a unique experience in this House. Perhaps if we accept this across the chamber on both sides instead of trying to apportion blame we may ultimately add to the dignity of this place by improving the general standards. It became low farce and a rather crude parody.
—We could start with you.
—If the Minister converts the matter into that sort of disputation across the chamber we will get nowhere.
—The Leader of the Opposition is speaking by indulgence on the point. I ask him to speak to the issue and to avoid criticism of any persons.

—I do not seek to do that because I think it is totally unproductive. I believe that there is a need for some tightening of the general procedures in this House and a greater display of dignity. I would be the last to claim that I have been immune from dereliction from time to time in that respect. I am sure that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), in a moment of weakness, would make a similar confession. Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence because I believe this is an important matter. It is particularly appropriate that we discuss it now. The atmospherics are such that it has come to the fore with the intervention of the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) and your own obviously concerned response. Is Question Time to be a serious search for information? We have a problem. Some serious questions were put up on economic matters this week. Responses slid right around them and were totally irrelevant. One finds that some of the commentators on this matter--
—The honourable gentleman is now going beyond the scope of the indulgence.

—I do not think so, Mr Speaker. I think we ought to talk briefly but seriously about this. Are we genuinely concerned about trying to repair the situation or do we all want to see this continual downward spiral, this degeneration and degradation of our status? We suffer. I noted people sitting in the gallery looking rather perplexed, if not somewhat scornful, at certain aspects.
—The honourable gentleman has made his point.
—I will conclude. I want to draw your attention to General Business item No. 7 which appears on the Notice Paper in my name. Very simply it states:

SPEECH.PARA: That a Joint Committee of the Parliament be established to inquire into and report on-
(1) the power, jurisdiction and effectiveness of the Australian Parliament;
(2) the privileges of the Australian Parliament;
(3) the proceedings and usage of the Australian Parliament;
(4) the machinery of the Australian Parliament, and
(5) the relationship of the media of mass communications to the Australian Parliament.

Let me conclude on this, I hope, succinct point. So many of the procedures in this House belong to a much earlier age, perhaps measured in centuries distant from the present time. They are irrelevant in many important respects to the things we have to consider and the way in which our society wishes to proceed. There is, as Laurie Oakes very correctly observed, at least in this respect, a great burden of frustration upon the shoulders of so many intelligent and able members of Parliament who wish to be diligent. The present procedures stand in the way of what could be many instances of valuable productive work.
