The proposal I have put forward, which is quite comprehensive, is that a joint committee of the Parliament should exhaustively explore the way in which the Parliament functions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman is going beyond the indulgence. He is speaking to the motion.
—Mr Speaker, could we consider an early slating of this issue for discussion and, I hope, sensible dissertation rather than point scoring in a partisan way?

—In responding quickly to the Leader of the Opposition, let me make this point: Politics enter into this chamber inevitably. The honourable gentlemen, in his search for a change of the rules, cannot search for the elimination of the politics. If we cannot eliminate the politics the next thing to do is give the chamber all the dignity it can have while discussing political issues. I must draw the honourable gentleman's attention to this point: The House of Commons, to which the honourable gentleman referred in an applauding fashion, for over a century has adopted the practice of the continuity of an independent Speaker. I have been pursuing this matter for a long while. I have no doubt that the honourable gentleman ought to consider it very seriously. It certainly would be following a precedent which has proved to be good in the House of Commons. Apart from that, I ought to point out to the honourable gentlemen that from my observation of the House of Commons there are occasions on which the noisiness and the interjections are even worse than they are in this House.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW OF THE SEA: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(a) notes that the resumed Tenth Session of the Third United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea decided on 28 August 1981 that the next (Eleventh) Session of the Conference, to be held from 8 March to 30 April 1982, is intended to take final decisions on the provisions of the text, so that a Convention can be opened for signature at Caracas, Venezuela, later that year; and also notes that the United States review of its Law of the Sea policies will soon be completed;

(b) reaffirms its commitment to the basic objectives of the Conference in working for the conclusion of a comprehensive and widely-accepted Convention on the Law of the Sea which would lay down a balanced and equitable regime, both for the use of the seas by all people for all legitimate purposes, and for the management and use of the resources of the seas and the seabed;
(c) recognises that Australia has vital interests in the early conclusion of these negotiations; and

(d) strongly expresses the hope that the United States Administration will decide to join with the rest of the international community in working for the successful conclusion of the work of the Conference at its Eleventh Session.

For some time I have had a motion on the Notice Paper relating to the law of the sea. As a result of some discussions with the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) it has been agreed that this House will consider a further motion which is an amendment to the one originally proposed by me. It reaffirms our commitment to the basic objectives of the law of the sea and it emphasises Australia's vital interests in having an early conclusion to those negotiations. Most importantly, it expresses the hope that the United States will decide to join with the rest of the international community in working to a successful conclusion of the work of the United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea at its eleventh session. At the outset might I thank the Minister for agreeing to the terms of this today and also for the constructive attitude that he has taken in respect of this matter. I appreciate it. It is very pleasing that there can be a bipartisan approach to matters that are very significant to Australia.

I remind the House and those who are interested in this matter that the current law of the sea negotiations represent the greatest attempt at international co-operation since the founding of the United Nations. If these negotiations are successful they will provide a treaty which will peacefully regulate two-thirds of the world's surface, a treaty which will provide mechanisms for the peaceful settlement of disputes arising between nations concerning their maritime boundaries and their activities on the high seas. We need look no further than the recent incident between Libya and the United States involving the Gulf of Sidra to realise just how important such mechanisms can be.

Because the negotiations are important, tremendous efforts have been made over a period of nine years by representatives of 150 countries-virtually the whole international community. We have a vital interest and a vital role in these matters. We have played a very leading part successfully concluding a comprehensive and widely accepted convention. I thank our career representatives who have taken part in these negotiations. It is not only in Australia's interest but also in the interest of the international community. Let me reiterate what it means to Australia at the national level. It means that we acquire an extended territorial sea of 12 miles over which we will exercise full sovereignty. In addition, we will acquire a 200-mile economic zone which will give us effective, if somewhat limited, sovereignty over an additional one million square miles of territory off the Australian coastline. This territory is rich in mineral, hydrocarbon and marine resources. We are also guaranteed freedom of passage for our own merchant fleet and our navy through international straits and archipelagic waters, internationally regulated and ordered exploitation of the resources of the high seas and the deep seabed which will be not only to our advantage, but also, most importantly, to the advantage of many of the poorest countries in the world. We are also guaranteed the protection and preservation of that environment.

For many developing countries, including a number of our Pacific island neighbours, the greatest single resource is the living and mineral resources of the 200-mile zone which the law of the sea treaty will give them. Our Pacific neighbours and developing countries do not want to be relying on handouts. What they want is to have their own resources developed and to be self-supporting members of the international community. The matter of the law of the sea, more than any single item on the current international agenda, provides the opportunity for them to achieve that goal. In two weeks' time the Commonwealth heads of government will meet in Melbourne. They will address themselves to the issue of North-South dialogue and the importance of a more equitable share of the world's resources with the nations which are now struggling to feed and clothe their people. But while many suggestions have been made, many proposals considered, the hard fact is that the major proposal on the international drawing board which would give practical help to the vast majority of these countries is the successful conclusion of the Law of the Sea Treaty.

To its credit Australia has recognised this fact and has played a key role, but we have reached a crucial turning point-a point at which the greatest single power in the world and our ally, the United States, has thrown the success of the project into doubt. The most recent round of negotiations concluded late last month. The next round commences early next year. The Conference has decided that it will be the final opportunity to reach agreement, but unfortunately at this point the United States has made no commitment to attend the final session. I sincerely hope that it will do so, and the point of this motion is to impress upon the United States how important this issue is as seen from the Pacific region.

I had discussions recently in respect of the law of the sea negotiations with the Foreign Minister of Mexico, the Foreign Minister of Canada, and the Prime Minister and Foreign Minister of Fiji. There is a strong feeling of support for this issue and concern at the failure of the United States to agree to a successful conclusion. When I spoke to the Prime Minister of one of the leading countries in the Pacific I asked him what the position in the Pacific would be if the United States did not co-operate. He made this point: The United States would not have a friend left in the Pacific. The Opposition does not want to see that happen and I know that the Government does not want to see it happen. The purpose of this motion is to convey our concern to Washington in a most sincere spirit of friendship and co-operation.

TALK.START.PARA: -Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. The Government supports it in the bipartisan spirit which has characterised the approach of successive Australian governments to the United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea. The motion refers to Australia's vital interests and to the early conclusion of the law of the sea negotiations. This is a point I have made frequently both inside and outside this House. In a statement I made to the House on 26 May, as honourable members may recall, I said that Australia, as an island continent with extensive off-shore areas and heavily dependent on international trade, had a vital interest in the issues before the Conference and that it was an objective of the Australian Government that the international law of the sea should be cleared of the doubts and uncertainties that now exist.

SPEECH.PARA: To this end successive governments of Australia, both on this side of politics and the other, have taken the view that our substantial interests in the law of the sea would best be protected by the early adoption of a comprehensive and widely accepted convention. It is not just our national interests but also our membership of the international community which provide strong grounds for maintaining the bipartisan spirit with respect to the Law of the Sea Conference. International agreement on a regime to cover all the resources of the sea and all the uses to which the sea can be put would be of enormous significance to the international community. It would represent a triumph of co-operation over conflict and of dialogue over dispute.

I take this opportunity to inform the House briefly of the most recent developments at the Law of the Sea Conference whose resumed tenth session ended, after four weeks work, on 28 August. Firstly, on specific issues a wide measure of agreement was reached on the sensitive question of how maritime boundaries should be drawn between adjacent or opposite states. In addition, the Conference decided that the proposed international seabed authority, the body that will regulate mining activities on the deep-sea bed beyond national jurisdiction, would be located in Jamaica and that the Law of the Sea Tribunal would be located in Hamburg in the Federal Republic of Germany. But perhaps the most significant achievement of the session was that the Conference survived the strains arising out of the continuing uncertainty over the future participation of the United States in its work. That nation was given the opportunity of discussing the concerns it has with the present draft convention in preparation for the United States Administration to decide its future course.

As stated in the motion before the House, we hope that the United States Government will now decide to join with the rest of the international community in working for the successful conclusion of the work of the Conference at its eleventh session which is to be held in March and April next year. It is a hope that will be widely shared around the world. I expect that a number of countries may be making their views known to the United States authorities. The Forum island countries of the Pacific have suggested that the Law of the Sea Conference be discussed at the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. I welcome the opportunity that this motion provides for this House to make its views known on a subject which has such special importance for us as a major trading nation and as an island continent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cass The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in this debate very briefly as I was Minister for the Environment at the time we were involved in these discussions. A number of factors were involved. We were concerned that with unrestrained exploitation the environmental threats could have an effect on everybody, not just those countries that border the sea. If the ocean is damaged or the ecology of the ocean is in any way harmed that may have very harmful effects on us all. After all, we draw a lot of living resources from the sea and that is the danger. We need only to look at the effect of unrestrained whaling to see what I am talking about. Of course, the large enterprises in America that are already geared up to develop these resources in the sea wish to proceed straight away and do not want to be restrained by anything.

SPEECH.PARA: My fear-which obviously is implied in this motion-is that the American Administration appears at this stage to be bowing to those commercial pressures and not paying due regard to the concern of the rest of the world, including, I suggest, the long term interests of the United States of America. For those reasons it is a very significant fact that we have managed to evolve a bipartisan approach to this problem. Without the law of the sea we will be confronted with enormous problems. It is extremely important that a satisfactory conclusion be drawn to the negotiations that have gone on for years, and to which the Americans have been a party. Sadly, the new regime appears to have failed to take into account this long and painful development and it is too readily bowing to pressure from narrow commercial interests in the United States. For that reason I certainly support this recommendation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to pursue a policy of nuclear disarmament, cessation of the global arms race and a significant reduction in the transfer of armaments.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There could be no more important matter in the world today than the survival of the world. The purpose of this discussion of a matter of public importance is to condemn the Government for its failure to pursue policies which would lead to the eventual peace and stability of the world. I know that for some time the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has made speeches on the matter but the question is: What happens following those speeches? In fact, in the period between speeches we get nothing other than a further escalation of armaments. This situation occurs in relation to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the United States of America and a number of intermediaries that are very busily engaged in the production of weapons. Unfortunately and tragically those weapons are being used every day, every hour, and every minute for the death and destruction of human beings. We cannot just step aside and say 'it will not happen to us'. Once we come to the nuclear threshold-we have now reached that point-we are all involved. As we are all involved we have a vested interest in making our point of view known.

SPEECH.PARA: A very good forum for this would be the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting conference which is about to take place in Australia. What the heads of government assembling here can do to convince the super powers and the other powers in the world about what must be done to bring about a cessation of the arms race and de-escalation of weapons-ultimately, the removal of all weapons-ought to be the number one item on the agenda. I am well aware that there has been a build up of weapons between the super powers. But it is also very significant that in Australia we are rather silent about condemning what is happening. We are prepared to condemn the Russians, and so they should be condemned when they invade Afghanistan and threaten Poland. Everybody accepts that situation. But we seem to be very soft on the issue of the deterrent build up of arms in the Western countries.

I find most ridiculous the suggestion that we can support the concept of the neutron bomb. That suggestion is put on the basis that the United States must have the neutron bomb to match the Russian tanks that are assembled on the western flank of Europe. Admittedly, the Russians have a lot of tanks there but we must also think about their eastern flank. If honourable members want to put a case from the point of view of numbers-surely it should not be left to that-there are probably more tanks behind the North Atlantic Treaty organisation forces than the Russians have. For sheer arithmetical calculations we do not just look at whether one country has 4,500 tanks and the NATO forces have perhaps 1,500 and then exclude from that count the number of tanks that, for example, France or the United Kingdom have and the question of other supporting arms. I think it is ridiculous to say that we must have the neutron bomb concept to counter the tank concept. The reasoning is not valid. We are not going to get a limited nuclear war. The neutron bomb is a nuclear weapon. In fact we are fast approaching the neutron bullet, a weapon that can be used in action by every soldier. Once the nuclear capacity is used in warfare there is no limit to the extent to which it will eventually be used. If we brought all the nuclear missiles of the two super powers into play they would exceed 20,000. The pair are evenly balanced. The United States said that at the moment it cannot find any way to eliminate them. Perhaps we can understand that if the question is approached on the concept that what the Soviet Union has must be matched. By the same token, the Soviet Union says that it cannot see where it can give ground because of the concentration against it. That is a valid argument in a number of areas, not the least of which is the United States policy to build up China as a third force to counter any Soviet expansion.

What is Australia about? Surely, as a third party involved in this area, we could say that we do not applaud the neutron bomb. Yet the Prime Minister has said that he can understand the reasons for it. At the same time, have we deplored other matters that relate directly to the future of Australia? Why are we saying that there is nothing wrong with a concept of giving arms to China? Why is it that we make no protest when the Chinese fire an intercontinental ballistic missile into the Pacific and say we understand it, think it is reasonable, and thank them for giving us notice in advance? Does that do anything for peace and stability in the world? Why is it that we think it is reasonable to suggest that Japan could be re-armed on the basis that it also will act as a deterrent to the Soviet Union? In the process of talking about our region, why is it that we make no condemnation of the fact that Mr Holdridge, a senior United States diplomat, said when in China that there was no reason why there should not be military pressure put on Vietnam? There was no objection at all from this Government.

At the present there is military action in Afghanistan, a civil war perhaps in Iran, and certainly a war between Iraq and Iran, conflict is still raging in Lebanon in the Middle East. At least 200,000 Lebanese are living in this country. They are wondering when the Government will say something about the future of Lebanon. There has been plenty of discussion about a peacekeeping force for Sinai. But there has been no Government discussion at all about the future of the Palestinians and the West Bank. The fact that that matter has not been solved has brought about the virtual destruction of Lebanon. This is, of course, a crucial issue for the Lebanese people. They cannot understand why the peacekeeping force has to be limited to one segment of that area when their country is being destroyed and when thousands upon thousands of Lebanese have died. Their next of kin in Australia are wondering when the Government will raise the question of peace and stability in that region.

All armaments used in these conflicts are supplied by either the Soviet Union or the United States. They produce billions and billions of dollars worth of weapons, not for their own defence in many cases, but for sale. The Stockholm International Peace Research Institute says that the Soviet Union is doing very well, thank you. It supplies about 30 per cent of arms sales to the Third World. The United States, not to be outdone, provides about 45 per cent. In the past 10 years arms sales to the Third World have totalled $US60 billion. So, there is a race between the two super-powers. They run the most profitable business in the world-selling arms to others. We, in Australia, have not officially condemned what is happening.

In considering the question of de-escalation of the arms race, Australia should adopt some of the initiatives that have been adopted by other countries. I recommend to the Government that it seek membership of the Independent Commission on Disarmament and Security Issues. The Commission recently held its third meeting in Vienna. In simple terms, its idea is to prevent armament and to guarantee progress towards disarmament. It has a distinguished membership. Members include the Commonwealth Secretary-General, Mr Ramphal, who will be leading the secretariat of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne in a few days time; the former Prime Ministers of Sweden, Norway and Holland; Mr Cyrus Vance, the former United States Secretary of State; Dr David Owen, the former British Foreign Secretary; Mr Arbatov of the Soviet Union and others. That membership shows that at least there can be an assembly of people who can talk how to save the world and how to bring about peace in the world. Unless that is done we are heading for a holocaust no matter how we try to avoid it. In a speech to the United Nations on disarmament in 1978, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said:

We need greater progress for SALT negotiations. We need the creation of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty. We need methods to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons among nations which currently do not have them. We need to study the relationship between disarmament and the developing needs of the poor countries and we need the creation of reasonable arms control arrangements such as an Indian Ocean zone of peace.

We applaud all that. What has happened to those concepts outlined in the Prime Minister's speech in 1978? Washington has failed to make progress with the SALT agreement. It has abandoned it. Whilst it may be claimed it abandoned it because of the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, I remind the House that I knew well before that that it would not be done because United States senators took a view in which they did not agree with President Carter. They had no intention of endorsing SALT two arrangements. It is no excuse to say that there were difficulties over Afghanistan that prevented the United States from going ahead with that agreement. The United States has opposed the creation of a comprehensive test ban treaty. Far from preventing the spread of nuclear weapons among nations the policies that are now being adopted encourage their proliferation, not the least of which policies would offer an encouragement to South Africa to become very active, particularly in relation to Angola. It is thought that the South Africans have a capacity for building armaments with a nuclear potential. Do these policies do anything to encourage Japan, which also has a nuclear potential, to increase its defence forces? This Government said nothing about that. The introduction into Australian territory of the B52 bombers, obviously with a nuclear capacity, does nothing about safeguarding us in the immediate future. Talk about a zone of peace in the Indian Ocean does nothing when we have the B52 bombers operating in that sphere.

We can applaud the United States for suggesting that there ought to be zones of peace in the Middle East and the Pacific Ocean. We would like to extend that zone of peace to the Indian Ocean. We commend those things. The Reagan Administration does not seem to be doing anything about the need to study that relationship. 'Zone of peace' is just an expression. When we talk of disarmament and the poor countries being involved in war we seem to be going in the other direction. There seems to be this feeling in the Reagan Administration of not really being interested in the North-South dialogue. That is a matter of great concern. I notice that it has been made clear in the Reagan Budget that foreign aid to the poorer countries has been reduced.

In the context of this matter of public importance which we are putting to the House this morning let us look at the facts as they are now as against what the Prime Minister expressed them to be-facts with which we agreed in 1978-and then let us look at what has happened from our point of view. Let us look at this question of the proliferation of nuclear weapons. We have abandoned the requirement of consent before reprocessing. Let us look at what is happening in relation to weapon capacity and sales. Does it do anything for peace and stability to suggest that we will encourage the United States to sell some $2.25 billion worth of equipment to Pakistan? Pakistan also has a nuclear capacity and could well be involved in a nuclear confrontation with India. What does India do? It immediately decides that it too has to escalate its ability to provide a nuclear capacity. We can look immediately to our north, where a concentration, use and encouragement of weapons could lead to a situation where, if disaster breaks out, we would get the residue. If there is military action between China and Vietnam we will have to deal with the millions of refugees; nobody else will.

What sort of policy is the Government adopting when it encourages no aid to Vietnam? In fact, it wants to bring Vietnam to its knees. Of what value was it to wait until yesterday to protest to Pretoria about the invasion of Angola by the South Africans? They know that they need not care any more about apartheid because the United States Administration said: 'Do not worry about it; we will give you full support'. Certainly we oppose communism. The great threat to the world is the fact that communism is failing. There could be encouragement by the Soviet Union if it were suggested that it adopt military action to prop up some of these failures, whether it be in Poland or elsewhere. If in that process there is escalation of the fear that the United States and other countries are also building up their weapons, where is the deterrent? If some country thinks it will fail in a confrontation, it might fire the first weapon.

We want to see in Australia an independent approach to this issue on the basis of what can be done for the world. Our role is not to remain silent. We should not just run along with what everybody else thinks ought to be the situation. There are too many troubles now. They relate to the Middle East. They relate to South East Asia. They relate to the African continent. They relate to Latin America. Every one of those areas is using armaments. What are these countries being encouraged to do all the time-to contain the philosophy of communism? That is no way to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government welcomes this opportunity to put on record its policy on nuclear disarmament and arms control generally. The Government has pursued consistently and vigorously a policy of nuclear disarmament and strongly supports the goal of non-proliferation-the prevention of the spread of nuclear weapons. At the Special Session of the General Assembly of the United Nations on disarmament held in New York in July 1978 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)-this is a quote additional to that given by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen)-said:

SPEECH.PARA: The first focus of the program of action for arms control and disarmament must be on issues of nuclear arms control. My Government's position is clear and unequivocal. We oppose further escalation of the nuclear arms race. We oppose the spread of nuclear weapons.
At the Special Session the Prime Minister outlined the Government's approach to nuclear disarmament. He stated:

First, the nuclear weapons powers must take effective action to limit and reduce their nuclear arsenals. Second, there must be an end to nuclear testing in all environments. Third, the international non-proliferation system must be strengthened.

In practical terms this approach has meant Australian support for the strategic arms limitation talks-that is SALT-process. That process is essential to the limitation of the vertical proliferation of nuclear weapons. The Government has also been a leading proponent of the drawing up of a comprehensive test ban treaty-the CTB. This is essential to action designed to meet the objective of an end to nuclear testing in all environments. The Government's unwavering support for the non-proliferation treaty regime has played an important part in shoring up measures against horizontal proliferation.

It must be recognised, though, that the current international climate is not favourable to the successful negotiation of disarmament and arms control measures. The reason for this is the Soviet Union's armaments program and the instability and anxiety it has created by such actions as its invasion of Afghanistan and its support for Vietnam's invasion of Kampuchea. The willingness of states to enter into successful arms control and disarmament measures depends upon a degree of mutual trust and confidence. It is tragic that Soviet actions and Soviet policy have jeopardised that trust and confidence. Notwithstanding this international political climate the Government is and remains determined to maintain its strong support for the goal of disarmament and the negotiation of balanced and verifiable measures of arms control.

In a statement to Parliament on 24 March I stressed that either 'inadvertently' or 'deliberately' there 'are always some, while they find it possible to remain silent in the face of huge military efforts on the part of the Soviet Union, raise the cry of war mongering whenever the West shows any signs of matching that effort.' The fact remains that as the United States reduced or stabilised its military forces over the last decade the Soviet response has been an unrelenting and threatening build-up in all theatres.

The Reagan Administration has emphasised that there is a direct relationship between arms control and disarmament measures and the maintenance of general international security. Both President Reagan and Secretary of State Haig have pledged the United States to continuing support for balanced and verifiable disarmament and arms control measures. They have, however, made it clear that any such measures are bound to fail unless they are linked to restoration of the strategic balance and strengthening of the security of nations. For its part, the United States has made it clear that it is determined to redress the strategic balance with the Soviet Union. This is consistent with United States' security and supports Western security generally. The government has no doubt that the United States will continue to exercise its global responsibilities to the benefit of peace and security in the world. Indeed, Secretary of State Haig has indicated that he will be meeting with Soviet Foreign Minister Gromyko later this month to discuss the resumption of United States-Soviet negotiations on the limitation of theatre nuclear forces in Europe. It is hoped that those negotiations will resume towards the end of this year. We support this positive development.

The decision by the United States Government to manufacture and stockpile the enhanced radiation weapon-that is, the neutron bomb-must be seen in its proper context. The previous United States Administration gave consideration to the manufacture of that weapon but decided to defer such a decision. It is a matter for deepest regret that subsequently the Soviet Union did not respond positively to that decision. Instead, it continued with a massive and threatening armaments program with particular impact upon the European theatre. It is in response to that Soviet policy that the United States Administration has now felt it necessary to proceed to manufacture the neutron weapon. That weapon has as its main purpose the deterrence of Soviet armoured capability in Europe. No decision has yet been made on the deployment of the weapon, which is a matter for consideration between the United States and its European allies. I would also recall that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics itself is reported to have tested a neutron weapon and that France has tested a weapon and intends to pursue studies and research into the possible development of the weapon.

Quite contrary to what might be inferred from the wording of the issue before the House, Australia is an active participant in the major international bodies concerned with disarmament and arms control negotiations. It has played a prominent role, particularly in the United Nations Committee on Disarmament and in the First Commitee of the General Assembly where arms control and disarmament matters are considered. Australia's efforts in this regard have been recognised internationally as strong and helpful. There can be no doubt about the Government's deep commitment to nuclear disarmament and to the cessation of the global arms race. As my colleagues are well aware successive Australian Governments over a long period have followed a policy of rigorous control over the export of arms and warlike stores. Applications for the sale abroad of such material from Australian sources are subjected to close and rigorous scrutiny.

The Government is opposed to private traffic in arms. With regard to governments, a commitment is required of the importing government that there will be no resale to third countries without the prior approval of the Australian Government. The controls imposed by the Australian Government on the export of arms and warlike stores are fully in keeping with those applied by like-minded governments on countries possessing comparable weapons manufacturing industries. The controls we apply serve both Australia's national interests and the broader courses of world peace and stability. The Government remains concerned, however, over the magnitude of international trade in armaments. It is committed to assist in the development of any effective measures which might reduce the magnitude of that trade. It is also fully aware, however, that the surest and most enduring way to reduce trade in arms is for all governments to pursue policies, consistent with the Charter of the United Nations, which respect the independence and security of all States. It is only when States are able to feel secure and have confidence in their dealings with other States that the recourse to arms will be reduced. I repeat: It is the policies of the Soviet Union which constitute today the chief source of insecurity and mistrust between many nations in both the developed and the developing world.

The Government has emphasised the importance it attaches to the North-South dialogue, to an improvement in practical co-operation between the developed and developing world. This is an issue of major international significance. That priority is one of the chief victims of aggressive and hostile foreign policies. Equally, progress in the North-South dialogue would be greatly assisted by progress in disarmament and arms control measures. For our part, we are committed to playing the most positive role possible on both of these fronts-arms control and disarmament measures, and the maintenance of the North-South dialogue.

Finally, in the light of recent reports of the possible use of lethal toxic agents in Laos and Kampuchea, I would like to stress that the Australian Government is unequivocally opposed to the use of chemical and biological weapons. The Government notes with concern, however, the increasing number of reports of the use of such weapons in recent years, not only in Indo-China but also Afghanistan and elsewhere. Such means of warfare are banned by the 1925 Geneva Protocol for the prohibition of the use in war of asphyxiating, poisonous or other gases, and of bacteriological methods of warfare. The development of biological agents or toxins as weapons is specifically prohibited by the 1972 Convention on Biological Weapons. Australia is a party to both these conventions. At last year's session of the United Nations General Assembly, Australia co-sponsored a resolution which led to the establishment of a group of qualified medical and technical experts to investigate reports of chemical weapons use. The report of this expert group is expected shortly.

Australia is an active participant in discussions in the Committee on Disarmament in Geneva of a proposed international treaty for a comprehensive ban on chemical weapons. I am sure that my colleague would support the need for the rigorous investigation of all reports involving the use of chemical weapons and, should they be substantiated, would join in condemning their use.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Killen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill makes a number of unrelated amendments to the Defence Act 1903 and consequential amendments to the Defence (Visiting Forces) Act 1963. The most pressing of the amendments are those made by clause 6 of the Bill, which are intended to provide a means of protecting the livelihood of Defence Force reservists who suffer long term total incapacity for work as a result of compensable injuries received during Reserve service. Publicity was given some time ago to the fact that some Reserve units were taking out commercial insurance policies, at their own expense, to meet this situation. The Government takes the view that it is not appropriate that reservists should have to pay their own premiums to protect themselves against events occurring outside their normal civilian occupations, when these events are related to voluntary national defence training in their spare time. The Government accordingly decided, as I announced on 30 June this year, that legislation should be brought down to amend the Defence Act to bring the entitlements of totally incapacitated reservists more into line with those of totally incapacitated regular servicemen.

Under the Compensation (Australian Government Employees) Act 1971, employees totally incapacitated through their employment receive normal weekly earnings for up to 26 weeks and then statutory weekly payments not exceeding a prescribed amount per week, with extra amounts for dependants. In the case of regular servicemen, their normal military salary and relevant allowances continue while they remain members. If such a member's service is terminated and his incapacity is assessed as more than 60 per cent in relation to civil employment, he becomes entitled to a class 'A' Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits invalidity pension of 76.5 per cent of his normal military salary.

Section 58B of the Defence Act empowers the Minister for Defence to determine financial conditions of service for members of the Defence Force. Clause 6 of the Bill amends section 58B to empower the Minister for Defence to determine the payment of additional compensation to reservists to whom compensation is payable under the Compensation Act. It is intended that a determination be made entitling a totally incapacitated reservist, after the first 26 weeks of incapacity, to an addition to the amount payable under the Compensation Act to bring his total weekly entitlement to 76.5 per cent of his average civilian weekly earnings or, if he was previously unemployed or a student, to 76.5 per cent of his reserve military salary. This determination will, in common with all other section 58B determinations, be subject to tabling in, and disallowance by, the Parliament, and will be drafted in such a way as to give the reservist a right to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against decisions made under the determination concerning the amount of additional compensation payable.

Clause 9 of the Bill marks an interesting new development, namely, the necessity to legislate regarding control over members of the public using defence lands for recreational purposes where general access for that purpose is permitted. There is an increasing use by the public of defence property for recreational purposes where this is compatible with defence requirements. This is a matter of interest to State authorities from at least four aspects, namely, the availability of such areas for use by their citizens; the development in such areas of recreational facilities such as barbeques and camping areas; the conservation of such areas; and the maintenance of law and order in such areas. The authorities of the States concerned have been most co-operative in this matter. I thank them for that co-operation. However, the States lack the power to make the legislation required to provide the necessary controls.

Adequate power to control the activities of members of the public on defence property is normally provided by the Public Order (Protection of Persons and Property) Act 1971, the Crimes Act 1914, the Defence Act 1903 and State criminal law. However, these powers and common law powers are not very suitable where persons are permitted to enter for recreational purposes, particularly where large areas are involved necessitating the employment of rangers. Where the ecology of the area is fragile, as at Garden Island in Western Australia, it is essential that there be practical powers of control over such matters as camping, the lighting of fires, the use of off-road vehicles and the removal of plants.

The nature and extent of the problem will be appreciated when I mention that some of the defence properties are quite large. Garden Island in Western Australia is about 1,200 hectares in extent, of which the public is allowed access to an area of about 950 hectares. Beecroft Peninsula at Jervis Bay is even larger, comprising about 4,600 hectares. We are faced, in effect, with a situation similar in a number of respects to that presented by the control of national parks, and the solution adopted is to pass legislation based, to the extent appropriate, on the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 of the Commonwealth. Clause 9 accordingly inserts a new Part IXB into the Defence Act which provides for such matters as the declaration of the relevant parts of defence lands as public areas; the appointment of rangers; their powers of arrest and search; and offences such as impersonating or assaulting rangers. The legislation also empowers the Minister for Defence to make by-laws relating to the control and management of public areas. All by-laws will be subject to tabling in, and disallowance by, the Parliament.

Provision is also made permitting the continued operation of State and Territory laws. This will permit the operation of laws such as those relating to the declaration of high fire danger. On the question of defence lands, I mention finally the Naval Establishments (Public Areas) Regulations. These were made at the end of 1980 as an interim arrangement pending the preparation and passing of the Bill now before the House. The regulations are necessarily limited in their scope. They cannot apply to all defence lands but only to those which fall within the definition of 'naval establishment' in the Naval Defence Act 1910, nor can they encompass all the matters dealt with in the new Part IXB of the Defence Act. The regulations will be repealed in due course.

The remaining provisions of the Bill may be dealt with more briefly. Clause 8, taken in conjunction with Part III of the Bill, which amends the Defence (Visiting Forces) Act 1963, in effect transfers certain provisions from the latter Act to the Defence Act. The operation of these provisions is not restricted to visiting forces and their inclusion in the Defence (Visiting Forces) Act 1963 was done as a matter of expediency, as the House was informed at the time. The provisions in question relate to attachments of personnel between the Australian Defence Force and the armed forces of other countries, mutual powers of command between such forces and the arrest and disposal of illegal absentees from the armed forces of other countries. In the main, the differences between the new provisions and the existing provisions are of a drafting or clarifying nature.

Significant changes are the provision of additional safeguards where illegal absentees from the forces of other countries are held in custody by the Australian authorities. The Bill requires the person who has custody of the illegal absentee to cause an authorised officer to be informed and to ensure that the person in custody understands his right to request his release. The power of an authorised officer, who is appointed by a Chief of Staff, to hand the arrested person over to the authorities of his own country is abolished and this power is to be vested in the Minister for Defence. One other significant change has been made where an officer of the armed forces of another country is given command over Australian forces. The Chief of Defence Force Staff is empowered by the Bill to limit the scope of the powers of command and discipline that may be exercised.

The remaining amendments of any consequence are made to the regulation-making powers in the Defence Act. These clarify the power to make regulations on four matters. Firstly, in addition to providing for the forfeiture of salary and allowances of members of the Defence Force who are absent without leave, provision may be made for the suspension of the payment of salary. Secondly, in addition to providing for the establishment and operation of Service canteens and messes, provision may be made subjecting them to Commonwealth, State and Territory taxes, other than income tax. Thirdly, provision may be made for compensation by the Commonwealth for loss, injury or damage by reason of anything done under the Defence Act as, for example, the exercise of control over building heights in the vicinity of defence airfields. Fourthly, in addition to providing for the appointment and procedures of service courts and boards of inquiry, provision may be made under which a witness may be compelled to answer a question although the answer may be self-incriminating, and a witness may be provided with protection against the use of the answer in proceedings against him before a Service tribunal or a civil court.

This last matter calls for further explanation. Boards of inquiry are held, not infrequently, to investigate such matters as the loss of an aircraft, a fatal accident involving the use of service weapons or equipment, the grounding of a ship or a failure in the operation of a ship's navigational or propulsion equipment, as well as deficiencies in, loss of or damage to stores. The primary purpose of a board of inquiry, particularly if there has been a serious or fatal accident, is to ascertain as quickly as possible what, if anything, went wrong and to prevent a recurrence. It may be that the board of inquiry's investigation will reveal some dereliction of duty and result in subsequent disciplinary action, but this must not be allowed to negate the primary purpose of the inquiry.

In order that the truth be established without delay, it is essential that witnesses give their evidence frankly. In the case of possible equipment failure, for example, which could result in, say, the grounding of aircraft, a witness who is provided with adequate protection against self-incrimination would probably be more ready to admit that the failure was caused by error on his part and not by any inherent defect in design. The law relating to boards of accident inquiry under the Air Navigation Act 1920 and to royal commissions, contains similar provisions. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Dawkins) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAXATION (ADMINISTRATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 September, on motion by Mr Howard:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill, the Australian Capital Territory Tax (Life Insurance Business) Bill, the Australian Capital Territory Tax (Vehicle Registration) Bill and the Australian Capital Territory Tax (Insurance Business) Amendment Bill (No. 2) as they are associated measured. (Quorum formed). Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these four Bills? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is not opposing these Bills which apply State taxes to the Australian Capital Territory, apparently in some instances at the behest of the State governments concerned. However, it is our intention to move an amendment because we are not satisfied that the application of State taxes as an automatic consequence of State government activities or State government representations is acceptable to a significant portion of the Australian population. Australian Capital Territory residents are the only group within Australia which is denied any say in local and State type taxes applied to their area and is also denied the right to fix its priorities on where those taxes should apply and what concessions would apply to that area.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Australian Capital Territory Taxation (Administration) Amendment Bill. The amendment sets out a position which should be acceptable to the Australian Parliament because it outlines some degree of acceptance of the fact that people are entitled to express opinions and to have representations when taxes are applied. That argument is not valid in respect of national taxes or those taxes which are applied generally throughout the Australian community on behalf of the Australian Government as revenue measures. We may or may not object and the members who represent this area may or may not object to those Commonwealth revenue measures. We have a right to express an opinion in this place and to vote directly against these measures. Those taxes which are a consequence really of providing a tax framework which is comparable with those in the States and the Northern Territory are at the behest of those governments for their revenue needs and are framed in such a way as the representatives of the people in those areas, in isolation from the rest of the Commonwealth, wish to apply their taxes.

Because the Australian Capital Territory has no form of self-government or municipal government and is dependent on this Parliament for its basic decision making process, we believe it is necessary that prior to the application of additional State type taxes the Parliament should have before it a comparison of State type taxes and other related matters as they apply in the various States and Territories. For instance, whilst payroll tax is not part of this Bill, the Australian Capital Territory applies payroll tax on the basis that it is applied in New South Wales and Victoria. That is the justification for payroll tax in the Australian Capital Territory. It is a Commonwealth revenue item and the revenue raised may or may not be returned to the residents of the Australian Capital Territory as part of its State tax support and for the support of those programs in this area which would have derived from State Budgets. But those taxes are raised without the same considerations which go into the taxes in the States. For instance, if the Australian Capital Territory, which is subject, as I understand it, to taxes on payroll similar to New South Wales-and certainly not at a lower rate-were in fact applying the taxes under the New South Wales State Act which applies to all the areas which surround the Australian Capital Territory, and which I think it is reasonable to say is as a general consequence in competition with the Australian Capital Territory in respect of say, private development capital for business activities, then those taxes would be subject to certain concessions which are not available in the Australian Capital Territory. Certainly, in Victoria, such concessions are available. For example, in Geelong in my electorate which would seem to be reasonably comparable-it is not quite as large though it is a single provincial city-a 50 per cent deduction in payroll tax is available to decentralised industries established in that area. In Ballarat and Bendigo in Victoria a total exemption from payroll tax is available to decentralised industries. This may or may not be an advantage. It may or may not be something which the residents of the Australian Capital Territory would wish as one of their priorities on taxes. But it is not an option open to them. They are, in fact, dependent to some degree on pressure from States which are seeking to make the Australian Capital Territory less attractive for business and other activities than their own competing interests. The States have a vested interest in that respect. They are also seeking to have applied, without any consideration of the priorities which the residents of this area would apply, taxes which may or may not have been chosen as revenue measures had this area made its own determinations.

This legislation applies taxes in respect of a number of matters. I believe we are entitled as a parliament to have before us a comparative statement in respect of taxes which are applied in the Australian Capital Territory, the revenue measures available in the Australian Capital Territory. I think it is also essential-and this is especially so with regard to vehicle registrations-to have before us some indication of the priorities which would exist if members of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly were, in fact, determining which concessions would be available. For instance, whilst probably it is proper for this Parliament to look on diplomatic registrations as a reasonable exemption from motor registrations-it is probable that applying these registration fees would break an international convention-it is not a priority which I think the people of Victoria, New South Wales or Tasmania would accept as reasonable for forgoing revenues. The Australian Capital Territory licensing and registration revenues are, in fact, deductible by those amounts. There are varying forms of concessions on taxes and registrations in the different States. I believe that we cannot at this stage create a situation whereby Australian Capital Territory determination of these concessions is involved because the whole financial structure of the Australian Capital Territory is, to say the least, unclear and it is certainly tied up in Commonwealth revenues to an extent which makes it almost unextractable. Therefore a proper picture of input and expenditure does not exist. For those reasons the Opposition moves:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'consideration of the Bill be deferred until (a) the House is provided with detailed comparisons with overall localised taxes and revenue measures applied in the States and the Northern Territory, and (b) the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly is consulted on the application in the Australian Capital Territory of state related taxes and that the Assembly be requested to provide a list of priorities for concessions from state type fees and taxes, in order that the Australian Capital Territory will have comparable rights to choose its own priorities as enjoyed by the States and the Northern Territory'.

I move that motion because it expresses what I believe are the basic rights of the people of the Territory. They are entitled to know what in fact the financial structure of the area is, what charges and costs are applied, and whether those charges and costs are being applied in a way in which they would if this area were part of a State or were a self-governing Territory. I believe that in the priorities for exemptions, the people of the Territory should not be worse off than those of the States merely because they are governed by the Australian parliament. It is normal for the State governments, especially at times of elections, to make concessions in a number of areas where they are popular. I point out to the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) that in New South Wales, for instance, motorised wheel chairs are exempt from registration. I am not sure whether that is the case in the Australian Capital Territory. In New South Wales totally and permanently incapacitated pensioners have a concession of approximately 75 per cent. I am not aware whether that concession exists in the Australian Capital Territory. It may be that the Australian Capital Territory has different priorities-I have mentioned the matter of diplomats-but I believe we are entitled, if we are to continue to deny the Australian Capital Territory the right to determine its own concessional rates, to ask the Australian Capital Territory elected representatives for their opinions on these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sainsbury Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like first to comment on the amendment. I do not believe that anybody has any worries in the sense that figures ought to be available so that the Australian Capital Territory revenue and expenditure on State-like matters can be looked at in comparison with its needs and in comparison with what occurs in the States. It seems to me, however, that the amendment ought not to be supported because of the fact that at present it merely seeks to defer the collection of revenue which is an integral part of the Budget. Further, the present anomalies which are being removed are anomalies whose existence I do not believe would be argued by anybody. In other words, the amendment is not going to the root of any possible differences when the total cost comparisons are looked at; it merely seeks to correct some things which, in the eyes of any fair-minded people, ought to be corrected. They are some of the more obvious cases. Perhaps I will get a chance shortly to discuss why they are more obvious than some others.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) raised in an earlier debate relating to similar Bills flowing from the Budget as it affects the Australian Capital Territory this general question of where Canberra stands. Is Canberra better or worse off than the rest of Australia in terms of indirect tax collections, stamp duties and charges which are made on a State-like basis? We do not know. In the views of the Australian people, Canberra is a feather-bedded place, but I agree we do not know. I think I may have mentioned in this place that the late Senator Knight was always saying in private to me that the perception in Australia of Canberra's position in relation to charges is quite wrong. He never was able to show me proof of that, but I think the fact that he and the honourable member for Corio are prepared to say it shows that this comparison ought to be carried out. It will be carried out. I understand that the best body, the Commonwealth Grants Commission, will review this question in 1982. The Grants Commission is still looking at State relativities, and that is something that flowed from decisions made a few months ago. As soon as that State relativities examination is complete, the Commission will become involved in the Canberra question. It seems to me that rather than talk about deferral of present matters until that stage we ought to say: 'No. Let us get these more obvious things sorted out, and then, in a bipartisan spirit, let us look at what the Grants Commission tells us after its review of the Canberra situation in 1982'.

The honourable member for Corio raised another important matter of principle, and that is what sort of judgment the Government ought to make on the Canberra charges question when we have a dichotomy of views. First, Canberra ought to be independent. The people who live in Canberra ought to have decisions made in respect of their revenue according to the specific requirements of Canberra. That recognises that any group in Australia ought to be regarded as a group in which specific decisions ought to be made. In other words, just because there is a specific charge in Western Australia there need not necessarily be the need for the same charge in Canberra. I recognise that. There are special needs and special circumstances in Canberra.

However, Canberra is in the middle of New South Wales; it is completely surrounded by New South Wales. People cross the border, as they may in a federation, without any impediment and use the services of Canberra. That gives rise to the other point of view. How much special consideration ought to be given to the needs of Canberra when it is surrounded by New South Wales? It will be a matter of judgment. No doubt the best solution is some sort of compromise between the two conflicting aims. Certainly, in my position as representing many of the people who live in the surrounding areas of Canberra, I can say that the general view in my electorate is that charges ought to be the same. I have mentioned this matter in the House before. Since the present Government came to power in 1975 there has been a breaking down of the differences. I have instanced a number of areas previously in this place. I do not propose to refer to them again. Certainly insurance stamp duty and stamp duty on the transfer of motor vehicles are two areas in which the anomalies can create problems-perhaps not only for my area but also for the Australian Capital Territory.

It is well known that a number of people who live in New South Wales contrive to have their motor vehicles registered in the Australian Capital Territory even though their place of residence in not in Canberra. When one considers the $2 in $100 stamp duty on the transfer of motor vehicle one can imagine people perhaps looking at ways and means of contriving in this fashion. It seems to me that we may as well call a spade a spade, regularise the procedures and not invite people, to break the theoretical law of New South Wales by going ahead with this. In regard to life insurance matters, I think it is fairly obvious that the people who work in Canberra or in the surrounding areas such as Queanbeyan freely move about. If they live in Queanbeyan today, they are quite likely to live in Canberra next year or vice versa. From that point of view, why have different charges for fundamental arrangements that people enter into such as life insurance? I just say that these things are fairly obvious anomalies that need to be corrected.

Of course, one cannot run away from what flows from that, namely that the Commonwealth has a chance to increase its revenue. Of course, there are in New South Wales some charges that I could not advocate under any circumstances for the Australian Capital Territory. In New South Wales there are some quite heavy imposts. The honourable member for Corio has already referred to the payroll tax situation. In New South Wales there is now a surcharge for companies with payrolls of over $1m. That might sound harmless enough, but I can assure the House that there are in Queanbeyan companies which have payrolls of over $1m and the payrolls of some of the larger employers, such as the Queanbeyan Leagues Club, are extremely high. That one per cent surcharge by the New South Wales Government on payroll tax can cost a lot of money. One per cent of $1m is $10,000 and one per cent of $2m is $20,000. It is not peanuts. That is the sort of thing I do not want to see introduced in Canberra. If anything, I believe the Federal Government ought to be trying to give the lead on the payroll tax question towards the eventual total abolition of what I see as an iniquitous tax.

I recognise-my position on this is quite well known-that if a tax of one sort is reduced or cut out by a State or Federal government without cutting back on programs, which is not usually possible, that forgone tax has to be raised in another way. Certainly I recognise that if payroll tax were cut out, taxes probably would have to be imposed in some other manner. It seems to me that, with payroll tax, the wrong people are being charged at the wrong point and that that militates against employment, especially at this time when employment is one of the most important issues in Australia.

I want to raise a couple of other matters very briefly. First of all, the imposition of any new sales tax, which these Bills refer to, is in a sense a slight movement in the direction of a different mix of tax. This has been a hobby horse of mine, despite the fact that I recognise that in the community there is a perception that a change in the tax mix towards a higher proportion of indirect tax may impose problems for people on lower incomes. I do not agree that that proposition is right, if the situation is handled in a gradually phased way. On the other hand, I believe a mix of tax involving higher indirect taxes can to a very large degree give people greater discretion. One could say that if there are indirect taxes on clothing, that is not discretionary because one must clothe oneself. But that argument is not quite right. There are points in one's preference patterns where one will decide to buy an extra lot of clothing, a motor car or fruit or some other commodity. In our generally affluent society in Australia we have at present over-consumption of many of the things that were previously called essentials. I see anything in the tax system which gives individuals a discretion as a move in the best direction. Of course, on top of that-I do not want to canvass all the arguments-there is the other very substantial argument that wherever there is an indirect tax, many of the people who live in a cash economy, and there are plenty of them in Canberra, at least pay some tax. That is not a facile thing to say and it has been very forcefully put by such people as Professor Mathews.

Another matter to which I hope the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) can address himself shortly concerns the anomalies with respect to workers compensation across the New South Wales-Australian Capital Territory border. The previous Minister for the Capital Territory addressed himself to a problem which occurred when Palmdale Insurance Ltd collapsed. A number of my constituents in Queanbeyan were very hard hit by that because they were employed by companies which had insured through Palmdale. There was a great problem because there was no supplementation fund, as exists in New South Wales, for the payment of workers compensation to people who were insured with a company which just could not pay out. The previous Minister corrected that anomaly by setting up a supplementation fund. That was largely due to the efforts of people like me. But a number of other anomalies, both with respect to the substantive nature of workers compensation payments in the Australian Capital Territory and with respect to procedural arrangements, need to be completely reviewed. A number of lawyers in my electorate of Eden-Monaro have pointed this out to me. They are the practitioners who found problems for New South Wales citizens who suffered injury when working in the Australian Capital Territory. That is an area to which I hope the Minister can address himself. I understand, certainly from a communication I received from him dated 7 August, that he will be doing that. In this legislation we are overcoming some of the anomalies that ought to be corrected in the interests of people in New South Wales and, I think, in the interests of fairness and an equitable system of taxation which, as much as possible, heads in the direction of treating people in this country on an equal basis.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—You may proceed.

—On the AM program this morning and again in a report tabled in the other place a few moments ago there have been suggestions, conclusions and allegations related to my ministerial role with respect to the subsidiary of the Australian Dairy Corporation known as Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd. Paragraph 9.38 of the report comments, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee concludes that on the balance of probabilities, Mr Sinclair's recollection of the events was not as reliable as that of Mr Webster. In other words, it appears to the Committee that on the balance of probabilities, Mr Sinclair was told of the terms of the compromise which necessarily involved a continuing breach of GATT.

That statement is not true. I wish to advert very briefly to the reasons why that is a misrepresentation and an incorrect conclusion. The first is that I think it needs to be noted in this chamber that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations is about propriety. Yet repeatedly letters, announcements and even this report have been pre-released to the media either prior to dispatch by the Chairman or prior to release to the other place. Indeed, Simon Nasht this morning on AM released the contents of this report. Yet until its release a few moments ago by the Chairman of the Committee, it was, of course, a privileged document. It is worth noting that the principal adviser to the Committee was moonlighting as a journalist with the Bulletin newspaper while employed as a full time member on the staff of the then Opposition Leader in the Senate. He is now, and has continued, in a role where one can only presume he has very close connections with the media, and one can only condemn whoever was responsible for these prior releases.

Secondly, I think it needs to be said that with respect to this whole affair successive reports have been forwarded to the Australian Federal Police for inquiry relating to activities within Asia Dairy Industries. The matter was referred promptly by me and by my colleague the present Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) to the Australian Federal Police, as was indicated this morning by my colleague the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman). While some reports have been received, I understand that a final report has not yet been received by the Minister. I only hope that the Commissioner of the Federal Police will now accelerate the conclusion of his report so that aspects relating to reference to some matters appertaining to the then Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation can be concluded. If the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) believes any action should be taken, I hope that that too can be initiated at an early time.

I think it needs to be said, however, that aspects of the references related to some allegations made regarding certain activities by the then Chairman. It is that Chairman's evidence that has been preferred in this report to that of the First Assistant Secretary of the Department of Primary Industry, Mr Wallace, whose evidence is presented on pages 170 to 173 of the report. In an analysis of that report any lawyer would be concerned at the way in which that evidence was taken and the cross-examination was conducted. I believe it is critical that, in the proceedings of committees before this Parliament, witnesses are treated with proper respect and that propriety is observed. It is interesting to note that Mr Wallace's recollection concurred with my own.

Mr O'Bryan, another senior officer-the then Assistant Secretary of the Department of Primary Industry-was also called on to give evidence. His evidence is found at page 170 of the report. It is of interest that Mr O'Bryan was also a member of the Australian Dairy Corporation Board. Part of his concern was that the then Chairman reported inadequately to the Australian Dairy Corporation on the activities of Asia Dairy Industries. Mr O'Bryan was, of course, also the principal adviser in the dairying area and he equally concurred with my recollection of events. So the conclusions to which I referred, that is, those contained in item 9.38 of the Committee's report, have been reached in spite of the evidence of the First Assistant Secretary of the Department of Primary Industry and the evidence of Mr O'Bryan, Assistant Secretary of the Department of Primary Industry. Mr O'Bryan has since retired on the grounds of invalidity. He was also the Government representative on the Australian Dairy Corporation. The conclusions are contrary also to all the minutes and documentation that were available to the Department of Primary Industry. In correspondence to the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, in an attachment which is included in the report at pages 152 to 156, I commented:

I do not recall any discussion with Mr Webster on the nature of the outcome of the negotiations with HOMPI on the rebate following his return from Manila. Certainly, no evidence was provided to me to indicate that the A.D.C. share of the credit in the rebate account was being used to continue the rebate in breach of the GATT minimum price. Such an arrangement, if known about, would have been totally unacceptable to the Government.

I confirmed that evidence before this House by way of personal explanation on 7 May 1981. I refer honourable members to the House of Representatives Hansard of that date where I am reported as stating:

I assert to that honourable gentleman and to the members of the Senate Committee that I believe the evidence given to them is totally correct and has the substance of my being a Minister and giving it in this place.
And it would not differ-and I add these words-were it to be by way of statutory declaration or an oath. However, on that occasion in the House I said:

I do not believe there is any reason why there should be a statutory declaration given to confirm formal correspondence entered into by me as a Minister in this place, to a chairman of a Committee in another place.

I strongly support the contention that action should be taken by a government with a chairman of a statutory corporation or a subsidiary of a statutory corporation if it finds there is a breach of an international arrangement. Such action was undertaken by me immediately evidence came forward to that effect. The conclusions reached, however, in paragraph 9.38 of the Committee's report are inaccurate and against the evidence. I believe, therefore, that the report needs to be put straight immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the Minister be prepared to move that the House take note of his statement?
—No.
—Will we be given an opportunity to debate this matter at some stage?
—Yes.
—When?
—When we have the report. Debate has not yet finished in the other place. Presumably this report will be available then and we can debate it. I am dealing with only one very narrow aspect of it.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAXATION (ADMINISTRATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Opposition does not oppose the Australian Capital Territory Taxation (Administration) Amendment Bill and cognate Bills before us, nevertheless we have grave reservations about the underlying financial structure of the Australian Capital Territory. Accordingly, I have seconded the amendment put forward by my colleague the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes). Since the Budget it has become more and more apparent that the Government is interested only in extracting as much revenue as possible from Canberra without providing a firm and reliable commitment to Canberra's future growth and development. When the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) spoke earlier he dealt with the problems that Canberra faces in relation to Queanbeyan and the need to look at the Australian Capital Territory and Queanbeyan on a regional basis. I wholeheartedly endorse that view.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make the very important point that if we are to have the same financial responsibilities as people in New South Wales, which I believe we should have, at the same time we should have the same systems of government and the same sorts of rights. Currently we do not have those. The people of Canberra have taxes and rates imposed on them without having any way of appealing against it. At the same time as having the same responsibilities as the States we should have also the same rights. That is where I think the Government has failed. At the same time as having these taxes imposed-which I have said we do not oppose-we believe we should have responsibilities. The Government has failed to give us a firm decision on the Commonwealth Grants Commission's proposed inquiry into the finances of the Australian Capital Territory. The Grants Commission has not yet been given its reference and the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) has not given us an assurance that the Grants Commission will begin this inquiry this calendar year. It is essential that it begin this inquiry as soon as possible. I believe that the sorts of vague assurances that we have been given are just not good enough.

The Government is levying greatly increased charges on the people of Canberra and it is collecting more and more revenue without telling us how it is to be spent. The Budget has resulted in increased charges for a wide range of municipal services. Rates have gone up by an average of 13 per cent despite the fact that there is a surplus of approximately $6.8m in the municipal account. Where is the justification for this large increase when such a large surplus is in the account? I have heard the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) reply previously on this. He claims that there is not such a surplus. Yet the amount of money is quite clearly stated as appearing in the municipal accounts. It highlights the great problems we have in the Australian Capital Territory in coming to grips with our finances.
