The Government increases charges but does not explain to people why there is a need for the increases except to say 'the States pay it' or 'other local councils pay it'. But we do not have any say in determining those charges.

The recent Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Amendment Bill increased charges for financial and business transactions on the grounds that these charges should be brought into line with those in the States. There is no argument with the proposition that Australian Capital Territory residents should pay a fair share of taxes similar to those which apply in the States. But we must remember also that the people of the Australian Capital Territory have no form of local or State government and no input into the municipal decisions which directly affect their lives. Every community throughout Australia has a local form of administration which is responsive to community needs and which can promote its interests. But not Canberra. Instead of that we find that the time of this Parliament has to be taken up consistently with debating whether we should have an increase in charges in the Australian Capital Territory.

Canberra residents pay their taxes along with all other Australians yet they do not receive the 2 per cent of income tax collections made available for local government. Where does this money go? Nobody knows because there never has been a full examination of the financial arrangements for the Australian Capital Territory. Looking at the responsibilities of people to pay their taxes, if we did a breakdown of the figures I think we would find that the 68 per cent of people in the Australian Capital Territory work force who are Commonwealth public servants pay a much higher percentage of their income to the Australian Government because they cannot practise the tax avoidance and tax evasion which is practised by so many other Australians.

The Grants Commission inquiry is urgently needed to provide an independent assessment of Canberra's finances. Most of us expect that such an investigation will show that Canberra is indeed paying its own way. I wish more members of this Parliament were here today to hear this proposition because I get so sick of people saying to me: 'Look how well Canberra is going'. The truth of the matter is that Canberra pays its own way and these increased charges and levies only add to that burden. Nevertheless we are constantly told: 'Look how well off you are in Canberra'. That is why I think it is absolutely urgent that we have such an inquiry. I am not scared of the results and I am sure the people of Canberra are not scared of the results. But we need to have an examination. This Government is still dragging behind in getting this reference to the Grants Commission. We need the Grants Commission inquiry now, not at some indefinite time in the future. Why is the Government afraid to put it to the Grants Commission? Certainly the people of Canberra are tired of paying up, of having important financial decisions forced on them without having any input into those decisions.

The Bills before us today are a further unnecessary impost on the people of Canberra as it appears that their primary purpose, along with the earlier stamp duty Bills, is to raise revenue for the government coffers. The people of Canberra probably would not mind paying that money if we knew where it was going or why these duties are imposed on us. But we do not know that. The purpose of the Australian Capital Territory Tax (Vehicle Registration) Bill is to tax all new registrations and transfers of existing registrations at a rate of $2 in every $100 or part thereof. This will mean that on an average a second-hand car worth $4,000 a tax of $80 will have to be paid before the vehicle can be registered, and on the cost of a new car of, say, $7,000 the tax payable will be $140. This tax will be imposed without any examination of other recent decisions concerning vehicle registration in the Australian Capital Territory. For example, the infamous razor gang decided to abandon the system of annual independent inspections. No reason was given why that should be done. There is no possible philosophical basis for lowering road safety standards-at least I hope not. There is no saving of government expenditure as the vehicle testing stations at Phillip and Dickson are specially designed and equipped buildings which cannot be converted for any other use. The Canberra community has been shocked by this callous disregard for public safety which has been displayed by an ad hoc decision, and that this is what is was.

It is not just the people of Canberra who have been amazed by the razor gang's decision. I have heard from many people who live in other parts of Australia and who admired the safety precautions we took in Canberra. They are amazed to find now that those precautions are to be abolished for no good reason. The Canberra public has expressed total opposition at every opportunity to this decision. Thousands of people have signed petitions which have been presented in this Parliament. Many have written letters to newspapers, phoned talk-back radio programs and written to members of parliament. Everywhere one goes in Canberra it is obvious that there is a strong consensus of opinion about the need for independent vehicle testing in the Australian Capital Territory. What can people do about it? Nothing can be done because this decision was taken by a group of Ministers who have no responsibility for the Australian Capital Territory. I know that the Minister for the Capital Territory was not involved in the so-called Lynch razor gang committee. But I ask him to put the case for Canberra to the Lynch committee to try to get a reversal of that decision, which I believe was based on no firm foundation.

We now find that this Parliament once again is making decisions for the residents of Canberra, completely disregarding strongly held views in this community. Canberra has been the envy of other States in relation to road safety standards. Up to now we have had an effective independent vehicle inspection system, free of the problems experienced in other States where there can be a conflict of interest when local garages do inspections. The cost to the motorist must also be considered. Currently, Canberra motorists pay $213 a year to register their cars, irrespective of engine capacity, and $238 if it is a new registration. We find in the Budget estimates that these charges are about to be increased again, despite the fact that the independent inspection of vehicles will no longer be carried out. The Minister has been unable to provide us with the cost of the inspection component in the registration. He has also been unable or unwilling to reduce registration fees by the amount of the inspection component when this service is finally removed. Not only are Canberra motorists facing high registration charges, which are about to be increased, according to the Budget, but also we now find that on top of this we will have to pay $25 or $30 to a local garage to get an annual inspection carried out. Local garages do not have the specialised equipment or staff to do this properly. This will mean that Canberra motorists will pay the highest registration fees in Australia but at the same time will have lost the services of independent vehicle inspectors. We are facing a serious erosion of public safety standards as a result of this short-sighted decision.

We also find that the Bills before us will tax Canberra motorists even further. The Canberra community has borne the brunt of poorly conceived government decisions this year, both in the razor gang report and in the Budget. The transfer of the motor vehicle inspection functions to the private sector is one of the worst of these decisions. I urge that this decision be reviewed in the interests of public safety and in response to the wishes of the Canberra community.

The revenue to be raised from the new vehicle tax is considerable. Last year there were approximately 20,000 new or transferred registrations. The revenue from the new tax, at approximately $100 a vehicle, will be at least $2m a year. This money will be incorporated into Consolidated Revenue. There has been no guarantee that it will be returned to the Australian Capital Territory in the form of increased services or, more particularly, applied to the promotion of improved public safety standards. The Australian Labor Party position on this matter is clear. We do not believe that there should be any new taxes imposed on Canberra residents until a full investigation of the financial situation of the Australian Capital Territory is undertaken by the Grants Commission.

In the case of the insurance Bills, the amount of revenue to be collected is enormous. Under the new provisions tax will be imposed on insurance premiums received in the Australian Capital Territory. Whilst the Bureau of Statistics figures available do not provide a detailed break-down of the various categories of insurance, we can get a general idea of the amount of revenue to be collected. In 1980, $162.3m in premiums was collected in the Australian Capital Territory. If tax were applied at 7 per cent, this would generate $11.4m in revenue. These taxes, along with those collected from the vehicle registration Bills, will go straight into Consolidated Revenue. Canberra is being taxed heavily but there is no accountability to the residents as to how their money is spent.

According to the Australian Capital Territory Budget figures, $23m is collected from the rent on government housing. Where does this money go? Is it disbursed back to the Australian Capital Territory in improved services? We do not know because there are no clear financial arrangements for the Australian Capital Territory. These are only just some of the examples. Canberra residents have had to fight hard to get the ordinary concessions that apply, for example, to pensioners in other States. Again, if we pay the same taxes and the same levies as people in the States, we should get the benefits. Every time people here want a benefit they have to fight for it. I refer to a matter with which I was involved, getting electricity concessions for pensioners. We fought for that for two years. We got it. It was a promise by this Government in the last election. I am pleased to see that that has now come into effect. The sorts of battles that we have to put up every time we want to get these rights I believe should not have to happen. In this Budget I am pleased to see that we have special concessions for age pensioners in the motor vehicle registration area. But as I highlighted yesterday-I hope the Minister has taken note of this-certain categories of age pensioners now administered through the Department of Veterans' Affairs have been excluded. I hope that the Minister will refer to that matter when replying because I believe that those general categories of age pensoners should be taken into consideration.

These decisions on municipal benefits for Canberra citizens are made by Cabinet, not by a local representative administration. We are still well behind the States in the provision of transport concessions for our pensioners. These issues are properly the concern of the local community and should not have to be a subject on the agenda of the national Government. We can see how many people are really interested in this Parliament by the number of people here today. But it is a matter that really dramaticaly concerns the people in my electorate, the people of the Australian Capital Territory. It is a matter for their elected representatives. However, it will be essential to have all the information on the Australian Capital Territory's finances in order to have a sound basis for the extension of local services and concessions.

It is apparent that the decision to transfer the functions of land development to the private sector has been made without any analysis of the implications for the financial basis of a future local government. Until now profits from the sale of land leases, both commercial and residential, have been absorbed into Consolidated Revenue. Under the new arrangements whereby the private sector takes over land development, profits will be accumulated in private hands and will be unavailable for disbursement in the form of improved municipal services. Further, it is clear that Canberra home buyers will be paying higher prices for their homes as a result of this transfer of a Commonwealth function. This is a recurring pattern in recent Government decisions imposed on the people of Canberra. Higher charges, prices and taxes are being imposed while, at the same time, the Government stalls on the question of a full investigation of the financial arrangements for the Australian Capital Territory.

In 1931-I repeat that for the Minister's attention; in 1931-the Federal Capital Advisory Council asked the Federal Government to give a detailed report on the financial arrangements for Canberra. Fifty years later we are still waiting. What we want from the Minister is some action on it. The Government is still trying to fob off the residents of Canberra. It is not prepared to give them an honest answer about the funds spent on national and municipal functions. I would like the Minister to stand up and tell us, not that it is going to the Grants Commission at some time in the future, but when it is going to the Grants Commission. I would like him to tell us when we will have answers to the questions I have put to him today. If we have to pay the same taxes we want the same rights. I do not think that is too much to ask for the people of the Australian Capital Territory. I believe it is his reponsibility to try to provide answers to those questions.

Clearly, the Grants Commission inquiry into the Australian Capital Territory finances can provide the answers. I hope that it can provide all the answers but answers to some questions, at least, will be a start. But the Government has to give the Grants Commission a reference before further taxes and charges are imposed on the Canberra people. I urge all members to support the amendment, which will provide for a full investigation of the financial arrangements for the Australian Capital Territory and will give the people a fair go. We want to be treated equally. I hope that a first step towards equal treatment will be an immediate reference to the Grants Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) on her spirited address. But may I take one or two moments to correct a couple of matters. As much as I might wish to have control of the Commonwealth Grants Commission, the honourable member will find, if she checks, that the Commission operates under the purview and portfolio of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman). I have made representations to the Minister. Indeed, the honourable member knows this. She pays me the greatest compliment of my political life by virtually implying that I have a capacity, almost overnight, to resolve an issue that has been rampant in the Australian Capital Territory since 1931. I reminded the honourable member in an earlier debate that in 1931 two things happened. Firstly, there was a request for a review of the finances of the Australian Capital Territory with a division between national capital expenditure and municipal expenditure. Secondly, a Labor government at that time told the people of the Australian Capital Territory that they would have self-government within one year. I make the comment in passing that the question of self-government, the question of representation and the question of taxation have been current issues in the Australian Capital Territory for at least the last decade, but one could even go back for 50 years. The honourable member's party, the Australian Labor Party, made a firm commitment prior to the 1972 Federal election to give self-government to the Australian Capital Territory. Three years later self-government had not come about. In 1981, whilst I am delighted that the attitude of the honourable member is somewhat different from that of some others in her party, there is an approach in respect of self-government which I hope will be fruitful.

SPEECH.PARA: With the geatest of respect to the Opposition, the amendment is not acceptable to the Government. It does not advance the issue. The fact is that the review which has been promised will occur. It is not years down the track, as was suggested by another honourable member last week. The review is only months down the track. The Commonwealth Grants Commission is currently undertaking the review of State relativities. I have every reason to believe that as soon as that relativities review is completed the Australian Capital Territory matter will be the next reference to it. But I must add one further comment on behalf of the Chairman of the Grants Commission, Mr Justice Else-Mitchell, and the hard working members of the Commission. I do not think anyone would disagree with me when I say that the Commission is overworked and is under-resourced. It is a matter of ordinary, plain common sense that applying oneself as the Commission does and as the Chairman, in particular, does to the very onerous duties upon them, there is a limit to what can be done and the time in which it can be done. Having said that, I repeat that it is my belief-it is a belief which I state quite responsibly-that the review will occur in 1982.

There are three expenditure aspects. There is the national capital component of expenditure in the Australian Capital Territory, there is the State-type expenditure and there is the municipal-type expenditure. It is a matter of conjecture where those figures will come out in the ultimate. Whilst the honourable member says that we would like the 2 per cent of personal income tax collections for municipal services, that request might be quickly withdrawn if the figures showed that 2 per cent of personal income tax would represent about 60 per cent of the current revenues being made available. In other words, we are a little in the dark. The suggestion of 2 per cent, I think, is not likely to be picked up until people have a few more figures down the track. There is no $6.8m surplus in the municipal account. I again invite the honourable member, if she does not understand, to take the matter up again with the Secretary to my Department or, if she wishes, we can have a full scale debate.

I take the point of the honourable member in relation to motor vehicle testing. I will convey her remarks to ministerial collegues. It is simply not correct to say that the matter is not subject to review. If, for example, an ordinance has to be amended, it will be very much subject to review by comment both in the House of Assembly and in another place.

Lastly, I ask the honourable member in an absolute spirit of friendship and co-operation not to jump up and down on the question of land development. This is a golden opportunity for the private sector to put its money into the national capital and to make a contribution to the economy, which desperately needs the input of private enterprise. I invite the honourable member to attend to the details, while admiring the spirit with which she puts her case on behalf of her constituents.
Amendment negatived.

Upon which Mr Willis had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'whilst not opposing the Bill, the House rejects the budget strategy because:
(1) it deliberately reduces the rate of economic growth;
(2) it increases unemployment;
(3) it adds substantially to the rate of inflation;
(4) it relies on a massive private capital inflow;
(5) it fails to tackle the real causes of rising interest rates, and

and, in addition, deplores the Government's callous disregard of the millions of Australians living in poverty and its continued attempt to reduce the living standards of the great majority of Australians'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —To their eternal shame Government members in this House, who are here purely to represent and to protect the people who elected them, are gearing up to use their numbers to support a Budget which again, following the infamous razor gang cuts, hits at the weakest in the community. During my time in this Parliament I have watched the Government as it tries to anaesthetise the community with its mumbo jumbo inside this chamber and out. Those on lowest incomes have been hurt so badly that nothing can kill the pain. While Australians are told that they have to be content with just the crumbs the Government trumpets to the rest of the world what a prize, resource-rich plum we are, ripe for the picking-a lucky country. It all too often seems that the rest of the world gets the plum and Australians are left with the pip. How long will it be before the Government understands that average Australian workers are not wanting more of the national cake; they are just wanting to maintain the same portion?

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has used and abused the so-called boom. At election times Government politicians puff up with rhetoric about the boom; after the election they lower the boom in no uncertain fashion. The myopic commitment of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to the pursuit of monetarist policies at any price is now firmly established and evidenced in this Budget. The price for that ideological commitment is also abundantly clear-the people are the ones who will be paying. They will be paying cruelly for the ideological servitude of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to his master and benefactor, the Prime Minister. The victims of this Budget will be the people who can least afford to pay. As the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) has already said in this House the Government does not apply the principle of the user pays; the principle is the loser pays. The loser for the past six years and again this year are the pensioners, the sick, the unemployed, particularly the young unemployed, home owners and those who wish to buy their own homes, the average family, supporting parents, small businessmen-every Australian on low and middle income levels-and, of course, the retailer who now becomes the Government's tax collector for its billion dollar sales tax scandal.

One cannot isolate the effects, the flow on, of this tax. It is paid irrespective of one's taxable capacity or means, and nothing, save perhaps the Bible, seems to have escaped the sales tax net. There is a growing list of organisations and people who could normally have been expected to be Government supporters but who have given up whatever confidence they might have had in this Government. Take note of the Queensland Premier, the Queensland Liberal Party leader, the Liberal Party Premier of Western Australia, the Victorian Liberal Party Minister of Housing; note even the honourable member for Kooyong who has shown us that birds of a feather do not necessarily flock together. Who else apart from the ordinary Australian worker has criticised this Budget? It is a very impressive list; it does not just come from Opposition ranks. It includes the Master Builders Association, the Bank of New South Wales, the Australian Automobile Association, the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures, the Australian Taxpayers Association, CRS, the Confederation of Australian Industry and Mr Kerry Packer. The executive director of the Housing Industry Association, Mr Bill Kirkby-Jones, said that the industry regarded the sales tax increase as the 'final straw'. The President of the Master Builders Association said that the tax 'would spell disaster' for many home seekers. A statement released from a meeting of leading executives of Alcoa of Australia Ltd, James Hardie and Co. Pty Ltd, the Stegbar organisation, Australian Consolidated Industries Ltd, Taubmans Industries Ltd, Berger Paints (Australia) Pty Ltd, CRS, Monier Ltd, Ready Mixed Concrete Ltd, John Lysaght Australia Ltd, and Rheem Australia Ltd reads:

Decent housing underpins the social fabric of this country and we will not allow it to be eroded. Quite apart from the attack on the living standards and housing aspirations of ordinary Australians, the penalty, if allowed to stand, will lead to further unemployment in an industry which is presently facing serious difficulty.

I quote that article from the Australian of 29-30 August. The number of homes built last year fell by almost 5,000, and it does not take a prophet to forecast a further fall this year. If ever there were a Budget specifically designed to end the Australian ownership dream this is it. Not only will the increase in sales tax add to the cost of homes and renovations but also the credit squeeze which has been applied and the Government's glaring and deliberate failure to stop the inflow of speculative foreign capital and its refusal to ease the pressure on or regulate interest rates or make home loan interest repayments tax deductible will ensure that the climate for borrowing for home loans becomes chillier and chillier and the obligation of loan repayments becomes harder and harder. This sacrifice need not have been made because the policy direction of the Government is all wrong. It seems that the Government's money supply strategy is predicated on the disputable theory that scarce money will compel employers to resist employees' wages demands. Of course, anyone with an element of common sense could explain to the Government that, by its very nature, the Budget compels workers to seek wage increases to redress the fall in living standards represented by this Budget. An average family of four is worse off by approximately $20 a week as a result of this Budget.

Apart from the inflationary and regressive sales tax, what are the other features of this year's Budget strategy? Payments to the States are up 7.7 per cent. It is very little wonder that the Queensland Premier's spouse in the Senate has had a few cross words to say about that. The figure of 7.7 per cent compares with an expected double digit inflation figure for the coming year, an 18.9 per cent increase in personal income tax collections and an overall increase of 15.2 per cent in Commonwealth expenditure. Unemployment is expected to rise as a direct result of the Budget strategy. This has been admitted by the Treasurer himself. Offsetting this, the Government has announced an increase of $4.65 a week in unemployment benefit. That is on a par with inflation, which leaves people receiving that benefit as far below the poverty line as they were before. It is unforgivable.

Meanwhile, of course, the under 18-year-olds remain on $36 a week-a full $50 under the poverty line-which will lead inevitably to an increase in youth crime and youth homelessness, which is a blot on our society as it is. The Victorian Liberal Party Minister for Youth, Sport and Recreation said the very same thing the week before the Budget. Apparently his advice fell on deaf ears. There are 53,000 people in the under 18 category. This is not just a figure; there are 53,000 young people without jobs. Not only was there no increase in benefit for them but also, to its eternal shame, the Government has cut the only real, tangible, direct and effective unemployed youth support program that it had-the Community Youth Support Scheme. It was small-minded and criminally amateurish for a Government with a $1,542m domestic surplus this year to scrap a paltry, in money terms, $14m program which helped some of the most defenceless people in the community-the young unemployed. The money allocated to the Community Youth Support Scheme was arguably the best $14m the Government has ever spent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Better than CHOGM.

—As the honourable member says, it is better than the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. Now for the good news: After five barren years without a rise the Government will be increasing family allowances but the increase is for a third child and later children only which, in fact, means no increase at all for more than 70 per cent of Australian families. I hardly think that parents of one or two children rushed to the bedroom the moment they heard the Budget news to cash in, as it were, on the Treasurer's little bonus. With the birth rate declining and the trend to smaller families this must be seen in the naked light of day for what it really is-a confidence trick. So much for the good news on family allowances! What about the good news on pensions? About the only thing that can be said is that supplementary or rent assistance will be increased by $3 to $8 a week, and even that is not all that it seems. Everyone in this chamber can imagine going out with $8 in his hand and hoping to get even the most meagre type of accommodation. True to its form of giving with one hand and taking with the other, the Government has established a minimum rent for which assistance will be payable. This maginificent supplementary assistance was the one gift the Government had for pensioners this year. That is how barren it is. Pensions as a proportion of average weekly earnings will fall one per cent below last year. When the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) said that the Government was maintaining a steady course, he was dead right. The Government is steadily undermining pensioners. What else will the Department of Social Security be doing as a result of the Budget? The Government will penalise the spouse and children of a person engaged in an industrial dispute by rendering the spouse ineligible for unemployment benefit. That is another fine example of the Government's respect for families. It is a sad irony that the Department charged with maintaining social security should be responsible for creating so much social insecurity.

SPEECH.PARA: The patient contribution to pharmaceutical benefits scheme drugs has increased by 113 per cent since 1975. The Government has increased the price of oral contraceptives at a time when the allocation to the Family Planning Association of Australia has fallen by 10 per cent. It is illogical. Families will pay $2 to $11 extra per week for compulsory health insurance. Expenditure on job training schemes has fallen 44 per cent below the 1975-76 expenditure in real terms yet, as we all know, unemployment has risen by 54 per cent in the same period. There has been no increase in Aboriginal affairs expenditure, and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) would have expanded on that issue yesterday if he had not been gagged by the Government during Question Time. In that disgraceful abuse of Government numbers, justice was really miscarried.

Other areas have suffered under this Budget. Environment and conservation expenditure has been cut by 17 per cent in real terms; roads expenditure has been cut; tourism has been cut by 35 per cent in real terms; spending on migrant programs has been cut at a time when immigration will be increasing; air navigation charges are up, which means air fares will increase; urban and regional development spending has plummeted by 28.3 per cent; the Commonwealth Public Service has been cut by another 9,000; health expenditure is down by 21.3 per cent, as indicated in Budget outlays, and the burden for hospital funding has been dumped unsolicited on the State governments. The only thing going up is the cost of living. At a time when people are struggling to manage, we have a Government which cynically cuts any benefits going back to the public which elected it.

It is worth noting that in the International Year of Disabled Persons, when one might expect at least a few generous gestures from the Government, there has been no increase in the handicapped children's allowance. It is a farce. There are 25,371 people in that category. The sheltered workshop employees' incentive allowance, after having remained at the same pitiful level for six years, has been boosted by the awesome amount of $3. This entire allowance costs a crippling $1.4m. The Government really makes Scrooge look like Santa Clause. The promised $225m three-year housing program is $110m less in real terms than the previous program. At a time when the percentage of senior citizens has grown within our community and their housing needs are expanding, the Government is reducing the supply of public housing. For those few who are lucky enough to score public housing, future supplementary assistance will be abolished. The same illogical response is indicated in the Government's commitment to senior citizens' centres. The allocation has remained static at $4m for the last five years. Who else in the community would put up with having his income pegged? Certainly no one in this chamber. Surely I need not explain to Government members that that is a fall in real terms of the order of 60 per cent.

The personal care subsidy paid towards facilities for the frail aged in hostels has not been increased from $20 a week to the $32.50 a week recommended by the joint working party on hostel accommodation. The subsidy to Meals on Wheels has not beein increased, despite that voluntary association's invaluable service in the face of inflationary costs. The home care subsidy has been reduced from $2 for $1 to $1 for $1. This places an intolerable burden on State and local government, church and voluntary agencies to fill the gap. This year's children's services program has fallen by $20m in real terms below 1975-76 spending levels. Of course, it does not matter for how long we search in the Budget for a reference to women's refuges. The fact is that they are not there because the razor gang recommended them as one of the gifts the Federal Government should hand quite gratuitously to the States. Fraser co-operative federalism, as it is sometimes called, means that the Federal Government leaves the baby on the doorstep of the State governments. If those State governments do not have room for any more Federal babies, they are entirely abandoned. The Community Youth Support Scheme is the latest baby conceived and raised by the Federal Government to be so abandoned. In education, which is another crucial area the importance of which the Federal Minister for Education (Mr Fife) just does not comprehend, the total funding will be cut in 1982 from $452m to $479m, or by more than 10 per cent in real terms.

How does this Budget add to the impressive list of broken promises which constitute the record of this Government? Employment will fall this year, but last year, the election year, we were told that the Government's policies and the boom would strengthen the labour market. We cannot believe a word the Government says. Interest rates are soaring through the roof, but it was not long ago that the Prime Minister said that they would fall and keep on falling. That prediction might better apply to him. What about the total abandonment of the fundamental 1975 and 1977 election promise of tax idexation? We now have one-third indexation. Of course, the promise to retain Medibank was broken long agon into a thousand pieces. Where in the Prime Minister's 1980 election speech, was the Government's request to the Australian people for a mandate to increase sales tax? Much was made during that campaign of the Opposition's capital gains and resource tax proposals which we frankly acknowledged and which the Government distorted to cause unfounded fear. The Government's decision to increase the amount of sales tax revenue by almost $1 billion must have been written in the policy speech between the lines and in invisible ink.

How do Government members rationalise the real increase in Government spending when they were pledged to reduce it? Spending is a flat rate of 13 per cent above that of last year. What about the myth of the low tax, low profile Liberal Government? Not only will this Government rip off more in income tax, but also every time a consumer enters a hardware store, a camera store, a clothes shop, a shoe store or a furniture store the Government tax collector will be waiting to relieve his pockets of hard earned cash by way of this deceitful indirect impost of sales tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —They tax the poor to help the rich.

—As the honourable member has pointed out, it certainly does tax the poor to help the rich. That is what outrages me about this Budget. I am fed up with a government which is here to represent the people continually trampling on those people. The new sales tax which has been imposed has put into the luxury class many items which people on lower incomes are forced to go along with and support with their money. The Government is putting a sales tax on the woman who stays at home, struggling on one income to rear her family. Her husband has to put his hand in his pocket to pay the extra tax every time she wants to wash the dishes with detergent or wipe the dishes with a teatowel. The same situation applies if she is an income earner and perhaps can afford a dish washing machine. Items which are essential to everyone, including the poor, have been attacked by the Government through the sales tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The party that brought in small government has not stuck its nose in everywhere. The Australian community will be greatly reassured to know that the parts of movable toilet pans or chemical sanitary units will now receive exemption status, although the toilet pan, seat and cover will be taxed. I think that is a fitting reflection on the priorities of a Government that promised less intrusion into our lives, not to mention the promises about employment, interest rates, Medibank, smaller taxes and less inflation. To borrow from Shakespeare:
His promises were, as he then was, mighty;
But his performance, as he is now, nothing.
More aptly for a government which taxes the poor to help the rich, I quote from the Babylonian Talmud:
The righteous promise little and perform much; the wicked promise much and perform not even a little.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Government in this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1981-82. The honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) who spoke before me finished her speech by quoting Shakespeare. She said 'performance is nothing'. I would say that that applies to her speech. With the greatest of respect, she put her heart on her sleeve and criticised the Government for the expenditure cuts it had made and the new programs it had introduced. We did not hear from the honourable member one positive idea or solution to the problems that Australia faces today. That goes for the Opposition overall. There is always negativism. We never see anything positive. We never see any progress or thought for the future. I am convinced, after listening to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) speak on the Budget, that the Labor Party certainly has not learned the lessons of its past period in office when unemployment, inflation and taxes rose dramatically. If the Australian Labor Party-heaven forbid-were ever to govern again that would happen again. The Labor Party is committed to big spending and big deficits. It lacks ideas about how to control inflation and promote sensible and sustained economic growth. It believes that government can run people's lives and industry better than people can organise their own lives and better than industry can conduct its own affairs. I am confident that in the future the majority of Australians will reject that socialist approach.

SPEECH.PARA: From listening to the honourable member for Lilley one would hardly think that the Government had done anything previously. We need to refer to the Budget to remind honourable members opposite of what the Government has done. It has a most creditable record of its concern and help for people. Social security and welfare outlays, the largest single item in the Budget, account for almost 28 per cent of government expenditure. They are estimated to be $11,357m, an increase of 14.5 per cent. To listen to honourable members opposite speak one would think that we had not spent anything at all on social security and welfare. We have increased family allowances for the third and fourth child.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the rich.

—We have increased them for all Australians. That is what this Government is about. It is concerned about all Australians. We have increased the basic pension and benefits. We have continued the adjustment of pensions in line with the consumer price index. In November the standard single rate of pension will rise by $3.05 to $69.70 and the pension for a married couple will be increased by $5.10, to $116.20. We get no credit for that from honourable members opposite. We get no credit for the $12m increase in expenditure, to $58m, for aged persons accommodation. We get no credit for the increase of $2m in expenditure on crisis accommodation which will start a program for families in distress. We get no credit from the opposition for the increase in unemployment benefit for people aged 18 years and over without dependants. That benefit will be increased from $53.45 to $58.10 a week from November.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn my attention and the attention of the House to the record of this Government. Whilst the Budget document is looking forward to the future, let us reflect for a second on the past and the very creditable record of the Government. In 1980-81 private business fixed investment grew by more than 20 per cent in real terms. That is the largest growth for 30 years. It was a creditable performance. In the same year private dwelling investment continued to grow firmly with a real increase of about 11 per cent. That was a magnificent achievement. People who are criticising the Government at present about interest rates and the problems that people face in relation to welfare housing and in the purchasing of new homes fail to recognise the excellent performance of the Government in this area. I refer to the Government's performance in controlling inflation. As measured by the CPI, last year the inflation rate was 8.8 per cent-almost 2 per cent below the rate of the previous year. That is creditable. Average weekly earnings in the last financial year achieved the largest increase in real terms for six years-almost 4 per cent. We never hear Opposition members citing those figures or giving the Government any credit for its excellent performance. I have set the stage by dealing with the Government's performance in the past. It has made substantial economic progress. That does not mean that there are no problems to be solved in the community today. We are not denying that there are problems. Of course there are. We are applying our policies in a most sensible way to solve them. I welcome in the Budget the move to indirect taxation by the imposition of sales tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—The honourable member said: 'Shame!' He should pay attention. Opposition members are always criticising this Government for not doing anything about the tax avoidance industry or the cash economy. This Government has a most creditable record. It has done more to stop tax avoidance than any other government in the history of Australia. It introduced a new section 260 to the Income Tax Assessment Act.
—The Labor Government did nothing in office.

—The honourable member for Perth said that the Labor Government did nothing in office. It did nothing at all. Let us not forget that the Liberal-National Country Party coalition has done more to stop tax avoidance than any other government in the history of Australia. We have now taxed the cash economy. We all know that there is an underground cash economy in Australia. The imposition of sales tax has meant that we are taxing transactions in the community. The Government has made an excellent move in that direction. I personally would have liked to see a tax at the retail level. I feel that manufacturers and wholesalers in large part act as the tax collectors and have to fund the revenue. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you know the sales tax Acts provide that sales tax has to be paid within 21 days. That was all very well in the days when sales tax Acts were first enacted. People probably paid their accounts within that time. Today people pay within 30 days, 60 days and even up to 90 days. At some stage the Treasurer (Mr Howard) ought to consider extending the time of 21 days for payment for manufacturers and wholesalers. He also ought to look at the added burden being put on wholesalers and manufacturers in having to pay extra staff in some cases to administer the collection and payment of sales tax. I hope he will instruct the sales tax department to be as helpful as possible to those who have to pay the tax.

SPEECH.PARA: There are obvious difficulties in planning the implementation of sales tax in a Budget context. The more a government plans, the more people know, and the more chances there are of a Budget leak and the secrecy of the Budget being broken. There are a number of anomalies. I mentioned in the House the other day the problems that the Kit Kat and other chocolate biscuits and confectionery involve. In the construction industry where sand, gravel and other items are used it is hard to know whether the end use is exempt from taxation. Some discretion and good will should be used on behalf of the Commissioner of Taxation in administering the new legislation. I hope that in considering the legislation some of the anomalies will be worked out before it is in place.

I now refer to the Community Youth Support Scheme. The honourable member for Lilley and other Opposition members have criticised the Government; they say that it is being heartless in relation to unemployed youth. It is completely hypocritical for honourable members opposite to criticise the Government in relation to the Community Youth Support Scheme. I remind this House and honourable members present today that when CYSS was introduced the Labor Party was critical of it. I think it called the scheme cuddle therapy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be childish.

—That is on the record. The Labor Party was against the Community Youth Support Scheme when it was introduced. Members of the Labor Party realise that it was an initiative of the Government but for narrow political advantage they refuse to recognise that we have increased expenditure by 23 per cent in the employment and training area for young people. They fail to recognise the new programs which have been put in place. There is a 67 per cent increase in the school to work transition scheme for young people. But not a word of that do we hear from members of the Opposition. Are they trying to say that we do not care about young people? How can a government be accused of not caring if it increases expenditure by 23 per cent overall? As I say, in the school to work transition area, that very important time for people in the youth training area, we have increased expenditure by 67 per cent. Yet members of the Opposition have the hide to get up in this chamber and say that we do not care about young people. I am pleased to say that the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) has said that he has an open mind in relation to Community Youth Support Scheme projects and that if, because of geographic location, people are unable to attend these projects, or if people currently participating in those projects are unsuited to the new training schemes or the expanded training schemes, he will develop new programs to meet those needs.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the Government in relation to the Community Youth Support Scheme decision. We are in the land of positive ideas and new thinking. I think we have to learn the lessons of some of the mistakes of the Community Youth Support Scheme. We have to improve the projects and put better programs in their place. I am confident that, at the end of the day, those few people who are unable to take part in the new expanded program will have their needs met by this Government. I stand here and say that quite firmly and proudly. I think I have the support of my colleague the honourable member for Perth (Mr McLean) when I say that at the end of the day, when all the kerfuffle has died down and the Opposition has stopped screaming and stopped failing to recognise what the Government has done, the positive initiatives which have been taken, better schemes will be in place and young people will be much better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will remind you of those comments.

—Yes, and I will be proud to point out to the honourable member for La Trobe how those schemes came into place. I have been to Community Youth Support Scheme projects in and around my electorate. I have seen the needs and I know that the Minister will meet the needs of those people and of others in Community Youth Support Scheme projects in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I move on to the area of taxation. One of the concerns I have about the Budget is that it is still, I think, a big government Budget. I take the view that no person should have to pay more than 50 per cent of his or her earnings in taxation. I give the Government credit for cutting the rate of growth of government expenditure but we still have to bite the bullet of where we cut programs. In the community today there are great demands on government. People want the Government to do this or that. They ask why the Government has not done this or that. On the other hand, there is a great demand for and a need to reduce taxation. When people come to me with an idea about government involvement and say that the Government ought to do this or that, I say to them, as I say to the House today: 'Please tell me where you want to increase the taxation to pay for that program or where you want to cut government expenditure to pay for that program'. We cannot have new government programs without either raising taxation or cutting expenditure. People like the honourable member for Lilley fail to recognise that fact. I think that is perhaps a weakness of this Budget. There is still too large a commitment to big government and to the public sector. I would like to see government expenditure cut. Similarly, I am disappointed that we did not cut that expenditure so that we could give some tax relief because I believe tax relief is urgently required in the community today. But I want to give credit to the Government-we never get credit-for the substantial changes it has made to the personal taxation system. It introduced the three-tier, the three steps, collection system, yet it gets no credit for doing so. We have made credible advances in the area of taxation relief but I believe we still have a long way to go.

I now address myself briefly to the area of wage demands. I think the Budget is predicated on an approximately 13 1/2 per cent increase in wages. I am confident that that will prove to be an over-exaggerated figure. I have confidence in the arbitration system and in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I think we have to look to the Commission. There were a lot of newspaper headlines and hoo-ha when indexation was abandoned by the Commission. People in the media were saying: 'Oh, look, there is no indexation. The arbitration system has broken down. What will we do?'. We have the Arbitration Commission in place. We have respected judges and respected commissioners on that Commission. The Commission still sits. It is still working. It is still functioning. It is still hearing cases. Under the relevant Act it has to take into account the effects on employment and inflation of its decisions. We are going through a new stage of decision making by the Commission. I believe it is successful. In fact, I am very optimistic that wage increases will be held down during the next financial year. That, of course, will affect the Government's Budget figure and will affect inflation. It will reduce inflation. I think all of us on both sides of the House have to back up the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It is working well. Let us look at what is happening in the market place. The demand for an extra $20 that the transport workers were seeking by strike action has not flowed on throughout the community. Where it has flowed on, it has been handed to workers under terms and conditions; it is to be used as a credit for any subsequent increase that is granted. I think we are entering a new era of restraint and sensibility in relation to wage increases in the community. In so saying, I pay some credit to the Australian Council of Trade Unions in that regard. It may surprise some honourable members opposite that I am prepared to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wouldn't put too much money on it.

—We can only hope, can we not? We have been criticised in relation to rising interest rates in the community. I was delighted this morning to hear the Treasurer (Mr Howard) say that he thought we had started to turn the interest rate corner and that there had been some promising signs in the government bond market. Let us look at the question of interest rates. It is of concern to me and to other honourable members on this side of the House that interest rates are inhibiting people from buying their own homes or are adding to the costs of people who are buying their own homes. But let us give the Budget a fair go. Let us give it a chance to work. Last year we had an excellent figure for private dwelling investment. Such investment is increasing. If interest rates can be moderated and can turn the corner, if we can get them on the downward path, we can restore people's ability to finance their home purchases.

SPEECH.PARA: We have budgeted for a domestic surplus. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that means that the Government is not going out to compete in the market place with the private sector for money. We are trying to give the private sector room to breathe. Money, like any other commodity, reacts to supply and demand. The greater the demand for money in the community, the higher the interest rate. That is the reason for the Government's high domestic surplus and I believe this strategy has to be given a chance to work. It is silly and futile for honourable members opposite to get up and say: 'You have a $1.5 billion surplus; give some of it here and put some of it there'. I point out to the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) that every bit of that surplus that is taken away adds to interest rate pressure. So every time the Opposition says that we should use some of that domestic surplus in an area of expenditure it is in fact advocating higher interest rates for home owners. I think that fact ought to be recognised and pointed out. I think we have to recognise also that this Budget is another Budget for economic growth, another Budget that is healthy for the Australian economy. I am delighted to speak to it today. I am pleased to be able to support it, and I will vote for it and work for it in every way possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —An editorial in the Australian last Friday raised the following problem:

SPEECH.PARA: If Fraserism, Thatcherism and Reaganomics fail, it is difficult to see what the next philosophy will be. We could be back to high public spending and nationalisation a la Mitterand.
Since the Australian newspaper does not understand, never mind appreciate, the Mitterand program, it concluded:
The Prime Minister should get back to the basics of his own philosphy and make it work because there is nothing else in sight that will fulfil the aspirations of Australian society today.

These strident remarks are a desperate attempt to cling at straws in the face of overwhelming evidence that Fraserism has been a total failure. In this speech, I hope to demonstrate that there is indeed a clear and coherent philosophical alternative to Fraserism, which presents a vision of a much better society. This rejects the need for widespread human suffering and a culture of gloom and despair, as embodied in this Budget.

But first I want to expose a remarkable act of sophistry by the Australian newspaper. It does not deny that Fraserism in practice has been a serious failure. Indeed the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is attacked in the same editorial for being 'a big taxer and spender'. The problem, we are told, is that for six years the Prime Minister has not practised Fraserism-and if only he would, our problems would be solved. The common man, the average Australian, is suffering reduced living standards and oppression as a result of the policies of the Prime Minister which continue to be reflected in this Budget as in every previous Fraser Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will refer to the Prime Minister as such. The honourable member may continue.

—Now it is very little consolation to this average Australian, to workers and their families, to be told that the gospel according to St Malcolm is actually correct, even if he does not practise it himself. One can understand the feelings of ordinary people when they treat such a suggestion with contempt. And in so doing they would be right. For how can Fraserism be divorced from the policies and actions of the man who pompously claims to have formulated that so-called philosophy. In my maiden speech earlier this year, I argued that the Prime Minister is using talk of liberal principles and social justice but that his real purpose and real philosophy are entirely different. This unstated real philosophy is consistent with this Goverment's actions and policies.

SPEECH.PARA: But look at its consequences. They have been devastating for this nation and its people. The real Fraser philosophy is based on dividing this nation between the rich and the poor, the privileged and the oppressed. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) pointed out in his Budget reply, the Government will collect record taxes from the Australian people of $37,769m. Yet spending in all the major areas of need has been reduced in real terms since 1975; in education, health, transport, communications and housing. Urban and regional development is down 89 per cent. At the same time, grants and concessions to big business are up 56 per cent to $1,000m. In view of this situation, how can rational people-I include the editors of the Australian here- defend the real philosophy of Fraserism?

In earlier speeches on this Budget my Labor colleagues have analysed in great detail the detrimental consequences of this Budget on the Australian people and the inhumane values on which it is based. Their criticisms have been echoed by millions of people in this nation, the big majority of whom are opposed to this Government and its policies. Indeed, a national survey in Monday's Age shows that 73 per cent of Australians believe that they will be worse off with the Federal Budget and only 2 per cent believe that they will be even a little better off. So much for the claim that the Government's Budget fulfils the aspirations of Australian society today.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister's friends will be better off.

—That is true. The Prime Minister's friends will be better off. Nevertheless there is something in the challenge which the Australian newspaper has thrown out with its claim that there is no alternative to neo-conservative philosophies such as Fraserism. This is because the economic and social problems which we face in Australia are fundamental and the challenge before us is a serious one. It was raised succinctly in an editorial on the Budget in the Canberra Times of Saturday 29 August, entitled 'What Has Gone Wrong?' The newspaper asks how is it that one in five Australians are living in poverty. The editorial states:

SPEECH.PARA: Two thoughts immediately suggest themselves. The first is that there may be a great deal more hardship and poverty in Australia now than there was 10 years ago. The second is that much of the government spending that has occurred in the interim has been misdirected or, alternatively-dare it be said?-that the public sector's spending as a proportion of Gross Domestic Product should be even higher to accommodate greater social security and social welfare spending . . .

That probably is the most pertinent question that could be asked after Australia's experience during the past decade, for it encompasses the debate about the size of the public sector, the relative importance of traditional monetary and fiscal policies compared with incomes policies, and the debate about who is going to benefit from the resources boom. And until it is answered properly, and the implications of the answer understood, the lessons of the 1970s will remain unlearnt, the mistakes are likely to be repeated, and their damaging and divisive effects on Australians will be compounded to the diminution of all of us.

It is clear, that a new philosophy needs to be articulated in these depressed times when the Liberal Government has squeezed every ounce of hope from the people of this nation. This philosophy presents vision of a new future and a much better society for ourselves and our children. This philosophy is the new democratic socialism. It is the philosophy which, with increasing momentum, is being articulated from within the Australian Labor Party and in the democratic socialist parties throughout the world.

There are four major features which this democratic socialism would embody within the Australian context: First, a war against poverty in order to achieve a more equitable distribution of wealth; secondly, a substantial expansion in the provision of services to the people through the public and communal sectors of the economy; thirdly, a complete overhaul of the taxation system to make it more progressive and to include the introduction of a capital gains tax; and, fourthly, a substantial extension of public ownership in the economy, including especially the introduction of enterprises jointly owned by the public and private sectors.

I proceed now to outline these features in more detail and some of the concrete reforms necessary to implement them. First, a continuous war against poverty aiming to wipe out the ugly phenomenon referred to in the editorial from which I have quoted. This poverty is especially serious for our Aboriginal people and we stand condemned in the eyes of the world for it. But it is also present, in a less obvious yet insidious fashion, in our big cities and towns. The cause of this poverty is, firstly, the blatantly unjust and unequal distribution of wealth in this country and, secondly, the continuous plundering of the wealth of this nation by foreign interests, especially the foreign corporations. A war against poverty thus requires a struggle for a more equal distribution of the nation's wealth and an immediate end to the traitorous rip-off of Australia's resources by foreign interests. Such a war against poverty is not only the task of the Australian Labor Party; it is the duty of all Australians who believe in social justice, including all those who call themselves Christians. They must stand up and be counted. They must resist the Fraser Government's continuous attempts to make the rich richer at the expense of the overwhelming majority of the Australian people. They must also work for, and help achieve, the substantial and fundamental reforms which will be necessary if this war against poverty is to be won. Reform policies for the alleviation of poverty must be based on the recognition that the social security system in itself has not succeeded in resolving the problem. This is so notwithstanding the increase in total outlays for social security from 14.3 per cent of the Budget in 1969-70 to 24.7 per cent in 1979-80. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. These figures contrast the actual payout in social security for 1979-80 with that predicted a decade ago. Three figures stand out here. Age and service pensions were predicted to be $2,241m but were actually $4,034m, nearly double. This was not just due to the increase in payments in real terms which occurred during the term of the Whitlam Labor Government. The figures also reflect the fact that Australia has an aging population, with a greater proportion of persons in this category.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, child endowments and family allowances were $470m less than predicted, that is, reduced by 35 per cent. This reflects the Government's policies of reducing allowances in real terms. Third and most important, the predicted figure for unemployment benefits was for only $70m. The actual figure was $1,105m, a rise of over 1,000 per cent. This, of course, reflects the dramatic increase in the number of unemployed persons over the decade. Furthermore, and very significantly, if one discounts the increases above the expected level for unemployment and old age recipients, which total $2,828m, we see that this accounts for almost all of the increases beyond the predicted level. So much then for the claim that the Government is being much more generous with its social security dollars now than it was 10 years ago. The increased spending was forced on it because, through bad policies, many more people are receiving benefits than was originally predicted. Yet, the level of benefits remains well below the Henderson poverty line, especially for those on unemployment benefits.

What of solutions? As Professor Henderson remarked years ago, a war on poverty requires that all persons receive a guaranteed minimum income to at least the poverty line. This can be done by either a negative income tax or by increasing social security benefits to that level. The method is not of immediate importance; it is the result which counts, that is, ensuring that all persons have a minimum income to provide those things which they must buy through the market economy. But while such a guaranteed income for all people is a necessary condition for eradicating poverty, it is not in itself sufficient, for it needs to be supplemented by the provision of a large number of services through the public sector. There are two kinds of services which are necessary here: Those which are provided for the specially disadvantaged, such as the handicapped and the chronically ill, and those which are provided universally to all. The extension of this latter group of services is an essential feature of socialist philosophy.

The second feature is a large increase in the number of services provided to the people through a reorganised and revitalised public sector of the economy. The provision of services in education, health, welfare and the arts is something which people should consider not a privilege but a basic right. The public sector should also provide for greater access to housing, better roads and transport systems, decent planning in urban and regional development, and the protection of the environment. It is necessary to put an end, once and for all, to the extraordinary myth that the quality of life and the standards of living of people somehow increase if they have to find money to pay for these things through their own pockets. To provide communally for the basic material and cultural needs of people is not, as the Prime Minister would have us believe, to reduce peoples' freedoms. It is in fact to provide the preconditions for people to exercise genuine freedom and genuine choice. Just as the child who has received a decent education has many more opportunities for self-development than one who cannot read, so the citizen who has been provided with the basic material and cultural needs will be able to flourish and to make a much greater contribution to society. Indeed, the failure of this Government to provide for the basic needs of people, even when they cry out for help, as is the case with the young unemployed and the women in refuges, exemplifies the inhumanity of Fraserism.

In pursuing the goal of reducing the public sector, both within the Federal Government and in the States, this Government turns a blind eye to the tragic human consequences. Thus it has tried to make a big business out of the health and welfare of individuals, claiming that we should make people bear the burden. But I ask: Is a person who is so ill as to be hospitalised or a person who turns to a social worker because of the trauma of a broken marriage not sufficiently burdened? Does he or she also need to be further burdened by this Government's stringent financial policies in health and welfare? Is it any wonder that even many Liberals have branded this Government as one totally lacking in compassion? The problems regarding health and welfare can be generalised to all the areas of human needs services I have mentioned. By refusing to expand public services, this Government is not increasing freedom, but keeping people locked in chains of ignorance and poverty.

But there is a further factor which the Government dogmatically refuses to face up to. In the economy, it is this area of public services which is most labour-intensive and in which growth in employment can take place-if it is allowed to do so. The legacy of the Fraser Government is that, at the time when there is an unprecedented demand for government services, many of the people who can provide those services, such as teachers, are unemployed. Yet the dogmatic claim that the private sector will provide decent jobs for all these people has been exposed as nonsense. At this juncture the Federal Treasurer (Mr Howard) and many members opposite are likely to object: Where is the money coming from? That is a reasonable request and it deserves a considered reply. I do not deny that such a program requires an increased level of public spending-and a substantially increased level at that.

What I deny, however, is that this will require increased taxation on workers and their families, for the only way to fund a decent level of public services and to provide a guaranteed minimum income for all is to implement the third aspect of democratic socialism; which is the complete overhaul of the taxation system, including the introduction of a capital gains tax. It has become increasingly clear to the people of this nation that workers and their families are bearing a disproportionate burden with the existing taxation system. This can be easily shown from the estimate of Budget receipts for 1981-82. The biggest contribution to taxation is by far the taxes paid by employees under the pay-as-you-earn system-a total of $17,255m. In addition to this, however, a further $2,913m will be paid in sales tax, including the new tax of 2 1/2 per cent on clothing, books, building materials and many other items. Excise taxes on beer, spirits and cigarettes will be a further $1,859m. Finally, and most importantly, taxes on petrol and related products will be $4,396m. Nearly all of these indirect taxes-amounting to $9,163m-are passed on to consumers, most of whom are workers and their families. On the other hand, companies-I remind the House that many big businesses are foreign owned-are paying only $5,170m. Thus working people are paying more than four times as much in taxes as big business.

This Government has talked a lot about the possibility of tax reform, but all proposed reforms have been merely to change from direct to indirect taxes. There have not been any reforms which would in fact shift more of the tax burden onto the shoulders of the wealthy and the big corporations. If anything, the Government's abandonment of tax indexation has shifted more of the burden onto families with average or lower incomes. It is therefore necessary to change the distribution of the tax burden in a radical way. The most important reform required here is the introduction of a capital gains tax. Such a tax would prevent the situation whereby many wealthy individuals make handsome profits through the sale of property, shares and assets, but do not have to pay any tax at all. Most Western nations, including the United States, have such capital gains taxes, and the introduction of these to Australia is now an urgent necessity. Such a tax is also very necessary if tax avoidance is indeed to be wiped out, for the ability to represent income as capital gains is by far the major loophole in the tax system, and will be eradicated only when capital gains taxes are introduced.

The Australian Labor Party proposes also to introduce a resources rent tax, and this will also ensure that those resources companies which are making super-profits will pay reasonable taxes on that income. If these measures are introduced, it will be possible to remove the sales taxes imposed by the Government in this Budget and to give some income tax relief to lower and middle order wage earners. These moves would restructure the tax system so that big corporations and wealthy individuals would bear their fair share of the burden. It would also allow a Labor government to present a balanced Budget, if this was considered appropriate fiscal policy.

However, while the above changes to the tax system would allow for moderate extension of public services, the complete program of guaranteed minimum income and major extension of services and public employment outlined earlier requires a further feature: A substantial extension of public ownership in the economy, including especially the introduction of enterprises jointly owned by the public and private sectors. Australia has one of the lowest sectors of public participation in profitable enterprises in the whole Western world. The Government, of course, foolishly believes that it should sell off such profitable enterprises to the private sector, thereby depriving itself of a major non-taxation source of revenue. To do this would be to impose further tax burdens on ordinary Australians, for the lost revenue has to be made up. The Government has not given a single viable reason why such enterprises as the Bendigo Ordnance Factory, the Government bookshops or Trans Australia Airlines should be sold to private enterprise. Strong, profitable public enterprises are essential if we are to provide sufficient public revenue on a long term recurring basis to fulfil the needs of our people. In the Australian context there are two sectors of the economy in which such public enterprises can profitably invest; the resources sector and the high technology sector.

I will refer to a number of specific issues within this Budget that affect this side of the House, the mass of the Australian people and, in particular, those who are resident in my electorate of Calare. Before I do so I congratulate the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) because he is one of the few Opposition speakers who have endeavoured to point out from where the additional revenue would be raised to pay for the principles of democratic socialism that he has been espousing. I do not recall whether the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling), who spoke earlier, endeavoured to say at any stage from where these programs would be funded. If I recollect correctly, at one stage she criticised Government members for being party to increasing expenditure and increasing taxation, yet at the same time that was exactly what she was advocating. I think it has been most interesting and edifying for those people who are listening to this broadcast that they have had confirmed three times in the last 20 minutes that the Australian Labor Party stands for the introduction of a capital gains tax. The coal miners in the Lithgow area earning their $600 to $700 a week, investing in real estate and providing for their retirement, will be very interested to know and to have it confirmed that the Labor Party stands for the introduction of a capital gains tax and that it stands also for the reintroduction of a resources rent tax on super-profits. I ask the honourable member for Burke on the very criteria that the Opposition has proposed for a super-profits tax, how many coal companies would actually be paying a super-profits tax right now? The answer is only one-the Utah company. It will be a long time before significant revenue will be forthcoming from such a tax. The Opposition seems to forget that nasty private enterprise, nasty so-called big business, is very nasty also in that it employs people! The vast proportion of the people of this country are employed by the private sector. I thank the Opposition again for announcing to the people of Australia that it is out to cripple the private sector through a capital gains tax, a super-profits tax and whatever. I would like to know also--
—Tell us about the bankruptcies of small business.

—The honourable member should be careful or he will get an ulcer. I would like to know also how the Opposition proposes to crack down on tax avoidance because its track record is dismal. Not one tax avoidance measure was introduced in Labor's term of office. I ask Opposition members opposite to name one measure. There is a deafening silence.
