SPEECH.PARA: I will deal now with some specific measures. Firstly, in the health area the Opposition and some of its colleagues in the States are crying that the health measures that have been introduced will penalise a large mass of the Australian community who will not be able to cover themselves for health insurance costs. This is blatant rubbish. My colleague the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) has pointed out that only one in four Australians will face more expensive health insurance under the new proposals than under the old proposals. Under the new health scheme it is cheaper, or else it is free, for nearly three quarters of the people in Australia. This is largely a result of the expanded coverage for people eligible for free health care, and the introduction of a tax rebate of 32c in the dollar for the basic insurance premium. Opposition members are quiet. It must be because they are in agreement. The New South Wales Government has attempted blatant deception in its advertising of health changes. The Minister for Health in New South Wales, Mr Stewart-I will quote him directly in case some of our more academic friends would like to correct me-stated:
As a result of changes to Federal Government legislation affecting health funding . . . free hospital treatment in New South Wales has ended for all, with some exceptions.

Mr Stewart then goes on to point out that health care will be available for migrants and refugees in the first six months in Australia as if that is a State initiative. It is not; it is solely Commonwealth. The second point in the New South Wales Ministers' pamphlet is that those on unemployment or special benefits within certain income limits will be eligible for free health care. That is nothing to do with New South Wales; it is entirely Commonwealth. In an advertisement the Minister goes on to say:
The New South Wales Government will not see sick people denied help because of the Commonwealth's lack of concern for the sick.

What the Minister does not say is that 85 per cent of pensioners in New South Wales are already getting free health care under the Commonwealth's programs. Yet Mr Wran and his candidates have the hide to attempt to take credit for that. Over one million pensioners, veterans, low income earners, unemployed and those on special benefits are receiving free health care from this Government. Let us look at the hospital situation. Mr Wran has claimed that through a reduction in health funds for public hospitals he is having to close down public hospitals or change their role and function. Again, what rubbish! The Commonwealth's contribution to public hospitals in New South Wales has increased consistently every year from 1976-77, when it was $315m, until 1980-81, when it was $474m. On top of that the Wran Government should have available to it an additional $51m that it can put into its various health schemes. It acknowledges that fact because it is now saying that it has more funds available so that it can provide free health care for this 15 per cent of pensioners who are not covered by the Commonwealth. Where does that money come from? Mr Wran has also very proudly claimed that he has not had to put up taxes and charges in New South Wales. He has been able to do all these things because of his economic management and economic wizardry. Rubbish! That is largely due to the generosity of the Commonwealth and the tax-sharing formula that this Government introduced which provides for a rebate of personal income tax revenue to the various States.

In my electorate is a village of Carcoar which has a hospital that has been there for many years. It has been told that it will have to close its doors between the hours of 11 p.m. and 7 a.m. but that does not matter, it can still operate as a hospital. That is a hospital that closes at 11 p.m. and opens at 7 a.m. Recently there was a move-it was deferred because of the election-to close its doors from 5 p.m. to 7 a.m., to make it a hospital which operates for 10 hours a day, despite assurances by the New South Wales Minister that the hospital's role and function, particularly its acute care facilities, would not be changed in any way. Honourable members can well imagine how happy the people of Carcoar are when they realise that funds from the Commonwealth have been increasing every year that the Fraser Government has been in power.

I now turn to some claims made about roads. I was fascinated to see some campaign material from the Australian Labor Party. It was dropped into my letterbox. It claims that in this current Budget the Commonwealth's contribution to roads in New South Wales was $213m and the Wran Government's contribution was $590m. The Commonwealth's contribution is correct; it is $213m. But the Wran Government's claimed contribution of $590m is interesting. When one looks at the New South Wales Budget papers for this current financial year we find that the Wran Government acknowledges that the Commonwealth provided $213m of that $590m. It acknowledges that $288m comes from State revenues and the remainder comes from borrowings and the general loan account. The Commonwealth's contribution is contained within that $590m. Let us look a little further as to where--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is double counting.

—Of course it is double counting. It is almost triple counting. Let us look at where those road allocations go. The Commonwealth's contribution goes to main roads, local roads and national roads. Of the Wran Government's contribution, virtually nothing goes to national roads and nothing goes to local government roads-the ratepayers and the Commonwealth have to provide for them. Its main contribution goes to main roads. In fact its direct contribution to roads in New South Wales is $200m compared with the Commonwealth's contribution of $214m and a very large proportion of the balance from the New South Wales Government, of $140m, is taken up in debt charges and administration. So much for the claims being made by the New South Wales Government in advertisements about roads. Let us look at the prospect of increasing developmental roads in New South Wales. I personally favour the Commonwealth seriously considering withdrawing from funding rural arterial roads and putting all its efforts into national roads-both national highways and development roads-and the State Government taking full responsibility for its main and trunk roads.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning it was interesting to see that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has ruled that an advertisement by the Public Transport Commission of New South Wales is in breach of the broadcasting legislation as far as electoral advertisements are concerned. On top of that we know that the New South Wales taxpayers are contributing about $1.25m under the public funding program. That money is being taken from the New South Wales taxpayers by stealth. They are not asked whether or not they wish to provide that money. They were not given the opportunity to have a say in a referendum and they will object very, very, strongly to it. Unfortunately, I do not believe the majority of voters in New South Wales know that they are directly contributing to political parties with which they possibly have no affiliation whatsoever. Worse still, not only do we see the smiling face of Mr Wran projecting his image through advertisements paid for by taxpayers under public funding but also through the Public Transport Commission advertisements and the Carnivale advertisements. The referendum advertising will cost taxpayers in New South Wales the best part of $1m. Again we can see implicit in that advertising an opportunity for the Wran Government to get free electioneering advantage. Let us not forget that the Labor Party in New South Wales and throughout Australia is also supported by union dues and union subscriptions. Again that money is taken from unionists without their say and without their consent. Worse still, it is the only form of political party donation that I know of that is tax deductible.

I refer now to some matters which relate to local government. The Commonwealth provides a very significant share of its tax revenue to local government. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This year's Budget has been described by most commentators as severely contractionary. As the Applied Economic and Social Research Institute at Melbourne University pointed out, it represents new measures to restrain the expansion of demand which are now being introduced just as that expansion is beginning to slow. The Government is using all the instruments of policy open to it-control over interest rates, monetary policy, fiscal policy and Budget policy-to ensure that people's real incomes decline and that their spending power is reduced. This means that the growth in the economy, particularly in the first half of last year, will be allowed to dissipate. The policies must surely result not only in a contraction of the economy and a reduction in the people's incomes but also in a lack of access to public services which form part of the social wage. We should not forget as we look at this Budget that it follows a series of policy announcements which were the result of the deliberations of the Lynch committee, the so-called razor gang. The contraction in the public sector employment must result in a reduction in the quality of government services, which on balance will mean a loss of services to lower income groups.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes in health policy announced earlier this year and reflected in the Budget represent a major transfer of cost to the ordinary wage and salary earner. The fact that people will be forcedback into health insurance will mean an extra cost to the average family of at least $10 a week. However, the impact of this change in health insurance arrangements will fall particularly on the lower income family, the so-called working poor. These are the people whose incomes are between $200 and $300 a week, who will be denied access to public hospital without payment and who will be forced to take out health insurance. The changes include also the transfer of responsibility to the States of community health centres and dental care programs, which will mean, in the longer run, that lower income people will lose access to high quality primary health care. This will result in greater long term costs for health services. Thus, the Government continues to tighten the screws, not on its supporters, but on the working people of this nation. It is they who will be paying higher rates of taxation, higher interest rates for housing, more for health care, a higher price for basic consumer goods as a result of sales taxes, import parity prices for petrol to run their cars, higher electricity bills and gas charges and higher fares on public transport.

There is no compensation on the other side of the ledger. The Government continues to oppose wage and salary increases, to keep a tight rein on non-wage incomes and to reduce access for lower income people to basic services. The massive cutback in public housing programs has been severely criticised by every housing Minister in Australia with the exception of the Commonwealth Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh). The Government is unique among conservative governments. These governments have never been strong on justice. This Government not only reinforces inequality, but is also not prepared to ensure that people are guaranteed basic minimum standards of living. Notwithstanding its political philosophy, this is a government with an antediluvian economic philosophy. John Kenneth Galbraith in his book A life in Our Times noted that in the United States economics are still being taught-one might say that the same is true of Australia-on the basis of a fiction which has no relationship to the economic realities in the twentieth century. He said:

The business firm of the text books is still, in structure and market power, political power and social motivation, the microscopic competitive world of the Marshallian world. Where there were departures it was the exceptional case of monopoly or oligopoly and here both motivation and internal structure were essentially the same. Large or small there was still the driving force of the profit maximizing entrepreneur.
He continued:

This view of economic and social and political life allowed and still allows hundreds and thousands of students to be instructed in economics each year without intruding or damaging thoughts on the way that, as a matter of inherent and organic character, the great corporation exercises power over prices, costs, technology, consumer taste, military expenditure and government policy.
Galbraith concluded:
It is on the State that the public must rely for the assertion of the public interest. The State however is extensively under the control of corporate power.

Once one recognises the transformation of the corporate world into a network of international firms operating on a global basis, one recognises that the nation State's continued existence is at peril as an independent entity. This year's Budget is, in my view, quite clearly transparent to that controlling international interest.

This Government is a government in the service of corporate capitalism and of its institution, both private and public. The slogan is no longer: 'What is good for the General is good for America' or for that matter Australia. Rather, we are asked to believe that what is good for CRA Ltd, for Alcoa of Australia Ltd, for ICI Australia Ltd or for Safeway is good for the world. That is what is being challenged-a right of a national government to make an economic policy which it believes to be in the best interests of its citizens. We are being told that such a view is out of date and that the old rules which might have applied in the mercantilist days of the eighteenth century should be applied now. The international market place is the thing, the doctrine of so-called comparative economic advantage, the reduction of trade barriers and the open economy. The government which governs least governs best. An end to regulation by government and the introduction of self-regulation is the prevailing philosophy.

The philosophy of supply-side economics which is being foisted on this Parliament and which has the support, not only of the so-called dries but also of opposing camps for the leadership of the Liberal Party, one led by the Prime Minister (Mr Fraser) and the other led by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock)-represents a new phase in the evolution of conservative economic philosophy in this country. It should be seen as post-Menzies in its substance and in its reality. It is producing and will produce deep divisions in the Liberal Party and, I believe, may result, within a matter of a few short years, in the death of that Party. The Liberal Party which has in its history been able to make some claim to represent the interests of local capital is now, in my belief, completely under the domination of international capital. This Budget reflects that change. It reflects the Government's willingness, at the behest of international companies, to sacrifice the interests of the Australian people to demands of international capital. This is reflected in the massive inflow of foreign capital which has taken place in the last financial year. This has amounted to $6,500m. The Government expects and, indeed, hopes that this inflow will continue this year to the tune of $7,000m. The Melbourne Institute has pointed out:

Massive private capital inflow was the dominant factor in the money supply growth despite the record current account deficit, and is expected again to be an important source of money supply growth in 1981-82. At the same time to counter this expansionary influence on the money supply, public spending is being cut back and some government authorities are being constrained from borrowing overseas. Yet domestic interest rates are reaching record levels and funds are growing scarce for domestic borrowers, both householders and semi-government authorities while overseas funds for resources development by the private sector remains abundant.

The Government's failure to act to restrain foreign investment in the Australian economy, as opposed to its willingness to slug domestic consumers and services, is to be condemned for a number of reasons. Firstly, it is not at all clear that the funds from the inflow of foreign investment are going where the Government suggests that they may be. There is growing evidence, to which the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) referred, that a substantial proportion of these funds are going into the takeover of existing Australian enterprises and to real estate speculation. Both would be matters of concern. If the emphasis is on foreign takeovers, there is no protection against the loss of control over Australian technology or any protection against asset stripping and rationalisation resulting in reduced employment. The investment in real estate has already attracted government concern, particularly in respect to agricultural land.

However, there is also the issue of the investment of foreign capital in real estate ventures in the downtown areas of the larger cities as well as, more generally, in the housing market. The rapid inflation of land and housing prices in Sydney and Melbourne over the past few years has undoubtedly been related to the inflow of foreign capital. It is certainly an important factor in the Sydney property boom.

Secondly, it appears that rather than the majority of funds coming in from overseas going into resource development, the resource development is being financed largely from within the Australian capital market. Australian borrowings from foreign controlled corporations as a proportion of total funds raised by these corporations rose from 14 per cent in 1977-78 to 63 per cent in 1978-79. In 1979-80 that proportion was 55 per cent. Foreign controlled corporations have increased their Australian borrowings as a proportion of total domestic savings from 1.4 per cent in 1977-78, to 18.8 per cent in 1978-79 and to 20 per cent in 1979-80; that is, $1 for every $5 saved in Australia is being used by these corporations with no increase in the level of Australian equity.

Thirdly, we have seen that cumulative real growth in the money supply since 1975-76 has been only 4.7 per cent, while the growth in real income has been 14.4 per cent over the same period. This policy of tight money, combined with a massive increase in foreign money coming into the country, has meant that something has had to give. The Government has decided that what should give is the access to money by the domestic householder, the small investor and the semi-government authorities. The result must be a further contraction in the economy, a reduction in services, an increase in unemployment and further depression in living standards.

Fourthly, the Government appears to have disregarded the fact, in its attitude to foreign investment, that not only will we lose effective control of the domestic economy but also we will see increasing amounts of money repatriated in the form of dividends to shareholders in countries overseas. We are in effect building up a debt which must be paid for at some time in the future. Since 1972-73 the net outflow of funds associated with direct investment by overseas firms has exceeded the actual inflow of funds from abroad. In fact, over the period from 1972-73 to 1978-79 the excess of net outflow of funds amounted to $1,933m. In 1977-78, $1 in every $3 of company income in Australia was being repatriated overseas. As the levels of foreign investment go up so must the levels of foreign repatriation. In addition, repatriation of debt will increase. Each year between 1973-74 and 1979-80 the net effect of foreign investment on balance of payments was negative. Once the current phase of capital investment ends the balance of payments deficits will go up on the invisibles account. So it is that the Government is in the process of selling this nation. This nation is literally for sale. We have never had a government which was less committed to overall development, to balanced development, to facing the problems of people as opposed to dealing in fictions and in abstractions.

In no area of policy is the unreality of government policy more apparent than in the resources area. For years the Government has been holding before us the mirage of resource development as the saviour of the country's economy. Each year, and especially in election years, the figures get to be grander and grander. However, in all the time the Government has been in office there has never been a serious economic analysis of any of the projects, and certainly not of the projects that affect particular industries. The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson), who is at the table, is responsible for environmental matters. For years people have said: 'Let us look at the aluminium industry in this country. Let us look at all the costs as well as the benefits. Let us see what an industry of a certain scale would do for the people of this country'. Never at any stage has the Government conceded that that kind of analysis is necessary. Never has the Government committed itself to analysing what are the costs and benefits that may be associated with the development of, for example, a resource-based industry. It has simply asserted that we stand to gain from these developments. However, in the meantime we need to cut consumption, tighten spending, reduce real wages, run down public services, reduce people's standards of living and sharpen inequality.

There are associated with the resource development area a number of basic questions which any responsible national parliament would want to ask itself and would want to see answered. There are, for example, questions about the model of the economy which will see the nations real income built more and more in terms of export earnings. At least that is the assumption. What are the lessons of CRA's result this year? The fact is that that company and a fair share of the Australian economy, one could say, were totally dependent on what was happening in terms of international metal exchanges. Those exchanges went down internationally, that company's income went down to zero, and the Government's income necessarily would have gone down with it.

Let us take the aluminium industry. If the market remains depressed for two or three years, as internationally it is depressed at the moment, what happens to all the increased power capacity that is being provided by State governments across this country, at the price of rapidly escalating electricity bills-an increase of 40 per cent in the last 12 months in Victoria-if the aluminium industry does not go ahead to the projected levels of development? We are heading for a disaster. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) said yesterday at an Estimates committee hearing that it was of no concern to the Federal Government what the economics were of any resource project even though this Government authorised special infrastructure loans to encourage the States to race with a mad rush into power development to service an industry which historically has been highly cyclical and which is quite likely not to be able to sustain the kind of industry that the corporate sector plans for Australia.

What would be the implications for the public sector of this mad rush into power stations, coal loaders and capital infrastructure which is taking place across the country? Who is paying for it? The answer is that it is being paid for by the present consumers. That is why those prices are going up in Victoria and in various other States. The people are paying higher electricity prices so that companies can go in for these gigantean schemes which are based on an economic analysis in which this Government expresses no interest and which in my view is quite possibly faulty. What, one might ask, does the restructuring of the Australian economy mean in terms of the domestic economy, in terms of the way in which the society is operating? Do we as a society really wish to divide the country between the Sunbelt, as it is called in the United States of America, and the established cities? What are the social implications of so-called unbalanced development? I have been in Chicago, New York and in the north-east of the United States. That part of the country is a disaster area, whatever may be happening in the Sunbelt. I think we need to look very seriously at what restructuring means in terms of its social implications. We as a country cannot develop as we have in the past by importing a massive labour force from overseas to work in manufacturing industries and then say in 1980: 'That is it. That is the end of manufacturing industry. We do not want that any more. We are going into all these resource projects which are highly capital intensive, which will employ very few people and certainly will not employ the people who are currently unemployed'.

What are the implications of moving to a kind of development which will have us exporting more energy, processing minerals and importing more finished goods, especially capital goods? What will be the future of manufacturing industry under these policies? Can we assume that net economic and social benefits, in terms of the industries in which the Government has decided to allow free market forces to operate-that is, the international oligopolies-will expand without regulation? Where are the overall cost benefit analyses which prove that when all the costs and the benefits are calculated there will be a net gain? What are we prepared to sacrifice to let this whole process happen?

The short term costs of unplanned and market oriented resource development are getting to be clearer and clearer. Most people understand them. They mean higher interest rates, reduced government services, and mounting housing prices in resource areas and in the established areas of the large cities. They mean the diversion of capital away from established areas in favour of new areas that may never be established as any more than temporary cities. We have seen all this before in this country and we know what it means. This country was built on a tradition of people living their lives in temporary cities that finally decline and die when the gold is gone. We are building on unstable and uncertain foundations.

The new gold-uranium-is being exploited for uncertain markets in a world in which it would be the fuel to destroy civilisation. There may be a few bucks in it; it is by no means certain. It is more certain that it represents a threat to the life of the Aboriginal people at Oenpelli. It is certain that it will threaten the lives of those people who work in the industry. It is clear that there will be fewer, rather than more, safeguards internationally. Uranium will be a fuel for destruction exploited by international companies which have infinite confidence in their own survival and very little interest in the survival of people.

This Budget is the Budget of a people whose masters have no interest in or loyalty to this society. It is unfortunate that the suburban lawyer who is our Treasurer and who is undoubtedly a good bookkeeper does not have a greater sensitivity to the larger issues that are involved in the way in which this society is being restructured. I conclude by referring to an article by Kenneth Davidson in the Age of 3 September, in which he said:
Mention the resources boom and watch the eyes glaze over. The general response is: 'It has nothing to do with me. I don't own shares'.
Well, dear reader, it has everything to do with you, and you are making a large contribution to the financing of the new resources projects now getting underway.

The heroes of this development process may be the large mining houses such as CRA or BHP, and the new class of financial manipulators or mining entrepreneurs (take your pick) from Western Australia, but make no mistake, the bulk of the savings and most of the sacrifices are being made by the average Joe Joesephene in the household sector of the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every Budget presented by this Government since its return has been met by the Opposition with words of gloom and despair. As usual, what we have heard today and what we have been listening to with unremitting lack of zeal in recent days is no exception. The inability of the Australian Labor Party even to formulate a viable alternative Budget and the performance of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) on the floor of this House make it quite clear that the Labor Party of Australia is still not able to lead this country and has learned nothing in its years in isolation on the Opposition benches. Deficit budgeting, as advocated by the Opposition, cannot bring about lower inflation. It cannot reduce interest rates. It can achieve nothing of lasting worth. In fact, it would destroy the sound economic measures which have achieved excellent results over the last six years. It has taken us all that time to restore the confidence of Australians in Australia and of the world in Australia. Yet those people opposite forget so easily that under Labor, under the Whitlam Administration, in one year alone personal income tax rose by 46 per cent, compared with wage rises of a mere 23 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been told by the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous), who is an outstanding spokesman for left wing democratic socialism, that we have to have more taxes, we have to have resource rental taxes, and we have to have capital gains taxes; that it is a sin for people to make any money; that the only honest man is one who is employed by the state for the state. What about the fact that the state is supposed to be the servant of the people? We have heard nothing of that, not a word. Once again, day after day we hear this extraordinary diatribe that somehow or other the economic system, based on the sweat and the capacity of the Australian people is to be given second or third place, in the belief that the solutions to Australia's problems are to be found simply in more and not less government interference, in more and not less taxation, in more and more detailed involvement of a government based in Canberra in the day to day activities of the Australian people.

This Government rejects that. This Government has been returned on three occasions on the firm understanding that we intend to develop Australia, to develop its resources, to give the people of this great nation of ours every opportunity we possibly can to achieve what this nation is capable of. That can be achieved only if we have policies directed at lowering and controlling inflation, policies directed at giving as many people as we possibly can useful and sustaining employment, policies directed at supplying the fundamental requirements of those in our community who, for whatever reason, do not have the opportunities to claim a fair share of this country's resources. Of course it is the responsibility of the state to see that those people's way of life and standard of living is maintained at a reasonable level. That cannot be achieved by the simple process of taxing people out of existence, nor can it be achieved by the continuation of policies which, in the eyes of the Labor Party, direct themselves at nothing more than taking from some and not giving to those who are in need. The taxes they take will simply be used up in more and more public administration employing more people to interfere in the decisions that other people have to make for themselves. This country would return once again to the doldrums we suffered so deeply in the years from 1972 to 1975.

TALK.START.PARA: —Socialist republicanism.

—A socialist republic. This nation wants to see dynamic development, development is not just a case of how many tonnes of iron ore we drag out of the ground. Development is more than that. It is the capacity to give to our people a belief in their role in the development of this nation. The policy we are enunciating and the principles we have once again emphasised in this Budget are the only ways we will be able to achieve those objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the record. In the last 12 months we have seen a reduction of inflation of 2 per cent. We are now down to about 8.8 per cent, which is the lowest we have had for some time. On international standards, comparing Australia's record with that of members of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development group, which is a fair comparison, we are seen internationally as an outstanding example of a young and dynamic community led by a government which knows where it is going in terms of philosophical principles, a government which knows how it will reduce inflation, which knows the difficulties that have to be faced and the often difficult decisions that have to be made. Success can be achieved only by a continuity of policy, not by changing our shirts every time it seems convenient, not by Opposition going to every group in the community and saying: 'We will give you more because we, the Opposition don't have to pay for it'. The simple fact which the Labor Party has consistently refused to accept is that the Government has the role of collecting taxation. It has, as a Government, to answer to the Australian people for what it has done. The Australian people in 1981 have not forgotten the lessons they learned with such difficulty in the past.

This Budget symbolises yet again the Government's determination to protect and to build upon the economic gains that we have already achieved. Decisive reductions in the deficit to further reduce inflation and to help ease pressure on interest rates are essential. We have heard so much today, and on other occasions, of the difficulties of young people in getting homes. I sympathise with them. All members of the Government parties sympathise. Most of us owe money to somebody, usually to the banks. We know what interest rates mean. We also know that there is no simple solution to high interest rates, certainly none suggested by the Opposition, except to cut back the Government's demand on the money market for funds, to ensure that the funds which are available in the Australian economy are able to be purchased at market values on the basis of priorities which will be set by the market-place. On many occasions in the past governments have tried to interfere with this basic economic fact. On every occasion all they have done is make the situation worse.

As the Treasurer (Mr Howard) said this morning, there are already indications that high interest rates have reached their maximum. I sincerely hope he is correct. I have noted with some optimism the trend in the United States in the last week. There are indications that if the United States interest rate structure settles down, and possibly falls, we will see a similar situation developing in Australia. I emphasise the point that there is no easy short-term solution to this type of problem. The fact of the matter is that there is more demand for money in Australia at present than available funds can be found in the market-place. Inevitably, the result of that is that prices for money, as for any other commodity, must rise.

Despite this situation, the benefits of the Government's fight against inflation have been clearly seen. Investment growth in the last 12 months increased by 20 per cent. A total of 140,000 new jobs have been created in 1980-81 alone. Through our training programs we hope to see a similar trend this year as well. Living standards are rising. Last year there was a 4 per cent increase in real terms. Only last week we learned that average weekly earnings were nearly $300 a week, the highest they have ever been in Australia's history. Confidence in Australia's economic future is obviously well on the way to being restored. The creation of additional jobs and higher real incomes is dependent on sustaining this confidence to generate further investment and productive growth for the future.

A number of subjects have been raised this afternoon to which I would like to refer. Firstly, we have the question of income tax. I made the observation earlier that it was under Labor that Australia reached its highest record annual level of income tax. Let nobody in this chamber or outside forget that fact. In 1977 the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman), who is at the table-he was then the honourable member for Denison-and I started a campaign called 'The 50c League'. On that occasion we took for the people of Australia to the Government, the demand that the maximum rate of tax should be 50c in the dollar. It is known that for economic reasons we did not achieve 50c in the dolar on that occasion, but we did achieve a significant cut-back in the mariginal tax rate in the last Lynch Budget which followed.

I believe on the basis of the taxation policies that have been followed by the Government this year, in particular the introduction of indirect taxation, the principles of which I support, that the Government will be in a position at the time of the next Budget to bring down considerable taxation reforms and reductions. It is in that context that I believe the Government should direct its efforts at maximising the rate of taxation at no more than 50c in the dollar. A similar reduction in all rate scales must, therefore, be carried through to ensure that pensioners and people on low incomes do not find themselves on higher tax scales purely because of inflationary factors. After all, the tax scales have not been changed since 1976. I hope that the next Budget will see reforms in that area.

This country will develop on the basis of people having more spending power on which they can make their own decisions. That they should have to give more money to governments indefinitely-this is the policy of the alternative government, the Labor Party-is obviously not the solution to Australia's problems in the future. The Leader of the Opposition was the man who presided as Treasurer over the introduction of the five most arduous taxation scales in the period 1974-75. He also presided as a member of the Government over the highest rate of taxation we have ever seen in Australia. The introduction of indirect taxation has generated a substantial amount of noise and little else from members of the Opposition. It is interesting that they should take this view. I would have thought that in any logical examination of the situation most Australian people would ask for a reduction of direct income tax in return for some increase in indirect taxes. I believe that the first step has been taken. I am optimistic that in the next Budget we will see a reduction in direct taxation.

I now refer to employment. In the last two years the number of people in jobs has increased by 330,000, the biggest increase in Australia's history. Spending on employment and training programs in this Budget alone has increased by 22 per cent in 1980-81. We expect to train 200,000 young people during this financial year, with 90,000 benefiting from participation in the Special Youth Employment Training Program alone. It is interesting to note some of the observations which have been made by members of the Opposition on this subject in this chamber in recent days and, in particular, in earlier years. I refer to the Community Youth Support Scheme which the Government for good reason has decided to scrap. The honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) this afternoon described this program as 'the best $14m the Government has ever spent'. Yet, one of her senior colleagues, the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) at the time we introduced the CYSS program said:

. . . is no more than tokenism, confined to creating drop-in centres, providing cuddle therapy rather than the jobs young people really need . . . The $12.6m would be better spent on genuine job creation and training programs.

That is exactly what we are now doing. The funds which are being taken from CYSS are being spent on a range of job training programs. It is strange how the memories of Opposition members are so short. They can afford such a luxury, hoping that nobody ever reads back into Hansard. However, with the abolition of the CYSS program I believe that we may face some difficulties. I do not accept the view that it is the responsibility of government to be the sole source of employment training. I believe the community has been and is willing to accept a real share of responsibility in this area. Therefore, I was delighted to note the remarks made by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) recently that if required the Government would be prepared to consider new programs to look after the section of unemployed youth who, for various reasons, often over which they have little if any control, are not able to fit in to the of training programs which will receive increased funding from the Government. It is my personal view that in the next 12 months or so such a new program may well be required.

On this subject I speak with some passion and concern. For three years in Sydney in my electorate I have been demonstrating through a pilot program called 'Youth Work' that there is a very close relationship between unemployment and the problems that a section-it is probably as high as 25 per cent-of unemployed youth face in being able to return to or be integrated into normal job employment opportunities. Many of these young people have difficulties in reading and writing. For those people to go into a program of training which involves academic disciplines is therefore, to put it mildly, somewhat difficult. There is a range of reasons why they are in that position, not the least of which are breakdowns in families and inability to receive an education in the normal context.

In those cases the Government has the opportunity to work with the community-I emphasise that-in encouraging the development of programs which gives the opportunities which every communtiy has for work training and experience and develop in young people perceptions of their capacity to make a contribution to society. Through self help work participation programs we can break down the deep-seated belief of many young people that they do not belong to society. They have a feeling of lack of participation and sense of self esteem, a belief that they are not a part of the community as a whole. We cannot encourage these people to develop such attitudes. We cannot as a government or a community allow them to persist any longer. We therefore have to find ways to develop community employment opportunities, to work with them to meet the community's needs. Participants must earn money and feel that they have a role to play. The 'Youth Work' program developed in Sydney has achieved much along these lines. I do not for a second suggest that it is necessarily perfect for everybody but it has certainly worked well in our area. The success rate is within the range of 65 per cent to 70 per cent. I believe that this is a result with which we can be justly satisfied. The role of government must be to help to create the conditions, climate and opportunities for people if it wants them to have a more direct role in the activities of this nation as a whole.

I now turn to foreign investment. It has been for many years the big bogy of the Labor Party. It believes that this nation somehow can develop and create the funds to keep our economy moving forward and not slipping backwards, as it did under Whitlam; that we do not need any foreign money to do it. The simple fact is that this nation has always been an importer of foreign capital. If we consider the various boom periods of the 19th and 20th centuries and what has been achieved it is abundantly clear that we are the ones who have come out on the right side of the ledger. However, the time has now come for us to give serious consideration to the further development of Liberal philosophy. It has always been the view of most, if not all, Australians that the individual has the right to sell his labour on the market. Strangely enough, however, we have never really developed the concept that the same individual has the right to sell his capital at the going market rate. That is the essence of the concept of Trust Australia which some honourable members may be aware I and my colleague Mr Moore are developing. It has been referred to in the media. I hope to see the Government take initiatives in this area in the near future.

The basic principle of Trust Australia is that every Australian has the right to feel that he can participate in a practical way in the development of this nation and gain from his investments. Because he is prepared to share the risks as well as the benefits of developing Australia he may increase his income by dividends. It is not good enough for the Labor Party to prattle on about the flow of capital out of Australia in the form of dividends. That does not always have to be the situation. A great amount of that capital can remain in Australia provided the Australian people are prepared to take the risks. I regret to say that over the years there has not been a strong tendancy to do so. Equally, one has to be fair and say that the capital market is structured in such a way that the average Australian does not have access to those opportunities. Only 4 per cent of people in the Australian community, according to statistics prepared by the associated stock exchanges, actually own equity in Australian companies. For a country which has to develop so far and so fast, I regard that as a grossly unsatisfactory figure. What about the other 96 per cent? What can be done for them?

One of the proposals within the context of Trust Australia is that we should develop either one or a group of national trusts which will enable people who do not have access to the markets, people who do not understand the fine details of the monetary system, to be able to make investments in Australian companies on the basis of advice given to the trust by professional experts in the business to ensure that people have the opportunity to participate. On the basis of that experience, if they then want to go the next step and make individual investments, let them have the right to do so. The same principle applies to old people-the pensioners. Leaving money in a sock under the bed or putting it in no interest bearing deposits in banks is a travesty of the opportunities which should be given in the capitalist system. Those people, regardless of their age, have the right to be able to sell their capital at the going market rate. In that context, therefore, they also have a role to play in Trust Australia. On the basis of French experience, it is proposed that we should give investors a tax deduction on the maximum rate dividend or income of up to $1,500 a year. This would encourage average Australians to put their capital to work for the benefit of Australia and for their families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1981-82 which proposes to appropriate sums out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund for new policies, capital works and services, payments to the States and for the ordinary annual services of government. The Budget Papers accompanying the Appropriation Bills reflect the government's decisions and priorities on expenditure in relation to income received. I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) because one would reasonably expect that the annual priorities of any government would seek to provide sufficient funds to all sectors of the Australian community so that all Australians would be in a position to receive a fair share of the wealth of our nation. In the time available to me this afternoon I intend to portray how the Government's Budget for 1981-82 is not one which provides a fair share of the wealth of our nation to those in need but rather provides further concessions to those people in our community least in need and places greater burdens on those requiring assistance. In this, the Government's eighth Budget in six years, we see the worst example of the gross discrepancies in the division of the national cake between competing interests. It is a Budget that ignores the needs of the average family and of the disadvantaged. It is a Budget of deceit because tax concessions promised in October last year have been cancelled and the promises made earlier this year by the Government not to increase indirect taxes have been broken.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal firstly with revenue proposed to be raised under the Budget. The people of Australia need to be reminded that this Government came into office last October after promising tax reforms and tax cuts yet it is now responsible for the highest taxes in our history. Over the last five years this Government has taken $124,000m in taxes from the people of Australia. During the current financial year the Government proposes to tax the people a further $37,768m-an increase of 16 per cent over last year. When taking into consideration the fact that wages are expected to rise by 13.5 per cent and prices by 10.75 per cent, the increase in taxation revenue is quite considerable. It is even more considerable to those earning a wage because of the additional burden of taxation which they will endure under the pay-as-you-earn system whereby tax is deducted directly from wages prior to payment of those wages. On the Government's own admission personal income tax has gone up by 22 per cent. Over the past six years, pay-as-you-earn taxpayers have had to pay an additional 15 per cent in taxation for every dollar earned. During the current financial year, pay-as-you-earn income tax payments are expected to rise by no less than 22 per cent whereas income tax payers not in the pay-as-you-earn system are expected to pay only 5.3 per cent more in income tax than in the previous year, which obviously represents a very marked fall in the share of their incomes being paid as tax. What this means, in cold hard facts, is that when this Government came to office six years ago, the working person on a normal wage paid $1 in tax for every $5 earned. Today, it is $1 in tax for every $4 earned. In those six years, wages have doubled but pay-as-you-earn tax has risen by 150 per cent.

Let us look at the other side of the coin. Six years ago, companies paid 48 per cent of their profits in tax. The level this year is expected to be 41 per cent. In other words, companies which six years ago had to pay $1 in tax for every $2.10 in profits now have to pay only $1 in tax for every $2.40 in profits. Six years ago on average 17c in non-PAYE income tax was paid for every $1 of non-wage income. Today, the level is only 14c. The sense of inequity felt by pay-as-you-earn taxpayers when they see that other income earners are paying a continually falling share of total revenue from income tax is especially likely to elicit understandable discontent with the existing levels of money wages and salaries. Pay-as-you-earn wage and salary tax payers also may note with interest the allowance of $220m for revenue shortfalls in taxation on non-PAYE individuals resulting from tax avoidance practices. This means that the rise in revenue from non-PAYE taxpayers would be more than twice as great but for these tax avoidance practices.

On top of those taxation increases I have just outlined, the Government also is increasing sales tax on a broad range of items, some of which in the past attracted no sales tax impost at all. Receipts from sales tax this financial year will increase by $811m to $2,913m or, in percentage terms, by a massive 38.6 per cent. The decision to impose sales tax on a number of goods previously excluded means that clothing, footwear, drapery, soft furnishings, manchester, et cetera, building materials, books, magazines, newspapers, packaging and wrapping materials, tools and a range of other goods, not including at this stage food, medicine or wine, will now be taxed. What these increases mean, of course, is that a family of four now will pay an additional $4 per week for their basic necessities of life. The cost of a home also will increase by approximately $1,000 because of the impost of sales tax on building materials. For those families with children at school, the increases will be even higher because of the clothing content involved.

In the debate on the Sales Tax Amendment Bills a few weeks ago, I stated that I believe that the present sales tax increases are only the beginning and that food items and services which are presently exempt will be the next series of goods to be brought under the scope of sales tax imposts. This would then complete the package of suggestions made by Treasury in its 1974 Taxation Paper No. 5 dealing with Commonwealth taxation of goods and services. I predict that by next year the Government will have imposed sales tax on food and services which, if taxed at 2 1/2 per cent, will bring in additional revenue of at least $600m at today's prices. What this means in hard terms is that families will be paying a further $2.50 a week for their necessities. I seek the permission of the House to incorporate in Hansard Appendices D and E of that Treasury Paper No. 5 of 1974 which bear out what I have just outlined to the House.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Since this Government came to office in 1975, the average family has been a lot worse off. The costs of food and other essential goods have continued to rise and the cost of homes is beyond the reach of most wage earners. These massive increases in revenue are designed virtually to eliminate the Government's deficit during the current financial year for the express purpose of creating a reserve situation so that in 1983-an election year-the Government will be in a position again to bribe the people of Australia with promises of lower taxes. On three previous occasions the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) bribed the people of Australia at election time with promises of lower taxes. Eact time, after the elections had been won, the Prime Minister promptly not only broke his promises but also actually increased taxes. Obviously, we can expect the same lies and deceit in 1983.
—Order! The honourable member for Banks will withdraw those unparliamentary terms.

—I withdraw. The Budget receipts put paid to the Government's consistent claim that it is aiming at small government and that it is a low tax government. It is not a low tax government; in fact it is the highest taxing government ever seen in this country. This is a government whose aim is to shift the burden of revenue from the wealthy in our society on to the shoulders of those in the middle and lower income brackets. It proposes to do this by increasing indirect taxes and lowering direct taxes. This was confirmed by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on the Caroline Jones radio program on Tuesday morning of this week when he said that the Government was aiming at a different mix of taxes, so that indirect taxes are further increased. Promises made earlier this year by the Government that it did not propose to increase direct taxes were nothing but a pack of lies.
—Order! The honourable member again offends. I exhort him to be more careful. The honourable member will withdraw.
—I withdraw, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer told mistruths to the Australian people and to the Parliament at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: I now refer to the way in which the Government proposes to spend the funds available to it during the current financial year. If we turn to table 1 of Budget Paper No. 10 we see that the Government proposes to expend $40,862m through Commonwealth Government departments embraced within the Budget. In table 5 we see that a further $2,655m will be spent through Commonwealth authorities such as Telecom Australia and Australia Post, et cetera, which is not provided for in the Budget Bill before the House at present. This gives a total expenditure by the Government during the current financial year of $43.5 billion. During its six years of office government expenditure has increased from $20.6 billion to $43.5 billion, an increase of 111 per cent. The big difference, however, lies not in the amount of money expended, but in the priorities into which funds were channelled. Six years ago, under a Labor government, the major priorities were health, education, housing, welfare and urban and regional development. All those priorities have been reversed by the present Government to the extent where we see that funds for those priority areas have fallen. In real terms, education expenditure has fallen by 2 per cent, health is down by 22 per cent, transport and communications are down by 53 per cent, housing is down by 59 per cent and urban and regional development and environment are down by a massive 89 per cent.

The Government also will not provide the $9m necessary to continue funding the Community Youth Support Scheme, a scheme which directly employs almost 700 staff and which last year aided some 55,000 young unemployed people throughout Australia. The CYSS program conducted in my electorate at Panania has been very successful in providing 52 jobs and hope for some 1,700 young unemployed people over the last six months. Not only has it been able to find jobs for young people but more importantly it has given them a self-respect which will stand them in good stead and give them an advantage when they seek employment in our ever diminishing job market. The scheme deals with young people with a myriad of problems, including those from broken homes and those with drug related problems. Young people coming to the CYSS offices for help require special attention which, in my opinion, cannot be provided at normal Commonwealth Employment Service offices. I appeal to the Government to be big enough to reverse its decision to close down CYSS. Nine million dollars is a very modest sum indeed to provide to a scheme which is giving such human assistance to those young people in need. I place on record my appreciation of those people on the Panania CYSS management committee and of its two project officers for their tireless efforts and dedication in providing counselling and assistance to so many local unemployed young people over recent years. I can only hope and pray that their work can continue.

Government decisions in the welfare area are also dismal, with no new projects being funded and some organisations being funded at the same level as has applied for the last two years. I instance two local welfare organisations in my electorate which are struggling to survive. The Association for Children with Learning Disabilities at Peakhurst this year will receive $38,500, the same amount as it received last year. In 1979-80, however, it received $54,000. How in heaven's name does the Government expect this Association to keep going when its funds in real terms have been halved in two years? The Bankstown-East Hills Handicapped Children's Centre at Revesby has received a grant of $14,000, the same amount as for the last two years. It sought funds of over $30,000 to enable it to provide sufficient services. These organisations are surviving only because of the dedication of parents and of management. They run raffles, and social nights and fetes to raise funds so that young people attending these centres will continue to receive assistance. What kind of a government do we have that denies our handicapped children the right to a decent life? I will tell honourable members. This is a miserly and miserable government which decrees that funds go to the strong, the greedy, the rich and not to those in need. It is a government which has shown a great degree of indifference to the needs of the vast majority of Australians.

This Budget means more inflation, even higher interest rates and less economic growth. It is a savage attack on the living standards of Australian families. Australia now has the dubious distinction of having the second highest interest rates in real terms in the world. There is little light at the end of the tunnel, too, because whilst the Government continues to encourage an even larger inflow of foreign money than the $6.5 billion reached last year, interest rates will stay at a high level. Of this money coming in from overseas, $3 out of every $4 is going into taking over existing Australian businesses.

Families with three or more children total 26 per cent of all families in Australia. They will benefit from the increased family allowances-the first increase in five years. However, the other 1.5m families, many of them young families starting out, will get nothing. Instead they will have to pay out on a whole range of higher indirect taxes, including a new tax on essential goods such as clothing, as I previously have mentioned. These higher taxes come on top of increased health insurance payments and higher home loan repayments which already have been announced. It is another government Budget that takes more than it gives. Increased welfare benefits for a minority of families, pensioners and the unemployed will cost the Government less than $100m; yet the new taxes will cost the Australian community more than $450m. On top of all this the Government is planning a massive 22 per cent increase in income tax revenue, which means that the average taxpayer will have to pay an extra $580 this year, or more than $11 a week.

Overall, the Budget does nothing for Australia's future, despite all the sacrifice of the last five years. There will be more inflation, higher interest rates, less economic growth, no joy for the unemployed and higher taxes. In summary, three of every four Australian families get nothing from this Budget except higher taxes. In total, the Government's economic policy has cost the average family paying off a home an additional $40 a week because of the following increases: Income tax, $11 per week; sales tax, $4 per week; health insurance, $8 per week; and home repayments, because of interest rate increases, $17 per week. The Government has completely and utterly lost its credibility with the Australian electorate because of its success rate in breaking election promises and its dismal record in halting inflation and interest rates. It is a government which is not fit to govern. If it had any self-esteem it would resign and face the electorate so that it could be judged on its abysmal record.

In conclusion, I refer to a matter raised by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) last Wednesday evening in this debate. He cast reflections on myself and other members of the Opposition by insinuating that the oaths of allegiance taken last November were not taken properly because of the Labor Party's recent policy of working towards the goal of achieving a republic status for Australia. This Minister, who struts around Parliament, often displaying a greater degree of dress sense than good sense, should realise that loyalty to the Crown is not diminished by a longing for the reform of Australia into a more democratic society. I reinterate what I said in my maiden speech to this House on 26 November 1980: I consider that after almost 200 years of settlement Australia has advanced enough to be able to stand on its own feet and manage its own affairs without being dependent on outside influences. I believe that Australia should become a republic whilst remaining a member of the Commonwealth of Nations, and I will pursue that goal while I am a member of this Parliament, which I predict will be for a longer period than the honourable member for Denison will be able to achieve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not an ideal week, I believe, in which to speak on anything in this House because this place certainly has been groaning and creaking under the influence of the New South Wales State elections. I guess it has been accepted by most members as one of the facts of political life that an important State election such as that in New South Wales must intrude into the expression of party political views in this House. In some ways it has been a matter of some amusement, as well as concern about the issues which have been raised during the State election campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: However, when those matters continue to be raised on the Thursday after all other electronic media have been silenced with regard to election matters, I believe this House should view with greater seriousness the way in which it regards that ban which applies to other people but not to this place. One of several things obviously can result. If the House is sitting on the Thursday, we can debate matters of State electoral importance. If we do that we will encourage the public outside who may be concerned in the media either to disregard the law or to regard us as less than adequate in making that law. I suggest that Parliament can do one of two things in that regard. Either it can decide not to sit on the Thursday and, therefore, not put the House to some form of public ridicule by itself not having regard to a law it requests all citizens to have regard to, or it can alter that law. In response to the spectacle we saw today, I suggest it is time for the Government to amend the Act to make it lawful in some fashion for the electronic media outside this place to enjoy the same freedoms that we enjoy here.

I have pleasure in supporting the general aspects of the Budget this year. I congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on the continuing thought that he has given to the Australian economy and on his bravery in facing some of the very hard questions within his portfolio. I will make some direct mention of some of the minor things which irritate me. Of course, one would expect any Budget of any party to have some minor irritations because of the very disciplines I have referred to. In the first place, it is encouraging to see that the Government is dealing responsibly with interest rates and the economy in general by having a Budget surplus.

In that regard one need only listen to members of the Opposition today and throughout this general debate to see the total inadequacy of the Australian Labor Party in fronting the proposition that it might be an alternative government. It has learned little, if anything, from the years of the Whitlam Administration. One hoped for the sake of Australia that it might have learned something. One hoped, perhaps for the success of Liberal policies, that it had not. Quite frankly, it has not. Very few honourable members opposite have given any indication of what the source of the increased spending they advocate would be, except the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) who today was brave and honest enough to detail where the money should come from to formulate his democratic socialist program. When one considers the few people who advocate a different and additional source of money for their socialist programs, one finds that they will again destroy the engine of the economy. By the proposals they put up they can only so deter enterprise in this community that we will get back to the Whitlam years of a slack economy, a slack exploration program around the country and a total lack of enterprise in any risk-taking in the community. After all, risk-taking stands behind much of the development we have and only it can provide the jobs which so many opposite prate about.

The imposition of sales tax in the Budget, as the Treasurer has stated, is obviously a major new initiative to broaden the tax base so that at some time in the near future we may be able to get at the income tax disincentives now arising in the community. As the average weekly wage will soon take so many Australians for the first time into the second and higher rate of taxation, we can see how urgent it is that the Government give some attention to this matter. Difficult as it is always to broaden taxation in such a way that it affects every member of the community, nevertheless, it is necessary to effect the reforms that lie in the future for us. The generally consistent approach of the Government to inflation, the determination to present to the Australian community the challenges and alternatives which face it, are again the Budget's essential and laudable attributes.

I suppose the general question in the community with respect to this Budget is how we manage success, because Australia is going through a period of sustained growth. We are not debating the difficulties of depression. We, as a community, are assessing whether we can manage the various conflicting interests who all want to share in that growth. It is interesting again to find that members of the Opposition deal with this problem, as they so often do, from a position of envy and greed and decide that incentives must give way to the proposition that we can give but do not have to produce. This seems to be inherent in their answer to the general proposition of how we deal with the conflicting interest in the community. There is a very real conflict between those who receive and those who provide the revenue for the various welfare and assistance programs with which the Government is involved. This is drawn to the attention of the House in the Budget Papers when pensions and allowances are referred to. I quote this paragraph:

The Government has decided to amend the pension income test provisions to address some of the deficiencies in the law that enable people to deprive themselves of income in order to obtain a pension . . .

We know that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) is facing immense pressures in keeping his budget to something which the economy can generally meet. I applaud his intentions to see that it is administered fairly and without favour. One must recognise, however, that these people who depend on pensions for security in the evening of their lives are not to be treated lightly in the sense that they can be compared with some others in the community who deliberately avoid their contributions by way of income tax or some other tax collection. They are people who often do not understand the workings of the financial structure and take action to protect themselves, often to their own detriment. Nevertheless, they take that action to avoid what they see as an imposition on them by government stricture. Whether or not we like it, there is a rising tide of expectation amongst aged people in this community that we have to contend with if we are to bring any discipline, as has been referred to by the Treasurer, into the administration of the pension schemes. I certainly urge caution.

I make this little specific reference: We must have regard to the fact that no scheme or variety of schemes can completely solve the problem of the fairly widespread deposits held by pensioners in various banks or societies in such a way that they will not bear income and, therefore, depreciate their ability to collect a pension or to hold a health benefit card. For instance, those aged people who know the financial world can deposit their money simply in the value of their home, which is something no government can claim to be income. If a would-be pensioner or a would-be pensioner couple had tens of thousands of dollars spare, they could easily in a sense get rid of it in a non-income producing area by buying a more expensive home. I hope that when the Minister is dealing with this he will be tolerant and recognise that these are people who stand by themselves and are not to be seen, as others often are, as tax avoiders or as people who are anti-social in their attitude to the general community.

Of course, the impact of high interest rates, which the Budget attempts to deal with in the sense that it is a surplus Budget and removes the pressure of government borrowings, from the general economic community also falls very heavily on the State governments. On the debts of the nation, it is interesting that the States basically carry the national debt. They are the ones that have the long term debt which is funded and must be repaid and they are the ones that bear the greatest burden, in governmental terms, of the high interest rates of today. This national debt places pressures on those governments which they meet only by cutting expenditure, increasing taxes or using loan funds for current expenditure. So many State governments are using very significant sums of loan funds which they obtain with the agreement of the Loan Council for current expenditure that it must be a worry that they should be forced into that area of very difficult financing. The States must then pay, as we know, long term interest on that money.

I turn now to some of those matters in recent Government decision making, which I said were of minor note, which were not quite so pleasing. I refer first to one item which seems to stand out in the deliberations of the so-called razor gang. I say quite clearly that the imposition of fees for tertiary education second degrees is a very false economy. It is an economy which is depressing the morale of many, often part time, students taking higher degrees who have assumed larger financial burdens by the very fact that they are older. Many of them are married and have heavy expenses. Yet we now expect them to pay a fee for a second degree. In doing so we are saving very little money on the education budget. If my memory is correct, Federal education expenditure this year will be $2.8 billion. I received a letter from the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) to the effect that he expects to save $8m by imposing tertiary fees for second degrees. It is depressing the morale of those people and it is hurting many individuals in this community who save and scrimp, who believe in a free enterprise system and who are out to improve themselves as well as the economy.

I am concerned also at the rather abrupt ending of the Community Youth Support Scheme. I understand the Minister's determination to offer valuable increased training facilities for the youth of Australia. It is a most commendable proposition. But I believe it is less commendable to terminate so abruptly the CYSS scheme when we have involved so many people voluntarily in the community, as individuals or as firms, in support of CYSS organisations. I believe the advice which has been given to honourable members all over the House and to the Minister shows clearly that many individuals among our young unemployed are not suited to partake of the training schemes, however well we may devise them. Whether or not we approve of the education system that perhaps turned them out in that form, the fact is that they exist and we must take the view that they need assistance. I seriously ask the Minister here-as I have done privately-to take note of that issue. Before the CYSS termination date arrives he should give heart and a future to those involved, perhaps by introducing a new, more efficient scheme under a different method of control, but at least a scheme, so that the people who have been assembled all over Australia voluntarily can go on to give their good work and their hearts to meeting this problem as they have done so freely in the past.

I have previously ventilated in this House by way of a question a matter involving the health scheme which I believe operates most unfairly on more than an insignificant number of Australians. The definition of a disadvantaged person, for the purposes of obtaining a health care card, is set out in the Health Acts Amendment Bill which passed through this House earlier this year. That definition indicates that a person must fill in a form and declare an income. On an assessment of that income he or she either will be given a card or will be denied a card. I have a student in my constituency who relies on some small investments of his own-which he made while he was away from home educating himself-and on the income of his wife. His wife's work is interrupted during the year because of various holidays. The questionnaire which those who are on wages or salaries must fill in requires, for the purposes of adjudicating whether a card will be issued, the person's income in the four weeks immediately prior to the application to be stated. This person came in to see me from the Department of Security office. He said that the previous four weeks salary denied him and his family-he is married with two children-the right to have a health care card, although over the whole year their income was slightly more than $10 a week under the yearly income provided as the qualifying level for the obtaining of a health card. The procedure applied most unfairly. He put this to the officer in the Department of Social Security who said: 'Your wife is going on holiday next month. Wait to apply then'. He came to me and said: 'What sort of a form is this. I happen to support your political party. I am in the third year of my five years of university study. I calculate and budget to the last dollar, yet I have to fill in this form which says that I have to describe my income of the last four weeks, whereas people who are receiving incomes from properties, businesses or self-employment average their incomes over a full year'. Of course the definition of income takes in earnings, sickness or holiday pay, sickness or accident insurance payments and long service leave payments. In a period of four weeks a person might have received a huge payment because of the peculiar way in which these payments arrive in a limited period over a year. I say quite clearly that the Minister must amend that form so that the position is tenable. At the moment I believe something like 100,000 people move in and out of employment every month. Many hundreds of thousands of people in the community, therefore, have a broken income over the year. The procedure is totally untenable for the purpose of finding out whether they are eligible for a most important benefit which could be worth up to $6, $8 or $10 a week-I have forgotten the final figure. Because of that method they are denied the right that people on self-employed incomes have.

I have one further extremely small matter to mention. It is so small that I am doubtful about raising it here at all. I raise it because it is a mean-minded matter. During the parliamentary recess I made inquiries in Parliament House in South Australia as I wanted to find out something from the Ministerial Document Service. The State librarian told me that he is no longer a recipient of that service. The Commonwealth has cancelled the sending of statements from the Ministerial Document Service to State parliamentary libraries. There are six such libraries and each time a document is not sent out we are saving a stamp and an envelope. Every Federal member of parliament gets these documents. I thought that this certainly was an oversight. I wrote to the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) and I received a letter which stated that State parliamentary libraries would not get the service.
