The letter stated that they should take out subscriptions to the Commonwealth Record as a substitute. I do not know whether our new federalism is leading us into a conflict in the library area. I thought perhaps this matter was too small to be involved in. It is so small that it obviously defines and delineates the meanness behind it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every year Budgets arouse the anger of people in all walks of life but this Budget does so more than most. It is a Budget that further divides our community, with divisions on both economic and social lines. The health measures, the termination of tax indexation, the crudely conceived and damaging sales tax measures and the inhumane and incompassionate termination of the Community Youth Support Scheme have met with an outbreak of unprecedented rage in all sections of the community except, of course, from those few privileged friends of the Government. It is a Budget that reasserts obsolete beliefs-beliefs that are not only reminiscent of the nineteenth century but also are socially divisive. Those who are currently the privileged few are the most generously treated in this Budget and those who share the burden of hardship in this society will be required to accept more of the burden. It is as though the Government were looking for measures to reduce the standard of living of the poor and the less affluent of our nation. The regressive nature of these measures will not be as readily forgotten by the electorate as the Government would believe. I think the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) has given notice of the change of the political allegiance of one of his constituents.

SPEECH.PARA: The anger now being displayed will, I believe, persist and ultimately culminate in the destruction of this Government. The true direction of the Government will not be gauged by the pious sentiments of social concern so patronisingly expressed by Government members. Such sentiments are just sugar coating on a very bitter pill. Rather, a more realistic picture of government considerations will be found in the unfeeling dedication to harsh monetarist policies as found in the policy statements of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Budget lines. Ordinary people, the poor, small business people, even the man on the land, will be made to pay the price of this Government's reluctance to test the muscles of its transnational and other powerful friends. It is quite obvious that the coterie of free traders, the current bunch of greedy nouveau riche and the would-be political and economic heavies who adorn the Government back benches have been able to intimidate the Cabinet so that their naive and destructive policies can prevail. But there is no denying the fact that it is the less affluent who will pay the price.

We have witnessed the weeping of volumes of crocodile tears from a number of government members who lamented the imposition of a new range of sales taxes and the increases on other items. Few will be convinced of the sincerity of these lamentations. These members must share the guilt of the Cabinet and the responsibility of decreasing the standard of living of so many Australians. The poor become poorer, difficulties confronting small business become intolerable and the cost squeeze upon these firms will push many of them beyond the threshold of viability.

One example which has been brought to my notice concerns a rapidly developing industry that should be encouraged. I refer to the mineral water industry in Daylesford, Hepburn Springs and Kyneton. Incredibly this acclaimed health giving water is not grouped with soft drinks, yet drinks such as orange juice and other fruit drinks are exempted from sales tax. When considering the concern that this House has shown one way or another in recent times towards problems associated with alcohol, it is a strange aberration that mineral water should be subject to sales tax. I ask the Treasurer to recognise the arbitrariness of the example and to remove what is an absurd anomaly.

I also draw attention to a number of other instances where the Government's sales tax action has created difficulties. I have received letters from many firms and small business people in my electorate of Ballarat protesting about the imposition of new and additional sales taxes. On their behalf I bring their concern to the notice of this House. I exhort the Government to reconsider its ill advised policy before the effects of the taxes result in greater hardship for firms and the employees. You, Mr Deputy Speaker, coming from a rural and provincial area, I think will appreciate the truth of what I am saying. Those people, who come from larger cities where people are more mobile and perhaps where society can withstand the impact of these taxes a little more, will appreciate what I am saying. On their behalf I bring this matter to the notice of the House. Sales tax will impose great hardships on the firms and their employees and hence, of course, upon families. The range of firms concerned is quite dramatic and highlights the degree of dissatisfaction which exists in the electorate and the growing disillusionment which is being felt by many people towards the Government. There is little doubt that many of these people were erstwhile supporters of this Government but they are now recognising that they have been very cynically misused. I assure the house that these people are not longer content to accept the harsh policies of the Government and they have turned against it.

Another matter of grave concern is a breach of principle in that the Government has seen fit to impose a sales tax on books and other printed matter. It has been raised before-certainly it has been brought to my attention in my electorate-and I will bring it to the attention of the house. It has long been a cherished principle that these items be exempt. The reason is obvious. Restricting the dissemination of information and the opportunities for increasing public knowledge has been abhorrent to all governments. I, along with firms in my electorate, such as Hedges and Bell of Maryborough, one of the largest printers of books in Victoria, and the Ballarat Courier, to mention just two of a large number of concerned firms, are alarmed at the implications of this action. I do not wish to impute motives, other than crude opportunism, to the Government. But the alarm has been sounded and it is up to the Government to allay the fears that are aroused. I do not often find myself in total agreement with the Ballarat Courier editorial, but on Saturday 12 September 1981 it hit the spot. The editorial states:
Outside the communist world and other countries controlled by dictatorships, where else but in Australia would you expect to find a tax on the dissemination and exchange of information?
The answer simply is: Nowhere else in the Western world, nowhere in countries where freedom of expression is valued; nowhere in countries where freedom to learn is valued as a right.
It is incredible that this should be so in Australia! In a country with a Federal Government that prides itself in championing the cause of the individual and his or her freedom.

We have our own opinions about that. As we have said, there has never been such a tax in a Western country but our Federal Parliament is now debating a 2.5 per cent sales tax on books, newspapers and magazines. The editorial continues:

Understandably there has been an outcry inside and out of Parliament on a measure that is totally against the public interest. And in that interest it is to be hoped the legislation is rejected or withdrawn.

I hope that will be the case. The article continues but that is the tone of it. This imposition is a matter of grave concern to those people and, I think, all who are interested in the protection of the right of people to the cheapest possible source of information. I suggest that many small country newspapers will find these changes-I have mentioned a number of them-difficult to absorb. On a point of principle and economically, this tax is offensive.

Today the Treasurer quoted figures-I will draw attention to the housing problem-to avoid the obvious charge that housing ownership in Australia was not buoyant. It is estimated that the additional cost of building materials will add $500 to the cost of a very modest house of $20,000. That is extraordinarily modest these days. These additional costs will put paid to the hopes of many young couples to own their own homes. That is obvious. The statistics referred to today by the Treasurer in the House in no way get to the problem that faces individual young people who are trying to gain a house. It is no credit to the Treasurer to try to deny it. It indicates what little understanding he has of the way young people have to watch their budgets. As has been said, it is a very regressive tax. It hurts people on low incomes more than the wealthy. Fewer homes being built means fewer people employed in the building industry. In my electorate activity in the building industry is well below full pace. This will certainly not help it to recover. I am concerned about a healthy economy for provincial cities and small towns.

The reverberations are felt right throughout the entire economy and it suffers. People are being forced out of the private housing market, both through failed hopes and/or bankruptcy. They are being forced to seek public housing. This move will put pressure on rental markets and the Victorian Housing Commission and aggravate the already serious problem. Already in Ballarat alone 350 families are on the list for public housing. This does not account for people in towns such as Maryborough, Kyneton and Daylesford who are waiting for public housing. This is a very serious matter in general terms. But I stress that in rural and provincial areas such as mine it will have disastrous effects on very many people. There is evidence already of reduced building activity. I will cite a case indicating that in a moment. The figures for Victoria show that there are 16,813 applicants for housing commission homes. Some of these people will have to wait five years or more. We can expect that that time span will increase and that the number of applicants will also increase. It is estimated that the number of low income earners living in poverty in private rental accommodation is around 200,000. This surely must shock us out of our complacency and force us to recognise that that must become a top priority for this nation.

I want also to bring to the attention of honourable members the problem of a small business in my electorate. The Government has asserted so often that it is the friend of small business. The managing director of one small business in Ballarat, Eureka Timber Co. Pty Ltd, wrote to me as follows:

I am writing to ask you to do your utmost to have the 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on building materials withdrawn. This sales tax could well be the last straw. The State Electricity Commission has just raised their charges by 20 per cent. The State Government through the Forestry Commission has just raised our royalty rate by 12 1/2 per cent.
It is as though the two governments have combined to destroy the building industry and the sawmilling industry-both very labour intensive industries.

The dream that every young Australian has had in the past of being able to own a house of his or her own may well become just that-a dream, a thing that used to happen but will happen less and less. It cannot even be argued that this move is anti-inflationary. It is obvious that it is close to inflationary.

I ask you most earnestly, along with the 24 men getting their daily bread from this small business, and who want to continue to do so, and not go on the dole, which will be their future if we are taxed out of the market place, to do your utmost, to stop this iniquitous tax from being implemented.

That letter is signed by J. L. Corrigan, the managing director. That is only one of the many letters of that kind which I have received and which I am sure many honourable members, probably mostly from this side of the House, have received. Honourable members can see that that puts paid to the hopes of so many young people.

In the last few moments available to me I want to raise the matter of the Community Youth Support Scheme. Among the many cynical acts of the present Federal Government the abandonment of this scheme must register as one of the most infamous. There is no evidence that the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) has any appreciation of the plight of young people enrolled in CYSS projects across the country. I applaud the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) and so many other honourable members for raising this matter. This is one of the issues which the Government obviously slipped through and thought that no one would notice. These young people are important. They have a right to their own dignity. They have a right to the future. Many of them are kids with problems. Many experience problems of adjustment. They are not necessarily kids to be taken up in projects which the Minister suggests are in the pipeline. He claims that there are training programs for the people. In fact, no more than 5,750 of the places in those programs will suit CYSS participants. Yet, over the period of a year there were something like 62,000 people going through CYSS.

I shall make reference to a number of comments recently published in the Ballarat Courier in which both employers and ex-CYSS participants indicated the value of the work that could be done by a well-run CYSS project. The CYSS projects were successful in spite of the lack of real interest by the Government. They were successful because of the dedication of the people who were in charge and who took an interest in them. They deserve the congratulations of the Australian community.

I have, for instance, some comments from Melanie, who believed that CYSS was good. She said that there was plenty to do, that there were skills to learn and that it helped build up confidence. She said CYSS should definitely be retained. Of course, the Government did not consider the opinions of CYSS participants as having any bearing upon the decision to axe the scheme. Belatedly it says it is interested. We will see. Melanie's employer said that she was an excellent worker and did her job well. He said that he had been considering employing another junior and if he did he would go ahead and approach the CYSS group. Of course, one of the sad state of affairs is that there will be no CYSS any more. Another lass, Sharon, said the worst part of being unemployed was having nothing to do. She said that CYSS helped her to fill that gap. She said it offered her a lot of work experience and skills. She is now working as a teachers aide at McCallum House, which is an institution for the mentally disabled in Ballarat.

It is my belief and the belief of many involved with CYSS in my electorate and certainly the belief of my colleagues that the Federal Government has simply discarded these young people. In Daylesford, Kyneton and Maryborough and other towns that do not face the prospect of any rapid industrial development the plight of these young people will become pitiful. These towns are progressive and they are self-starting. But in the current economic climate they are confronted by a tough task. The young people in these CYSS projects are not readily absorbed into the work force of those towns. With the termination of these projects their fortunes are bleak. I have asked the Victorian Minister responsible for youth affairs, Mr Dixon, to take over the CYSS projects if the Federal Government falls short of its responsibility to these young people. If the Government has even a shred of compassion for these young people and the thousands like them across the nation it must reinstate the CYSS program. Sure, it must review it and update it; any responsible government would do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —And give it more.

—Yes, and admit that it was mistaken. The youth of the country deserve better than to be the victims of this Government's ill-conceived policies. The Government's Budget for 1981-82 is insensitive and inhumane. The protests from the Australian public are loud and clear. It is to be hoped that the Government will rethink the direction it has taken and, in a contrite mood, make the changes so desperately needed to rekindle faith in government lost since it embarked upon its narrowly conceived direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The thrust of this Budget is to contain inflation, to contain wage demands, to ease interest rates, to maintain a steady growth in the private sector and to shift the tax base and provide for reductions in personal taxation in the future. We should note the importance of the last point, which is to shift the tax base. I do not think there is any dispute about these objectives. I am quite sure that, in due course, they will be achieved. Australia has been called, many times, the lucky country. There is no doubt that Australia is one of the strongest and safest countries in the world in terms of our economy, in terms of our currency and in terms of our future prospects. Although things can always be better, I do not think we should forget how good they are in this country for most people.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish in the time allowed to comment on certain aspects of the Budget. I will be critical of some and in favour of others. Whilst I am critical of some aspects I recognise that the Budget strategy is based on a complete package of decisions and to change any of those decisions would be to erode that strategy. I hope that the comments I make will be taken into account in the near future. I turn firstly to sales tax. The sales tax proposals have attracted a great deal of criticism. No one wants to see himself or his business adversely affected by these proposals. There is certain justification in criticising some of the items which will be subjected to sales tax. I refer in particular to clothing and footwear, commercial boats and items connected with the building industry. I agree with some of that criticism. I would prefer to see the sales tax concentrated on what might be called more luxurious items because it is difficult for low income earners to cope with this extra burden. There are others in the community in the higher income brackets who are much better placed to cope with this impost. I view with some alarm the imposition of sales tax on commercial boats because it concerns people who have contracted forward to take delivery of a boat. I am very sceptical of the retrospectivity provisions in relation to sales tax. I am also critical of sales tax being imposed on items in the building industry. This industry is vital to our economy. This impost, coming as it does on top of the high interest rates, will affect many home buyers as well as the people who are in the building industry.

I wish to say a few words about the pensioners in our community. I am very disappointed about the way in which they have been treated. We are constantly told that the aged in our community are becoming an increasing welfare burden within the terms of the Budget. Whilst that might be true I point out that it is not exactly the fault of those people that they are getting old and it is not exactly their fault that there are more of them. I fully agree with the Government's desire to move against the blatant schemes in which some pensioners are indulging. I hope that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) will move with sympathy and understanding. I would like to see him catch those people who are manipulating the system. I point out that we have indexation of pensions but that we do not have indexation of the extra income allowed to pensioners which for a single pensioner is limited now to $20 and for those who want a health card is limited to $40. Neither of these limits has moved for some years. The problem is that almost everything else is indexed, whether it be pensions or wages. We have here two static benchmarks that have not moved for some years. I believe that this is unjust.

Pensioners with limited means are getting very angry, and I do not blame them. Let me give an example. For every dollar that a pensioner earns over the $20 upper income limit he loses 50c out of his pension. By earning $14 a week extra a pensioner moves into the tax bracket of 32c in the dollar. When he earns $21 he loses not only 50c out of his pension but also, if he is in the lower income bracket, another 32c in tax. The fact is that out of $1 he retains something like 18c. I ask whether that is considered to be fair. If the $20 limit was considered good enough in 1972 I think the figure that is considered good enough in 1981 should be somewhat higher. I fully support the principle of not giving the old age pension to those who do not need it but in the process let us not further disadvantage those who have a genuine need. I and many other members of this House will be watching with great interest to see the proposals brought forward by the Minister in the next few weeks.

I deal now with aged persons homes. I am very pleased to see that an extra $12m has been allocated for this purpose in this year's Budget. It brings the total allocation for this item to $58m. One of the problems I have in my area concerns the fact that we form part of the Moreton South region in terms of nursing beds. That region works on a basis of providing something like 50 beds for every 1,000 people over 65 years of age. On the basis of that figure my area is disadvantaged to the extent of some 900 beds. We have 900 beds; on that formula there should be another 900 beds. I make a plea that the formula and the regional boundaries be revised so that people in my area, which could be regarded as a high age area, are given a fair go.

One of the other problems which I wish to mention concerns Telecom Australia. I see that the interest rate paid by Telecom to the Government is to be increased. The problem is that the Gold Coast area is a large growth area and Telecom has not been able to provide the infrastructure to keep up with that growth. I ask that Telecom sort out its priorities so that in 1981 it is not considered an extraordinary request to ask Telecom to put on a telephone. I must say that the local office of Telecom has been doing its best. I say also, with some degree of satisfacton, that the problem looks like being overcome within the next six months.

Mention has been made of the Community Youth Support Scheme. I agree with what people have said since I have been in the chamber over the last hour or so. In Queensland generally, and in my area in particular, this has been an excellent scheme. The three centres in my area have been good and I will be sorry to see them go. Overall the scheme has not been a success and the Government has determined that it will change the thrust of training for young people. To that effect a considerable amount of money has been allocated in the Budget to the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. The amount has increased, in fact, by 22 per cent to $203m. The allocation of trade training is $76m. The allocations for skills training and youth training have gone up. Some 235,000 people will be assisted under these programs. I agree with the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) and others who have said that these programs will not cater for everyone who has been part of CYSS. I tend to think that this is true. I will wait with interest to see the outcome of the investigations now being made by the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. I take this opportunity to thank publicly all those who have been associated with the CYSS centres in my area.

With some regret I must say that I believe that the States are not getting a fair share of road funds. We live in a largely decentralised country with a huge road problem. The problem is that the amount of money going to the States is barely enough to maintain those roads, let alone improve them. On a more positive side I am particularly pleased that defence spending is to rise in real terms by over 5 per cent. It is very easy to say, as many people do, that there is no threat to Australia. It is very difficult right now to identify any threat but it is there. It becomes more pertinent to talk about a threat if our defences are run down. If a very high level of professionalism in the defence forces is not maintained, men will be lost. Unfortunately, that has happened in past years. Once the defence forces run down it takes a long time to build them up. I am very glad to see that the defence forces budget has been increased substantially this year.

Turning to education, I am afraid that I cannot agree with my colleague the honourable member for Boothby that the introduction of fees for universities is a poor thing. I fully support the Government in the action it took before the Budget, although it is a budgetary matter. I am particularly glad to see that step being taken because, if there is only so much money to go around, I want to see more of it going into technical and trade training. In particular, I want to see a situation where a young person who qualifies at school for university can go there and get a first degree free. At the same time, there are hundreds and thousands of our young people who do not want to follow the pure academic trend and who want to get a trade. I want to see a situation where these young people do not have to go around, cap in hand, trying to find an employer to take them on. I want to see those who qualify being able to go to the local technical college and get a trade in the same way as their colleagues can go to a university and get a first degree. I believe it is very important that that opportunity be given to people. I do not for one moment hold with the theory that one can get a trade only on the job. Some of the most sought after apprentices in Australia have gone through trade training schools in the Services, where most of the training is college-based.

On the question of foreign aid, it is pleasing to see that the Government has increased the percentage of gross domestic product to foreign aid. There has been a lot of criticism about this, particularly in my home State of Queensland. The fact is that it is a very modest figure. As a middle ranking power in the world we have responsibilities to those who are less fortunate. I fully support that move. On the subject of veterans' affairs, the fact that merchant mariners who served in war theatres have now been brought in out of the cold, so to speak, has been a major success of this Budget. They have been out there since 1945. There has been some degree of criticism as to whether they should be in or out and that is what has delayed this move. On balance, I believe they should be in, and that is where they are now. Another important budgetary measure is the granting of disability pensions to the Papua New Guinea constabulary. It can be argued that they should be paid out of our large foreign aid grants to Papua New Guinea, and that might be a valid arguement. Nevertheless, I am delighted to see that these pensions have been granted because I do not think what Australia owes to the people who served in that constabulary during World War II should ever be forgotten.

I turn now to the question of personal taxation. The fact is-I think it is freely admitted on both sides of this House-that it is far too high. It is destroying incentive; it is destroying people's will and capacity to work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that true of Europe too, where the levels of taxation are so much higher?

—I am talking about Australia. The fact is that it is also encouraging higher wage demands. Perhaps my friend will care to answer that later on. Pay-as-you-earn receipts during the coming year will increase by 22 per cent. Unfortunately, to some degree we are hitting those whom we are also hitting with sales tax. To date there has been no trade-off in terms of reductions in personal tax. Too many people are approaching the 46 per cent tax bracket. The average weekly earning is now something like $300 a week. If it goes up by 10 per cent it will move into the second tax bracket. The Treasury estimate of wage rises this year is something like 13.5 per cent. I ask: Is there any justice in this when one is paying almost half one's salary into a tax system? On several occasions the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has said that the personal tax system is to be revised. We look forward to that.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the other problems associated with tax, although not personal tax, concerns the plight of private companies in Australia. As we all know, they are obliged by legislation to distribute something like 40 per cent of their profits. This simply means that no private company can expand. We should be encouraging them, not discouraging them, to take in their families as partners and expand their businesses. As it is, just about all of them remain static or fold or, more to the point, are taken over. When the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System is brought down, I ask the Treasurer, to have a good look at the matter, in conjunction with another important matter I wish to raise, double taxation on small shareholders. One of the previous speakers-I think it was the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly)-was talking about Trust Australia. I fully support his views on this matter. I am well aware that in some ways what I have been advocating is more spending in terms of pensioners, et cetera, and that it could be asked where we will make the cuts. I am talking about reassessing some of our priorities within the Budget. I fully support the move to indirect taxes. I look forward to seeing the other half of this contract, that is, reduction in personal tax.

In conclusion, I reiterate that I believe we have a strong economy-probably one of the strongest, if not the strongest, in the world. Wages have risen in real terms by some 4 per cent over the last 12 months. Investment has increased by 20 per cent and inflation is contained at 8.8 per cent. That is the way we want to keep it. Overseas money is coming in, and the Labor Party has been extremely critical about this overseas capital and where it is going. I ask, and I have not had an answer to this question, where we would be if this overseas capital did not come in. The fact is that if it were not here, the pressure on our domestic money market would be much greater. As it stands, it appears that interest rates have peaked, and that is part of the Budget strategy. There will be no development in this country without confidence, and confidence requires stability. The Budget plans for stability, and in that way and because of that I fully support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: — From the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) down, this Government has sought, in explaining the 1981-82 Budget, to justify it on the grounds of small government. The evidence is that the rhetoric and ideology highlight the fact that the closest the Fraser Cabinet has come to small government is in the small-minded decisions that have been taken. The Australian public has been bombarded with rhetoric by the Prime Minister for over six years. On many occasions he has been guilty of saying one thing and doing the opposite. The reality is that the latest Budget will not reduce overall costs to the community. In fact, the opposite will be the case. We all remember the words of the Prime Minister: 'People will be free to decide how they will spend their money. We will reduce taxation. People should be free to decide how they will spend their money rather than having the Government take the decisions for them through heavier taxation burdens.' They are great words, but what are the facts? Have taxes been reduced? Have Australians more money to spend? The only way those questions can be answered with a yes is if one is already a wealthy member of our society, but this is not so with average Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: For the term of the Fraser Government there has been a marked redistribution of wealth from the poor to the wealthy. For average Australians taxes under this Government are rising faster than income. Pay-as-you-earn taxpayers contributed 16.1 per cent more tax last year than in the year before, when they paid 17 per cent more than in the year before that. This Budget estimates that the rise will continue unabated. The increase in 1981-82 will be 22 per cent. On top of this, sales tax increases will cost the public $892m. Taxes under Fraser are now equal to 28.8 per cent of gross domestic product.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will refer to the Prime Minister as such.

—Taxes under Mr Fraser, the Prime Minister, are now equal to 28.8 per cent of gross domestic product. This is the same Government which thundered about high taxes in the Whitlam years. Under Whitlam, taxes as a proportion of gross domestic product were 24 1/2 per cent. I refer to a speech made in this House by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) on 27 August. He referred to figures of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the simple question of revenue from taxes as a proportion of gross domestic product for the OECD countries. One will see that Australia's revenue from taxes in 1978 is listed as totalling 28.8 per cent of gross domestic product.

He compared Australia with countries such as Canada with a figure of 31 per cent, France with 39 per cent, Germany with almost 38 per cent and the Netherlands with 46 per cent, to justify the claim that the Fraser Government is a low taxing government. Even though Government supporters claim that in the Whitlam years taxes were high, the figures I have cited show that the present Government's rate of taxation as a proportion of gross domestic product is much higher than it ever was under the Whitlam Government. Who will be the beneficiaries of this Budget and the money that is being collected? The first and major recipients will be members of the Fraser Cabinet, who see this Budget as the gateway to the 1983 election. The domestic surplus of $1,500m is aimed at slugging the community now in order to reduce taxes and offer election incentives in the future. Why should I believe that? The Treasurer (Mr Howard) admitted as much in his Budget Speech. He said:
Some of the new revenue proposals will help broaden the tax base and this will enhance the potential for further personal tax relief in future years.

How absolutely cynical can one get. The Treasurer referred to 'the potential for further personal tax relief'. For the whole period of the Fraser Government personal taxes have continued to rise. There is no such thing as further relief; relief has not even started. Personal taxes increased by 17 per cent in 1979-80, 16 per cent in 1980-81 and 22 per cent in 1981-82. When is there to be any personal tax relief as promised in the rhetoric of this dishonest and deceitful Government? How ignorant does this Government believe the public is? In the very next paragraph of the Treasurer's speech he again showed how cynical the Government is. He said:
In addition to measures to contain expenditure and broaden the tax base, the Government is continuing its efforts to stamp out tax avoidance.

How hollow is this statement when the Budget Papers show that the enforcement section of the Australian Taxation Office will decline by 179 officers. The enforcement section is concerned with tax evasion, the understatement of income and the new lodgment of returns. On 20 May of this year the Treasurer told Parliament that the amount of tax outstanding at the end of 1979-80 from taxpayers participating in avoidance schemes was $711m compared with $433m for 1978-79 and $158m for the year before. Clearly the amounts outstanding have been increasing, yet this Government is cutting staff in the taxation enforcement area. I quote again from the Treasurer's speech. He said:
The Government is continuing its efforts to stamp out tax avoidance.

Does this statement equate with a cut in the availability of enforcement officers? Just how sincere is this Government? The evidence is that whilst it believes it can milk honest Australians dry with tax increases, tax avoiders have little to fear from this Government. I will spend a little time on the Budget strategy. Not too many people are clear as to what the strategy is, least of all Government members opposite. I refer to the speech by the pretender to the leadership of the Liberal Party, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). He was not very praiseworthy of the Budget. He said:

. . . the burden of its achievement will fall most heavily on those least able to afford it-such as young families wishing to purchase their first home and families with low earned incomes or statutory incomes. The average family has been faced in the past 12 months with increasing taxes and charges on all fronts-higher interest rates, higher petrol prices, higher health charges and now higher sales tax across the board with little or no compensating increase in real disposable income.

This Budget is designed to increase taxes and charges at a faster rate than the growth in government spending. Clearly, many members on the Government side believe that. In simple terms the Government will collect $1,500m more in taxes from the people of Australia than it intends to spend. Many of them will be knocking off work now. They probably collected their pay today and looked at how much tax they paid. The Government is taking a percentage that it does not intend to spend. At this point it is worth reconsidering the Prime Minister's words which I quoted at the beginning of my speech. He said:
People should be free to decide how they will spend their money rather than having the Government take the decision for them through heavier taxation burdens.

What better way can that be illustrated than by what the Government is doing at present? This Budget has introduced a new element-savings through the public sector by conscription. A Budget surplus is in reality a means of banking funds on behalf of taxpayers. How hypocritical can the Government be? In reality the Government is increasing taxes and charges and adding insult to injury by putting the money it is collecting into consolidated revenue and reducing public services. How much do average Australians have to suffer to make room in this country for foreign investors? That is something this Government has been saying for four or five years. According to the monetarists, a domestic surplus is important to reduce the pressure on interest rates. However, in the year just concluded a domestic surplus of $400m was achieved. Interest rates have never been higher and families have never been worse off.

The effect of this Budget strategy will be to draw millions of dollars from the community expenditure stream, creating unnecessary hardship. For what? Is not the thrust of the Budget to bring the money supply under control? Why attack average Australians? The Budget is still being debated in this House. Already we have seen a change of direction in the Government's strategy. The Reserve Bank of Australia has given a direction to banks to lend another $900m. In the Prime Minister's own words, would it not have been much better for ordinary Australians not to have had these taxes imposed upon them so that they could have kept their interest free money in their own pockets and spent it as they chose, rather than a direction being given by the Government a couple of weeks after the Budget was brought down for the banks to lend the same money with interest? Who will get the money? Who will spend it? It will not be the ordinary person who has paid his tax today out of his pay cheque. Those who can afford to go to the bank and pay high rates of interest will be able to use that money. The Government is effectively taking it from the poor, transferring it to the banks and allowing them to lend it to other people who can afford to borrow it.

Is there an alternative? I say there is. Why not control the inflow of speculative capital that has brought the Government to this position? It has made decisions and has had to change them even before the Budget has been passed. The failure to control speculative money is putting pressures on the economy which will jeopardise many industries. Clearly, when investment spending is the major pressure point in the economy investment allowances and subsidies should be readjusted and abolished in many industries. I refer to pages 17 and 18 of the ministerial statement on the report of the razor gang. Dealing with investment allowances and taxation concessions, the statement read:

Taxation concessions for industry, which are equivalent in all practical senses to direct expenditures from the Budget, have also been reviewed and we have decided to reduce a number of currently available concessions.
This section is only a small part of the whole document. It continued:

The Government . . . believes that some reductions in the level of taxation concessions available to industry are essential if the burden of containing the public sector is to be shared by all groups in the community.

Let us look at the areas where industry is to take part of the burden. I refer to an article by Mr Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association. He said that this was the worst Budget in 34 years. The article stated:

When Sir Phillip Lynch's committee was appointed, it was to cut waste and duplications from government functions. Legislation-by-reporting as a means of making tax increases wasn't what it was all about.
Apart from broken promises, one change is ridiculous and not worth doing! Things like the Investment Allowance were trimmed from 20 per cent to 18 per cent, and effective immediately.

As for one depreciation change: Frankly it would be simply a giggle if it didn't have costly implications-not in the amount of tax involved (because that's chicken-feed) but in the amount of work involved for taxpayers and the Taxation Office. Depreciation schedules will now be up to three-times larger than before, and that waste in time and effort will continue for 10 to 15 years.
Did the so-called Razor Gang ear-mark some money saved, to give it to the Taxation Office for extra assessors and more storage space?

Mr Risstrom said that it should have. But we know from the Budget Papers that the opposite is the case. There are fewer taxation assessors. Mr Risstrom then gives an example of what was adopted. He says:
Only last August, in the 1980 Budget, depreciation rates were lifted by one-fifth to allow for obsolescence, but over the life of the item there's no more tax saved, and no long-term revenue cost.

That 1/5th adjustment has been cut back to (wait for it) 18/100ths, and you'll be 'fair tickled' to learn that the 13.5 per cent rate is to be precisely 13.275 per cent. What does such a big and important cost-cutting change mean?
He then gives this example:
A manufacturer buys a lathe for $5,000 mid-year; its a 5 per cent prime-cost item. An 1/5th-up rate of 6 per cent would allow depreciation if $150, but with a grand stroke--
That is, by this Government-
that's down to 5.9 per cent (18/100ths onto 5 per cent): the claim drops to $148!
For a company, it means extra tax of less than $1 a year! And a sole trader (income of less than $18,000) will pay 64 cents extra tax for the year.

Mr Risstrom said: 'Frankly that fiddling little change is ludicrous'. I totally agree with him. Let me quote the alternative. Let me quote again the words of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden). In his reply to the Budget Speech he put the case on behalf of Australians and his words should be repeated. He said:

A balanced domestic budget, or even a mild deficit, is what is required at this time. Certainly, the economy can afford it and it would be consistent with falling inflation, lower interest rates, and sustained growth of 5 per cent, provided controls are imposed immediately on short term speculative money from overseas. That is, we are talking about making domestic economic activity by Australians by allowing money to be made available to them rather than foreign carpetbaggers speculating in real estate, shares and in Australian industry to the detriment of Australians' welfare and security.
We would immediately abandon the proposed sales tax increases. This would leave $550m in family pay packets to go into consumer spending.

How true that is today. Already the Government has decided to allow the banks to put that money back into the system after this Government has taken it out of the people's taxes and to lend it back to the wealthy who can afford to borrow it. That is a great sort of policy, that is. The Australian Labor Party would not be afraid to protect the assets of Australians. The Leader of the Opposition has indicated clearly that an alternative approach is available, and it is certainly practical.
Let us look at some of the indirect effects of this Budget. I again quote from the speech of the former Minister for Industrial Relations, the honourable member for Kooyong. He had this to say:
It is important that government economic policies allow for progressive improvement of the economy without excessive expansion or excessive contraction.
He is having a go at the Government again. He went on to say:

An economically efficient and socially humane approach to management of the national economy involves smooth and timely changes of gear. Flexibility is, of course, essential but it should not be at the expense of the stability people hope to find in Liberal as opposed to Labor Party management.
I am pleased to see that he put in the words 'hope to find'. People are not finding it at present. He went on to say:
Not only businessmen but all Australians need to be able to rely on a degree of certainty and predictability in Liberal government policy-making.
Criticism again. Who is supporting this Government? Do we have two governments sitting on the government benches at the moment? The honourable member for Kooyong continued:
State governments would also appreciate some predictability and stability at the national level.
Too right State governments are looking for a bit better deal than they are getting at present. He went on:
As they assume greater responsibilities that were previously acknowledged by the Commonwealth Government, the States are looking for-and should receive-more room to move.

Of course they should receive more room to move. But what have they got from this Government? They have got nothing but the squeeze from this Government. We all saw the farce of the Premiers Conferences. There is no doubt that this Government is divided, very divided, over this Budget and the methods that have been used in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is wrong.

—I have just gone through what the honourable member for Kooyong said. In one little part of his speech he made four or five solid criticisms of the Government, but of course he did not mention how to achieve his call for small government. The honourable member for Kooyong left it at that after discussing the fact that the States are being squeezed. Let me expand on his words in that regard. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . payments to the States will increase by only 8.2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite enough.
—He said:

SPEECH.PARA: This is despite a transfer of functions to the States and curtailment of their borrowing capacity.

'Quite enough', says the honourable member for North Sydney. But who will have to provide the extra funds? Having already provided $1,500m to the Federal Government, which the Government does not intend to spend, average Australians will have to pay again in increased State charges. One only has to look at the State Electricity Commission in Victoria to see what has gone on. I quote an article in the Age of 19 August. Mr Trethowan, the Chairman of the SEC, is reported as saying this:
Our capital works programme this year is worth $620 million, but the Federal Government gave us the right to borrow only $308 million and that left us to find an extra $312 million.
We've racked our brains to find ways of doing it, but we have been forced to increase our tariffs to meet the shortfall.

In other words, this Federal Government has forced the State governments once again to hit those people who are paying all the time. The State Government of Victoria has brought down a Budget which, because of the policies of the Federal Government, is estimated to cost families in that State an extra $7 a week. No doubt the pressures of this Government will be felt all over the country.

In conclusion, let met look at a couple of small points. There are groups in this community who have been completely ignored, such as the Community Youth Support Scheme groups and the young people in those groups. Many honourable members have mentioned that something should be done about it, but this Government is sitting pat. I hope that pressure brought to bear before the end of October will ensure that something will be done for these people. Another matter I want to raise in the minute I have left concerns the blind and the blind day centres. At the moment, people in Victoria are working and trying to raise money towards putting in day centres to which blind people can be brought and trained. This Government has completely ignored that area. The Act concerning those centres was brought into this House by the Whitlam Government and the fact that the Act needs amending has been put to this Government many times, but the Government has totally ignored that fact for the six years it has been in office. I urge this Government to take a really good look at where it is spending its money and to amend that legislation and to make funds available to those people who are trying to help the blind in our community so that they can have some of the facilities required to rehabilitate them back into the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, before I commence my remarks on the Budget, I draw attention to the fact that your very worthy predecessor, a much loved member of this House, is in the chamber. Sometimes when I visualise him in that chair I get a warm and comfortable feeling, but other times I shudder with apprehension. If I do not point to one other matter tonight, the matter I will discuss will have well merited the particular slot I have in this Budget debate. It is the matter of zone allowances, or the revision of them. The people of Queensland, other than perhaps those who live in the metropolitan area, have always been concerned about the manner in which the zone allowance boundaries were first established and then, over a period, how the particular advantage in those areas was whittled away to a point where it was not of any great significance. So over the years we had hoped, and prayed a little perhaps, that someone might be aware of the disadvantages which exist as one gets further from the more populated, the more favoured, areas. Then came the news that there was to be an inquiry to revise the whole system of zone allowances.

SPEECH.PARA: People who live beyond the great metropolitan areas, particularly those in my State, became fired with a hope that through this instrumentality we would have the opportunity of exposing to all those concerned-not just the Government but also those living in more favoured areas-the very grave and continuing difficulties we have to contend with. They are very profound problems. For example, we put up with temperatures of between 90 degrees and 100 degrees. Not so long ago it was said that Europeans could not live in such conditions. I do not know whether it was thought that non-Europeans were inferior. If it was, thank God it is a thing of the past-or I hope it is. That was the attitude towards such climatic conditions. But we live in them; we tolerate them.

Let me now compare the costs of ordinary commodities sold in Brisbane with those sold in a town called Richmond. Why do I choose Richmond? I could have chosen any town. It is quite remarkable how much one has to pay when one gets 100 miles away from the city. For example, a 67 kilogram bag of flour, which may be used to make bread or pumpkin scones, cost $20 in Brisbane, or so I am led to believe. In Richmond it costs $27.68. That is 30 per cent more. Let us look at the price of a bag of cement, a fundamental requirement. If one wants to build houses, roads or curbing and channelling a bag of cement is very important. For a bag of cement in Townsville-closer to the isolated areas-one pays $62 but in Richmond a person pays an extra $55. Would honourable members believe that? I could go on and on. With the present price competition a motorist pays 33c or 34c a litre for petrol in Brisbane. The price in isolated areas is 42c to 45c. This illustrates the increasing difficulties in which people have to live and survive in isolated areas.

Along came the great deal. Because of great concern a committee of inquiry was established to examine all these conditions. We hoped that at long last a committee of people who should have a desire to appreciate these conditions would put in a report which at least drew attention to the difficulties. But what happened? I am supremely confident that the Government will do as it did with the recommendations in regard to general aviation, and toss any findings straight into the wastepaper basket. Except for a very few recommendations, most of the findings of that committee of inquiry are totally unreal and, if anything, would further penalise the people of the inland if implemented. For example, the city of Mount Isa, because it has more than 25,000 people, goes into another category and the people lose whatever advantages they had. Being reclassified from Zone A to zone B means a loss of all advantages. Fancy telling a group of miners who slave underground, a group of people who live in the most shocking conditions, that the result of the inquiry is that they may be further penalised. I again say that I am supremely confident that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony), and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) will have no part in these recommendations and will put them where they belong-in the wastepaper basket.

I now refer to a terribly important subject. One may say: 'What has the beef industry got to do with the Budget?' Just take the beef industry away from the Budget and have a look at the balance sheet. The beef industry is worth about $1 billion to this country. Some sneaky, criminal types decided to put over a bit of a lurk. Somewhere along the line of distribution they decided to sneak in some horse meat, and perhaps a few pieces of kangaroo meat here and there. It was not just a matter of the money that was involved. It was a matter of discrediting this country in the eyes of the greatest and most substantial friend we have on earth, the United States. I had the advantage last week of discussing these matters in Washington with Gardiner Murray, our veterinarian attache. I also had the advantage of talking to a fellow named Burton Eller, who was the senior vice-president of the National Cattlemen's Association. I was quite amazed at the reaction of the American Cattlemen's Association. I thought they would be jumping with glee. As I said to Burton Eller, I thought that, of all people, members of the Cattlemen's Association would be saying to themselves: 'This is the end of the threat we have from the thousands of tonnes of Australian beef that come into this country'. Their attitude was entirely different. They explained it by saying: 'We provide the more prime cuts; you people provide the sort of beef that is used for our hamburger chains'. But I could not find a hamburger chain that was not, in a subtle way, indicating that it would not have any part of Australian beef. That sort of thing happened with Wendy's-that is a hamburger group, by the way; do not misunderstand me-Jack in the Box, Burger King and McDonalds. They all had a sign exhibited to this effect: 'We provide only American domestic beef'. Their message was loud and clear. I got into a bus one day wearing a broad brimmed hat, and the driver said: 'Where are you from?' I said: 'I am from Australia'. He said: 'You must be a horse breeder'. My reply to him would have done credit to any bullock driver way back in the old days.

I said to Burton Eller: 'Obviously we will have a tapering-off of our trade'. He is the spokesman for the most powerful group of cattle breeders in the United States. He said: 'No, I do not think there will be. There might be a temporary recession but, in any case, I think your beef will be re-channelled from the chains of hamburgers shops and go into the supermarkets-and ABC and so on'. It would seem that we have overcome what could have been a great difficulty. But our people and people such as Burton Eller said: 'For Heaven's sake, get whoever is responsible and make an example of him'. As far as I am concerned, such people should be eliminated from the industry for ever and a day and never again be permitted to have any part of the beef cattle industry. They should be penalised to the new letter of the law. Let us revise the Act before we deal with them. Give them the greatest penalty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put them in gaol.

—Put them in gaol, as my colleague said. Japan is beginning to rethink the situation and there are other markets in the world that we hope to have, such as Egypt. We should let everybody know that we have discovered these people and that we are dealing with them.

SPEECH.PARA: I now speak on a matter that has been mentioned in this House time and again; that is, the Community Youth Support Scheme. My discussions with the Government indicate that it is fairly determined to terminate the operations of the CYSS. As far as my local branch is concerned-I suppose we all think in terms of our local people-I must do nothing but thank the officers for the hard work which they have done and which they continue to do in the hope that the Scheme might continue. I share that hope.

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be better schemes, I think.

—That is what I think. As my honourable friend says, there will be better schemes. I think the people of my area and throughout the State of Queensland and elsewhere are beginning to realise that the Government did not set out just to wreck something that might have been going along well but, rather, to provide something that might operate even better. I hope that is the case. I must say that the people in my area-I pay tribute to a fellow called Ray Tuck and his team who have done a damn good job-hope that it continues. I share their hope. But let us hope that something even better can come out of it.

SPEECH.PARA: As my friend on my left, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton), realises, we have a very serious problem in relation to the defence of this country. I must commend the Government for the increased funding of defence. It is considerable; it is tremendously helpful. I am sure it has had a big effect on the morale of the three branches of the Service. So far, so good. But I say, with the greatest sense of responsibility, that I had the advantage of discussions with the Chairman of the United States Senate Armed Services Committee, a fellow named Senator John Tower, and another gentleman named Melvin Price, who was the Chairman of the House of Representatives Armed Services Committee, and various other people. I thank the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) who helped me tremendously in arranging these discussions. The discussions were helpful and dealt with niceties and the exchange of goodwill and so on. But the discussions that really mattered were held in Hawaii. My goodness, one has to look at a map to realise, as I must confess I did not, that the Pacific Basin encompasses such a huge and significant area. In Hawaii I had the great advantage of talking to Admiral Long who is Commander-in-Chief not only of the huge Pacific area but also of the Indian Ocean and beyond. We talked about Baluchistan, about the Arabian Gulf and about other matters. It was a long briefing. He had assembled other people; for example, Rear Admiral Chewning who is in charge of planning.

This briefing went on for many hours. Out of it emerged some fairly sobering thoughts. The Soviet Union regards its intrusion and its ambitions in the Pacific and Indian Ocean areas so highly that it has established a command headquarters in Siberia which is every bit the equal of the Warsaw command headquarters. Prowling around at this moment in the Pacific Ocean would be not less than 30 fully-armed, modern, new generation submarines, and the same number would be in the Indian Ocean. The Soviet Union has the most modern aircraft possible scattered around the area at various bases which it has obtained either through satellite countries or under the guise of having an alliance with some country or another. It has increased its ground forces by 300 per cent. So there is this huge preponderance of mighty strength distributed through the Pacific and Indian Ocean areas. But we say to ourselves: 'Perhaps we will allow the Americans to put a few B52s into this country'. I am speaking as an individual now and not as Chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, because that Committee has a bipartisan distribution of views on this matter.

My personal view, having heard the evidence I heard over the last week or 10 days, is that if we are not going to have a country such as the United States poised in a suitable strategic position to help us in case of an emergency, who in God's name are we going to have? Is it better to be red than dead or is it better to be dead than red? We can take our pick. I think everyone in this chamber at the moment would not hesitate to make the choice. We are totally dependent on an ally, but we are saying to that ally: 'We will allow you to bring in a few B52s and to do the occasional surveillance trip over the Indian Ocean, but for heaven's sake do not bring any arms or anything that will threaten those poor Soviet submarines that are prowling around the oceans. Hands off them'. We have to be realistic. Hang it all, we have to forget our politics in this thing, become completely united and face up to a threat which is there and which is increasing in its intensity.

I turn now to an entirely different subject-the funding of the film industry. I go from a very sober contribution to this debate to one with perhaps a little more levity. While I was in New York I saw in the New York Times a full page advertisement telling the people of New York that because of the demand to see a film called Gallipoli it would be screened 24 hours a day. The advertisement was not in the other New York newspaper, which would have been more understandable because, after all, Mr Murdoch did have something to do with the making of the film. I believe it is the first time in New York that a film has been screened 24 hours a day to allow the people who want to see it to do so.

Late one night I sat up and watched a discussion panel made up of people associated with culture in various ways-film making, music, other arts and so on. The film representative said: 'We have some very good films around at the moment, but we have one that is outstanding and has everything. It is far superior to anything we have seen for a long time. It is a movie called Breaker Morant'. Honourable members can imagine how I felt, having had a little to do with the film industry, not so much as a star but as a person who ran a theatre for some time. I really glowed with pride.

I have a quick word now about two extremely important matters. I think the quicker the Government gets our domestic satellite up the better. Far too many people associated with strategic industries are scattered throughout the nation and have never seen even a test pattern; I imagine that many of then have never seen television. The satellite has to go up sooner or later. We can find money for lots of things; there are not so many millions involved. I think the whole thing should be accelerated not only to provide television for people who are scattered throughout the nation but also to provide defence, weather forecasts and communications. It would mean we would go into a completely new era. I appeal to the Government to try to isolate certain funds-surely it can be done-to provide a domestic satellite.

I turn now to roads. We are told that the Government is doing everything humanly possible, but the vote is not what it would be. Let me tell the House, as one who chairs a committee which watches local government throughout this country, that we will soon get to a situation in which roads will be crumbling. It will be not just a matter of building new roads but of maintaining what we have.

TALK.START.PARA: —We cannot maintain the one we have now.

—Absolutely. Why can we not think in terms of toll roads? I wish the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) were in the chamber now because he agrees with me on this. I am sure the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore), who is at the table, would agree with me that he and I can perhaps make the sacrifice, every time we drive to the Gold Coast, of paying a toll of 50c or $1. The Government would pick up millions of dollars and the toll would not affect one iota those people who pay it. Let us think in terms of putting a toll on the use of such roads or of some other means of raising the extra money required to sustain and maintain arterial roads which are there not for pleasure but to sustain the great industries of this country.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis). It is not my intention tonight to engage the Government in a debate on economic policy. The Government's assessment of the performance of the economy in its Budget strategy has been very effectively criticised by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and other speakers on this side of the House. I want to talk about some of the forgotten people, people who could have expected better from a Budget with a $1.5 billion surplus and who will be appallingly damaged by the Government's new and increased taxes on basic necessities and its failure to index fully taxable incomes. The Government's strategy is to hammer hard low and middle income earners in this Budget and offer them relief as an election approaches. The Government's eye is on the aggregated electoral behaviour in the future and not on what is happening to individuals now.

SPEECH.PARA: The swinging voter, this Government assumes, is somewhere around the median income range and, therefore, will be able to survive the depredations of the strategy with a little belt tightening and will respond favourably later on to permission to loosen that belt an inch or two in the Budgets of the next year or two. The problem is that the real life experience of Australians does not always conform to the aggregated average. Rising interest rates on housing loans catch individual families who may at this time be confronting educational expenses associated with children just commencing schooling, and new family expenses associated with sales tax on children's clothing. While some members of the community could absorb an additional $8 to $12 a week in mortgage rates and $5 a week in sales taxes, a large number of families on the margin will be pushed beyond their personal earning capacities and be forced, if they have mortgages over their houses, to become tenants in what was once their family home.

For the families in this position the effect of the Budget will be catastrophic now and recovery will not be possible in a year or two when the Government is in a more generous mood. They may never again be able to borrow to buy a house, having defaulted on a mortgage once or having been compelled to sell on their own initiative. A loss of educational opportunities to a child who confronts these sorts of family circumstances and becomes worried as his family becomes depressed and quarrelsome with financial worries, may well experience permanent damage in his or her life chances no matter how much better conditions may become in the future. Any marriage guidance counsellor would be able to tell honourable members that problems in families are overwhelmingly related to the family's financial situation and not other problems of compatibility or whatever. Yet, unless the family has five or six children the increase in child endowment for the third child and beyond will not make up for these imposts. Furthermore, the larger the family the larger the house and hence possibly at least the mortgage. So advantages here can be wiped out as well.

However, the major group of forgotten people in this Budget are the pensioners. The oldest trick in the Australian politican's manual is called: 'Neglect the pensioners for two years and toss them a crumb or two when the election comes around'. The Whitlam Government indexed pensions to mitigate the worst excesses of this practice. However, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) attempted to make the best of a bad job in his Budget Speech when he announced the normal November pension rise-normal, that is, at least since the Whitlam Government introduced indexation of pensions-as though this were a generous Budget decision for which the pensioner ought to be extraordinarily grateful. His sleight of hand cannot conceal the paltry nature of actual Budget initiatives for pensioners and the quite menacing remarks made later in the evening on which the Budget was announced in another place by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) on pensioners' efforts to avoid earning income. I will deal with that matter a little later. All the Government has done is to make small additional grants to aged persons housing and minor adjustments in rental assistance. The Minister for Social Security, however, launched into an attack on pensioners' income avoidance with a vigour and vituperativeness that we on this side of the House use when we deal with the tax evasion industry. The Minister for Social Security had this to say:

It has become evident that there is a growing practice of avoiding income for pension purposes, or even more commonly for pensioner fringe benefits. There is no essential difference, so far as the general community effect is concerned, between this and tax avoidance.

The two are not to be equated. A professional person trying to reduce a tax liability on an income of over $50,000 a year is not to be equated with a pensioner trying to keep his or her nest egg within the limits of eligibility for fringe benefits. The point about the tax avoidance industry, against which this Government refuses to take decisive action, is that income actually received by the avoider goes untaxed because of some strategem on his part or on the part of his accountant. In the case of non-interest bearing deposits into which many pensioners put their savings to avoid difficulties with fringe benefits, no income is received by the pensioner. It is an entirely different situation. There are schemes which permit capital to accumulate without it being regarded as interest and, therefore, income for tax purposes. However, the vast bulk of pensioners using non-interest bearing deposits are not in these schemes and, therefore, lose money as the real value of their savings decline.

The Government has already announced that it will deal with the scheme which permits increments to capital and that is an issue separate from the question of non-interest bearing deposits. However, the Minister for Social Security failed to limit his strictures to those schemes alone and has directly threatened to introduce a regulation, and if necessary legislation, to deal with the pensioners who are putting their funds into non-interest bearing deposits. If we are to believe the Minister, the pensioners are to be hit twice; once by the banks that are lending the money they receive from pensioners at normal rates, and once by the Government which is toying with the idea of a notional and taxable interest rate.

Let us look now at the situation of the pensioners, these people whom the Government equates with the worst rip-off merchants in our community. Let us see why they have to avoid income on savings from income on much of which they have already paid tax. I will use the example of a single pensioner today who is under 70 years of age. This year, the taxation threshold will be increased by only 3.8 per cent to $4,195. In the financial year ending 30 June 1980 a single pensioner could have had additional income of $18 a week to that of his pension before being taxed. This year it will be only $10. If this trend continues-I suggest that with the elimination of tax indexation it will continue-pensioners will soon be paying tax on their bare pension. The pensioners will also be in a difficult situation in that they will not be eligible for the health rebate as they pay no health insurance subscriptions.

Pensioners who earn $20 a week above the pension, which is the maximum allowable income before deductions are made, will pay tax of $153.60 next year. If they earn $15 a week above the pension they will pay tax of $70 for the year. Income of $20 a week more than the pension loses half the value of the increase due to a deduction from the pension of $1 for every $2 earned.

After tax is deducted the effective tax rate is 66c in the dollar. This is more than the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) pays on any of his earnings although the pensioner's income is still less than $100 a week. The pensioner loses fringe benefits with income of $40 more than the pension. Fringe benefits have always been important to the pensioner. Now, with the Government's scandalous new health scheme, the benefit is absolutely essential. That forty-first dollar will be taxed at 32c, 34c will be further cut from the pension and it will bring in bills of $8 per week as a result of the pensioner being moved off the health benefit. Is the Minister really surprised that pensioners will go to considerable lengths to avoid earning that extra dollar? The Minister for Social Security has offered the kindly suggestion to pensioners that they go on an overseas holiday or buy a car to use up the capital. The Government, in its ineffable generosity, will not take a jaundiced view of this.

We face the interesting sight of age pensioners, compelled to sell the family home and to move into more appropriate accommodation, boarding planes in droves and circling the globe until their money runs out. Or perhaps to provide a facade for the Government's attempt to will prosperity on the people, pensioners will be encouraged to park a Rolls Royce outside their new flats. The sight of pensioners drag racing in Jaguars up the Great Eastern Highway in my electorate will no doubt be of some considerable comfort to the Minister. But how ridiculous it is! The Minister expects persons on $110 a week, who want to keep capital in case of emergencies for themselves or their families, to shift the fruits of their thrift from the banks to travel agents and car salesmen. The Government ought to be thanking its lucky stars that this piece of exploitation of the pensioners' economic situation has improved bank profitability and probably therefore, albeit in a minor way, has prevented interest rates rising even further. The obvious solution to this situation is for the allowable earnings limits to be greatly increased and then indexed for inflation as the basic pension is. This would have been achieved indirectly if the tax threshold had been raised to $4,529 as the Australian Labor Party advocated at the last election. It is time that we gave consideration to regarding the pensioner health benefit card as a retired persons' health benefit and at least indexing permissible earnings associated with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am very glad that the honourable member for St George agrees with me on this matter. The pensioners in the electorate of St George have certainly been well served since the honourable member's timely re-election at the last election. Next year is the Year of the Aged. Therefore perhaps we can expect in the next Burget a more generous amelioration of the pensioners' condition, particularly as it will precede an election year. I am confident that pensioners will see through the short term nature of such commitments and will judge the Government on its parsimonious attitude of the last five years. I will get on to the Government's record in the International Year of Disabled Persons a little later. On the experience of the disabled I am not at all sure that the pensioners will experience the degree of generosity that they might expect in the International Year of the Aged.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has no understanding of the problems of families and the elderly. This Budget gives further indication of its disregard of the position of young Australians. The level of hopelessness among our young people cannot be underestimated. A recent survey of suicide statistics of young people under 24 years of age, which was conducted by Apex-not an extreme radical organisation-showed a doubling of the rates over the last 10 years. Since the Government's decision to abolish the Community Youth Support Scheme I have been inundated with correspondence from participants in CYSS programs and from service groups who support them. Universally these groups report bleak experiences for young people who have no alternative to them. They point to a reduction in crime and youth gang activity in areas where CYSS groups have opened. They offer me the very reasonable assumption that there will be an increase in anti-social activity with the closure of the various CYSS schemes. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) is proud of increased Government expenditure in various training schemes announced in the Budget. However, I wonder how seriously he has looked at some of the things he has done. For example, employers' subsidies paid for taking on and training young people have hitherto been conducted under the rubric of the National Employment and Training scheme and associated training schemes.

Over the years Commonwealth Employment Service officers have been able to use the guidelines requiring a substantial component of training to discipline employers who might wish to abuse the scheme as a source of cheap labour. Employers who make a practice of sacking workers at the end of the training scheme can be eliminated from the program. However, in the Budget Papers, these schemes have now been shifted from NEAT to the more amorphous 'work experience' programs. My understanding is that CES officers have not yet been informed of the guidelines that apply here. Prima facie, however, the training aspect of the subsidy has been substantially reduced as a result of this decision.
