The idea that the employer should train a young person in a skill needed in the place of employment will be replaced by a lackadaisical assumption that any old work experience will do. So what if that person is laid off at the end of six months? At least, according to the Minister, they have had some sort of experience.

I predict that abuse of the system will become rife, with several consequences. Firstly, there will be further disillusion for the young people affected. Secondly, there will be a spurious government conviction that substantial reductions will have occurred in the statistics of young unemployed. A further consequence will be abuse of the working capacities of many individual young people as employers seek to justify the non-retention of the young people put on under work experience. Last week I asked the Minister a question on this matter but he was unable to provide me with an answer. The Minister's department is in chaos. It becomes more chaotic with each promise he makes to wriggle out of the consequences of his stupid decision to close CYSS. This scheme is the only Government initiative in the youth employment area which came anywhere near to achieving its objectives.

I will comment on what is perhaps the most disappointing feature of the Budget, that is, its contribution to the needs of the disabled in our community. Much was expected of this International Year of the Disabled when the program was announced. This year's goal, we were told, was full participation in our society and equality of opportunity for disabled people.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will not get that from Fraser.
—No, we certainly have not.
—They put a few in the Ministry.

—That is probably the most significant contribution. We have had lots of committee meetings, conferences, et cetera, and small increases in allowances for institutions. There have been no bold initiatives of the kind the Minister indicated there would be when the year began. Sales tax exemption on new cars has long been granted to disabled persons. But Customs duty must still be paid on imported hearing aids, wheel chairs and medical appliances.
—But they needed a domestic Budget surplus of $1.5 billion.

—That is right; so everybody can go to the wall. Some groups of disabled people had hoped for the introduction in this Budget of an attendant care allowance similar to those operating in Britain and the United States. Such a scheme has obvious advantages for both the disabled and the community at large. American programs have shown that many disabled people have been able to seek and find paid employment as a result of the freedom and independence that this allowance has given them. They have been able to gain the confidence to get out into the work force and to establish themselves as dignified human beings in their own right. That is a very basic objective with which all of us on both sides of the House would agree. Yet the Government is doing nothing to achieve it. In the long run, the taxpayers benefit from there being fewer people requiring invalid pensions and, more importantly, fewer people needing very expensive institutional care.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of other allowances and aids have been sought by disabled groups in this year. None have been granted in this do-nothing Budget. All I hope is that before the end of the year additional expenditure is sought by the Government to make up for these very considerable inadequacies. This Budget surplus could well have been used to help the disabled and the unemployed, to increase fringe benefits for pensioners and to retain schemes which have been abolished. I support the additional amount of foreign aid appropriated in this Budget. However, I would like to make this point about the additional amount of some $100m. That is not our aid total; that is the addition to our aid in this Budget. Had the Government adopted a similar attitude in the areas that I have been talking about, that sum would have retained CYSS ten times over; or the Government could have retained CYSS five times over and introduced a wide variety of additional benefits for the disabled. These have never been assessed in any of the published statistics as being extraordinarily expensive to the community. It leaves me quite amazed that the Government has not come around to doing any thing serious about the disabled in this Budget.

I only say this to point out what a paltry sum in the overall Budget context this assistance would have cost. If the Government did not want to take money from the surplus, it might have taken it by improving the capacity of the taxation commissioners to investigate tax evasion. Yet here the Budget Papers show that the number of persons employed in the enforcement section of the Australian Taxation Office will be reduced by 179. How seriously is this Government committed to stamping out the tax avoidance industry? Not much when its activity in staffing the relevant office is considered. This Budget is ungenerous and it is uncaring. The cost of the Government's little games in attempting to set itself up with a bag of handouts in an election year will be carried by people whose lives may very well be ruined or, at least, very seriously damaged. The only consolation is that the cost eventually will be carried by the Ministers who produced it when in two years time they contemplate the future from the benches on which we are now sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with a number of the sentiments expressed by the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley). However I feel that the feelings behind our philosophies should be put in perspective. The honourable member for Swan will be supporting greater and bigger government, greater and bigger government intervention and the like. The points he made in relation to the effect that the Budget will have on individuals are largely valid. I will support a number of the aspects to which he has already referred.

SPEECH.PARA: I emphasise that I support the broad economic thrust of this Budget. It is a wise and economically responsible Budget. The record of the Government proves that its economic policies are proving well worth while. We have seen inflation brought under control and reduced. We have seen a rise in business confidence. We have seen a greater investment, both local and overseas, in industry and business. This is a reflection that the Government's policies have, indeed, been working. The consumer price index rose by only 8.8 per cent in the year to 30 June 1981. That is the best result for a number of years. We have seen better figures for employment both overall and for young people. We have seen a significant increase in real private business fixed investments of at least 22.5 per cent in real terms. We have seen strong expectations demonstrated in the capital inflow projected for 1981-82.

Last year we saw an increase in average weekly earnings of some 14.1 per cent. It presents some real cause for concern, I think, when we see a forecast increase of some 13 per cent in average weekly earnings for this financial year. In considering the wage setting system I think we should be very concerned about increases in wages during the coming year. I think the situation can be best summed up from the 1980-81 report of the Reserve Bank of Australia. The Reserve Bank does not normally praise the Government or one take the Government line. It is a completely independent and professional body. Its views can be accepted reasonably well. In its report, it said:

Activity rose strongly in the Australian economy during 1980-81. This contrasted with generally depressed economic conditions overseas. Following healthy increases in 1979-80, real non-farm product and total employment recorded their highest rates of growth for more than half a decade. The recovery was broadly-based with strong contributions from spending on both capital formation and consumption.

I think this indicates that the direction of the Government's policy is correct. My comments will be concerned not with the direction of the Government's policy but with the strength and thrust of that policy. As a Liberal I strongly support a reduction in the government sector. I believe that the government sector is still much too large. I welcome the 350 decisions of the razor gang. These resulted in a decrease in expenditure of some $560m. But let us not place too much emphasis on the fact that the razor gang did its exercise. In effect, all it did represented a decrease of some 2 per cent in the annual outlays of the Commonwealth, which is a relatively small per cent. It does not even add up to 0.5 per cent of gross domestic product.

At the time there were a number of criticisms of the razor gang's exercise. I criticised it at the time. I maintained that the Review of Commonwealth Functions should be an ongoing policy and a requirement of each Minister within this Government. The very fact that one had to appoint a razor gang was a reflection on the ability of Ministers to control, prune and limit the activities and functions of their departments. I believe that a Minister should firmly monitor the activities and functions of departments and that the razor gang's activities should be a continuing function of any Minister and of any department. I contrast this with the activities in private enterprise. Firms do not have razor gang activities. They have constant reviews of the activities of each individual branch, and make constant adjustments and cut expenditure and wastage. That is exactly what the Commonwealth should still be doing. I have a firm belief the Commonwealth has not cut expenditure to anywhere near the required amount.

As I said, I think the razor gang exercise was admirable in its concept. But overall, as I pointed out, the savings were small. In looking at the 350 recommendations of the razor gang we realise that a number of the recommendations were cosmetic and artificial and did not really contribute in any way to a reduction of government expenditure or a reduction of government staffing. I need only to refer to the recommendations concerning the Australian Wool Stores and the Australian Wool Testing Authority. I have spoken on these matters previously in this House. They were assets not held by the Commonwealth; they were not purchased by the Commonwealth; they were purchased by growers and financed by growers from their own charges. Apart from the fact that they were run by statutory authorities they were of no responsibility of or charge on the Parliament. The sale of those assets will in no way help the Commonwealth budgetary situation or lessen the impact of the Commonwealth Government's activities in the area of wool testing.

It worries me even further that a number of the recommendations of the razor gang have been repudiated since and a number have not been yet implemented. Yesterday it was announced that a number of the recommendations of the razor gang in relation to the Australian Capital Territory had been repudiated or changed. I notice also that there has been no effort to form a joint committee as was proposed in the razor gang report. This was to be a committee set up to review the functions and the activities of statutory authorities. I believe that there is a large area that still has to be reviewed in that way. I call on the Government to take action immediately to appoint that joint committee, which I think could make a valuable contribution in this area.

As I have said, as a Liberal, I am committed to a reduction in the size of the public sector, and so is the Government in many ways. Unfortunately, the actions of the Government have not matched its rhetoric. Let me go back to the Budget Speech of 1976-77. It was delivered by the current Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch). One statement that I appreciated and applauded in that Budget Speech was this:
It will do so in part by putting an end to permissiveness in government spending and turning back the recent trend towards bigger and bigger government.

They are great words. Unfortunately, as I said, our action has not matched our rhetoric. The rhetoric in that statement is absolutely in line with what I believe. In fact, Commonwealth Government Budget outlays in real terms have fallen only slightly during the term of this Government. They still represent 28 per cent of the gross domestic product. Total public sector expenditure is now some 38.1 per cent of gross domestic product. The fall has been reasonably insignificant in relation to both these figures. They have fallen from a peak in 1977-78 to the current levels, but the reduction has been quite slight. I believe there is a real need for this Government to honour its commitment to reduce the size of the Government sector. In fact, the growth rate for outlays in the public sector during past years has been faster than that for the economy overall. I acknowledge that in a number of areas, such as health, social security and education, there have been, in fact, expenditure increases above those which currently apply to total government expenditure.

I want to look at the Government's Budget aggregates. I want to look, firstly, at the receipt side. Last year we had a growth in Commonwealth receipts of some 18.6 per cent-a significant increase. No one could doubt that. We are projecting this year an increase in revenue of some 15.8 per cent. Part of this revenue will come from the implementation of changes in sales tax levies. Let me emphasise quite clearly that I believe there is no way in which a broadening of the tax base is not warranted. I can see good arguments indeed for a number of the sales tax increases. The implementation of the increase in sales tax on pet food could have been more gradual. I see no reason for such items which were exempt from sales tax previously being taxed at 17 1/2 per cent.

Overall I support the concept of a broadening of the tax base. I support that broadening on the basis that there are reductions in other areas of collection by the Commonwealth. I refer particularly to income tax. I think there is justification for the increase in sales tax only if this increase can be offset by a reduction in income tax. I am disappointed that that has not happened. Our rhetoric over a number of years has been that income taxes have to be reduced. I believe-some Opposition members may believe that I have been convinced of this by our propaganda-that income taxes have to be reduced substantially. I note that this year income tax collections will rise by some 19 per cent-by almost the same amount by which they have risen in the past 10 years. Income tax collections represent over 50 per cent of the total tax collections of the Commonwealth. This is much too high a level. I think if we look at the forecast for wages-an increase of some 13 per cent in average weekly earnings for this financial year that I referred to earlier-we will see that pay-as-you-earn tax contributions will rise by some 22 per cent. The Commonwealth is gaining in this way. I object to this in many ways. I believe that there is ample room for a reduction in government expenditure and substantially reduced income tax levies. I am critical also of the Commonwealth's outlays. Direct government outlays by the Commonwealth this year will rise by some 15.1 per cent.

I am critical also of the concept of federalism. I think this Government had a good federalism policy, one that could have matured and developed in many ways. Unfortunately, we have seen cuts in the amounts made available to the States. This year we will see a reduction in payments to the States from 8.2 per cent when compared with last year's figure. Yet Commonwealth Government outlays are rising by 15.1 per cent. The point I make is that if we try to impose restrictions on the States we should impose similar restrictions on ourselves. We are not doing that. As a Liberal I am committed to the transfer to the State governments of a number of functions currently carried out by the Commonwealth Government. I believe that transfer can take place only with an adequate transfer of the means to perform those functions.

Quite frankly, I am appalled at the legislation that has been introduced recently in relation to education funding providing for the transfer of capital funds to recurrent expenditure. I feel that this is not at all in the spirit of federalism, or the federalism that I espoused in the early days. I believe in a number of areas where Commonwealth funding is involved, such as education and roads, there can well be a relaxation of the Connowealth's control. Let the State governments which are in a position to make decisions make those decisions and bear the penalties if their decisions are not right in relation to the disbursal of funds. I note also that the tightening of State finances inevitably will result in an increase in State government taxes and charges. I note also that many of these charges are very regressive indeed. I think by their very nature thay are regressive. This places a greater burden on the family man and the single man.

Unfortunately, I must refer in some degree to some of the statements made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Swan. I comment on some aspects of social security and the adjustmjents made in this Budget. It is my belief that it is a requirement of government to service those who are most needy, those who are most deserving of social security benefits. We see two types of social security benefits: We see those which are designed either by way of a means test or some other device to apply to the needy and those which are applied generally. Quite frankly, I criticise this Budget for its decision in relation to the changes in the family allowance. I do not see it as fair or reasonable that families consisting of three, four or more children should be the ones who are the recipients of increased benefits. In my view this is a very rough and inaccurate guide as to need. I can think of many cases where the need may be much greater; for example, where supporting mothers, the unemployed, those who are receiving sickness benefits and other social security recipients have one or two children. I criticise very much the fact that we as a government have lost the opportunity to reverse the trend towards universal application of social security benefits. This is a perfect case where some type of means test could have been applied. The increased allowance should have been given to those in need, not to those who fell into a broadly based category.

I join the honourable member for Swan in criticising the statements by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) that the capital of pensioners should be included in the determination of their pension entitlements. I look back at the 1976-77 Budget speech. I do not have time to quote from that Speech. I was convinced that what we said in that Speech represented a fair change from the previous arrangement under which a notional capital return was means tested in determining eligibility for a pension. I definitely disassociate myself from statements by the Minister for Social Security that people who invest money so that they receive low or nil returns are in the same position as tax dodgers. I emphasise that I completely disassociate myself from those statements by the Minister. In fact, what pensioners are doing at the moment is exactly what we endorsed in 1976 when we changed the requirements and qualifications for receiving aged pension. In fact, I support some degree of justification on a needs assessment basis before a person can receive social security benefits.

It seems to me that we have our priorities completely wrong. In no way can I reconcile the decisions made in relation to family allowances, on the one hand, and pensions on the other. It seems to me that the ideal item in which to apply the idea of a means test is the family allowances area. If I had a preference, I certainly would have applied means testing in that area rather than applying it in the pension area. There are a number of areas in which I have criticised the Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that my good friend and colleague the honourable member for Canning (Mr Bungey) has been struck by a blinding flash of light. He can now see the difference between the Fraser Government's promises and its performance, and he mentioned taxation particularly. Wage and salary earners of Australia are now suffering record tax. In fact, the wage and salary earners of Australia are being taxed more now than ever before. In addition to the taxation payments, under the latest Fraser medi-muddle every Australian family has to find an additional $10 to $18 a week for payments to medicare funds. So in addition to the record taxation to which the honourable member for Canning alluded, every Australian family is further taxed under the Fraser Government's scheme for medical care.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight we are at somewhat of a disadvantage in this debate if we are seeking to embark on an informed discussion of defence issues. Last year the defence report was brought down on 19 August 1980, well before this time, and yet we have not received the defence report for 1981. Also about this time last year the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) made a detailed statement on defence, but we have not yet seen one this year. I think it is important to recognise that last year was an election year. As we all know, nothing concentrates the mind of the Liberal Party on defence so much as an upcoming election. We all know that the Minister for Defence is renowned for the eloquence of his rhetoric but not for the accuracy of his statements or his forecasts, and I will give an example. In his statement of 29 March 1979, and this was in the period of the Afghanistan euphoria, the Minister asserted:
The provision in 1978-79 for a defence outlay larger in real terms than any achieved since the last Budget of the McMahon Government;

Leaving aside the fact that Australia was still engaged in the operations of war at the time of the last McMahon Government, let us look at the record of the Government's defence report. I have alluded to the defence report for 1980, and I invite honourable members to glance at page 50. In 1978-79, the year the Minister was talking about, the defence expenditure as a percentage of gross domestic product was 2.6 per cent. If we look back to the last Labor defence Budget, the ratio was in fact 2.7 per cent. In real terms, the Minister's promise to have a larger outlay than at any time previously was ostensibly false. In 1978-79 the ratio fell to 2.6 per cent. In more recent times the Government has made equally inaccurate and misleading statements, and I refer honourable members to the 1980-81 Budget Paper No. 1. If they look at page 70 they will note that the Government promised that defence outlays in 1980-81 would represent a real increase of 'at least 7 per cent over defence outlays in 1979-80'. Let us look at the record. The increase in actual outlay was not at least 7 per cent, as the Government had indicated, but in fact was 4.2 per cent. In the same document the Government stated:
The financial guidance for Defence planning purposes provides for an average annual increase in defence outlays of about 7 per cent-
We get that 7 per cent back again--
in real terms during the current five-year program, 1980-81 to 1984-85.

The Government further stated that its aim was to bring defence expenditure to 3 per cent of gross domestic product. The Government must have forgotten that promise because if honourable members look at Budget Paper No. 1 for 1981-82 they will find the disclosure that the 1981-82 Estimates involve 'a real increase over 1980-81 of about 5.3 per cent'. So here is a forecast for one year of 7 per cent relating to a particular year and that particular year does not measure up to the promise made. The promise was 7 per cent and the Government finished up with 5.3 per cent. The same document also informs us that for 1980-81 Budget outlays were 2.7 per cent of gross domestic product. This makes a complete nonsense of the Government's repeated assertions that defence spending is well up. In six years of greater attention to propaganda and promises than to performance, the Government has managed to increase defence outlays from the Labor Government's figure of 2.6 per cent to 2.7 per cent of gross domestic product. So much for the hollow claims and empty rhetoric of this Government on defence matters.

Talking about hollow claims and empty rhetoric, another area of Government activity to which I would like to refer is the area of foreign aid. We all know that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is preparing himself for his entry onto the international stage at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne. He has discovered the North-South dialogue and is parading as the champion of the less developed countries. Again, let us look at the record. Some years ago the United Nations set a target of 0.7 per cent of gross national product for official aid. Referring to the official documentation of this Budget, if one looks at page 14 of Budget Paper No. 8, the hypocrisy of the Government on the question of foreign aid is plain for everyone to see. In 1975, the last year of the Labor Government, the Whitlam Government, Australia's aid reached 0.65 per cent of gross national product. That was very close to the 0.7 per cent that had been set as a target by the United Nations. Five years later, and five years of Fraser Government, the figure has dropped sharply. It has dropped from 0.65 per cent to 0.48 per cent.

Last evening the Estimates Committee passed a resolution that the Government should accept the 0.7 per cent target. The Fraser Government has never made a statement since it has been in government that the 0.7 per cent target set by the United Nations should be an accepted target of the Government. In the Estimates debates last night the Minister suggested that the expenditure this year, 1981-82, would show very little increase in real terms over the expenditure last year. So instead of perhaps 0.48 per cent, by a massive effort-surprise, surprise-it might get it up to 0.49 per cent or perhaps even 0.5 per cent. The resolution passed last night put it on the Government to make a statement that it was prepared not only to accept the target of 0.7 per cent but also to work conscientiously towards that target. We only hope that it will take the recommendation to heart.

This Government's record of assistance to the disadvantaged is as deplorable internationally as it is domestically. The honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) gave a catalogue of this Government's policies in relation to the disadvantaged within the Australian society. It is a deplorable record of inadequacy, incompetence and absence of any feeling for the disadvantaged, including Aborigines, the handicapped and the senior citizens of this country. The same thing applies to the Fraser Government internationally, as we have noticed in the statistics of its aid effort. These statistics are stated very clearly in the Budget Papers that this Government has presented. I am sure that the performance of the Prime Minister, as distinct from his rhetoric and promise, will not go unnoticed at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.

While we are on the subject of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, it is not too late for the Prime Minister to heed the parting advice of the outgoing President of the United Nations General Assembly. He recently criticised the massive indulgence of the international cocktail circuit. One is almost inclined to call it not only a circuit but also a circus. He pointed out that one national cocktail party at the United Nations General Assembly could fund a health care unit in a less developed country for over a year. This Government will spend $12m of Australian taxpayers' funds on administrative arrangements and entertainment, not only on the meeting in Melbourne but also on what is called the retreat in Canberra. It is not only a scandal, but also a disgrace. If the Prime Minister were less concerned about strutting the world stage and more concerned, as he professes he is, for the disadvantaged, he would divert a substantial part of that $12m to assist the people of the countries the visiting heads of government represent. I leave that thought with the Prime Minister.

I now turn to a subject that is very close to my heart and to people in the electorate of St George. I notice that the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) is at the table. I refer to aircraft noise. I have been associated with this matter as the honourable member for St George off and on for the last 10 years. I had the privilege of serving on the House of Representatives Select Committee on Aircraft Noise over 10 years ago. That Committee made a series of recommendations for minimising aircraft noise, not only at Sydney Airport but also at other airports throughout Australia. One of those recommendations was the strict enforcement of the curfew. When the Labor Government came to power in 1972-

TALK.START.PARA: —Office.

—I do detect the difference. When we came to office in 1972 we certainly had the power to enforce the curfew. That curfew was strictly maintained from 1972 to 1975. We are now fighting a losing battle. In 1976 the number of flights during curfew hours-I am indebted to the Minister for Transport for providing these figures-was 3,562. In 1980 that figure had jumped by 82 per cent to 6,480. In addition, jets-admittedly quiet ones but jets nevertheless-have been allowed to operate at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport during the curfew hours. To my mind, to the people who live in the electorates of St George, Barton and Grayndler this is the thin edge of the wedge.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a further disturbing trend, that is the increase in traffic in the late evenings between 10 p.m. and 6.45 a.m. These figures include traffic during the curfew hours: In 1976 flights between 10 p.m. and 6.45 a.m. numbered 8,463. By 1980 there have been a 67 per cent increase to 14,096. That increase of 67 per cent can be related to an 18.6 per cent increase in general traffic. There is now a concentration of traffic in the period 10 p.m. to 6.45 a.m. I do not think that the Minister at the table was the Minister for Transport in 1979 but at that stage the Government quite secretly introduced a reduction of the curfew to midnight. This meant that planes could land at Kingsford-Smith Airport without approval to 12 o'clock instead of the curfew hour of 11 o'clock. It was only through community opposition that that secret move was overcome.

As the member for St George I am concerned about the 24-hour a day traffic either landing or taking off over the electorate. Since 1976 there has been a 32 per cent increase in traffic over St George. In 1976 there were 29,072 movements over the St George area. In 1980 there were 38,477. This means that the more traffic that comes to Kingsford-Smith Airport the more the people of St George will have to suffer. The Fraser Government-I think this was confirmed this afternoon by the Minister at the Estimates committee hearing on the Department of Transport appropriations-intends to increase the traffic at Kingsford-Smith Airport to 280,000 movements a year. At present there are 182,000 movements. That means there will be a 50 per cent increase in the amount of traffic at Kingsford-Smith Airport. I say to the Minister for Transport that that is not on. It is always said: 'Things will not be so bad because we will have new technology aircraft. They will be quieter'. That is humbug. Trans Australian Airlines has bought the Airbus and I accept that it is quieter but the opposition, the Murdoch-Ansett airline, has purchased an increased number of Boeing 727s and 737s. Those planes are equipped with Pratt and Whitney engines which came into service in the United States in 1963. We are not talking about new planes, we are talking about old technology. These aircraft with their 18-year-old design Pratt and Whitney engines are being brought into service as new aircraft. We will have them for another 10 to 15 years at least. Any proposition that the so-called new aircraft will lead to quieter Kingsford-Smith Airport is sheer humbug.

We have been fighting for some time for a second airport for Sydney. The second runway-I make this very clear to the Minister for Transport-makes no sense technically or financially. Technically, in order to have simultaneous operations at an airport with dual runways, under International Civil Aviation Organisation regulations there should be a separation between runways of 1,300 metres or 4,300 feet. The Government's recommendation is for close parallel runways separated by 335 metres or 1,100 feet. There are some arguments about how much the second runway will cost. The figures run from $395m to $600m. But let me point out that the cost of a new airport would be in the vicinity of $675m. The lesson is very clear: Let us not take two bites of the cherry; let us not build a second runway and then go and build a second airport. The decision, to my mind, is very clear: Let us get on and build a second airport so that the people of the St George area will not for life ever more have to suffer the difficulties, the strains of aircraft noise, that they have suffered over the last few years. The decision should be made now. The Minister says that the Commonwealth has the authority. Let it use that authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to give my support to the Government's economic policy. I feel that it has been shown to be a successful policy basically because of its capacity to contain and to reduce the rate of inflation in Australia today. Inflation has a direct effect on every person's pocket. When a housewife or any other person in Australia today goes into a shop to purchase an item or goes to some business establishment to receive a service, he or she benefits from a contained inflation rate. Inflation has a direct effect on the money in one's pocket. I think the Government has been more than successful in world terms in this particular field. It is a tough policy in many ways. Sometimes I personally feel that there could be more compassion in certain areas.
—Name them.

—I will come to that in a little while. However, I feel that in the main the Government has been hard to be kind. The Budget had helped to shift the balance of tax from income tax to indirect tax. One could argue at length in the electorate or in the Parliament about the virtues of direct or indirect tax. Income tax is a disincentive in many ways for productivity. Right throughout Australia today there are people who do not want to be more productive because the income tax they would have to pay on the extra money they earned would not make it worth their effort. Therefore, I feel that income tax is self-destructive in many ways. I do not advocate the complete abolition of income tax and a move across to indirect tax; however, I feel that there should be a better balance. I am afraid that I do not quite agree with the Government's approach in that a little time ago it looked at indirect tax and then backed off and said: 'No, we will not bring in another form of indirect tax'. I have always felt that we should have moved into the indirect tax field at that stage. However, that is history.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the sales tax provisions in the Budget are not popular in my electorate or in any other honourable member's electorate. However, I feel that the move is the right one in the long term providing there is a balance with some relief in income tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you like to see VAT?

—No, I would not. I would like to see a retail turnover tax of a moderate kind but not a value added tax. In the field of social security, which of course received the largest slice of our Budget we talk about a 14.7 per cent rise or a total of $9.865m. I have some very strong personal feelings about the pension system. I am convinced that unfortunately there are many people throughout our society today who do not really need the pension they are getting. I feel that there are many people taking advantage of the system when they are not truly in need. When I was a lad and all through my early life I was led to believe that pensions were to be made available to those who were in need, whether through bad luck, bad health or some other incapacity. Pensions were to be provided to look after the needy. Unfortunately, I find as I move thoughout society today that there is this general thought: A pension is my just and deserved right; as a taxpayer all my life it is time I started to get something back. This might be all very well if we were talking about a national superannuation scheme but we are talking about a pension scheme funded by the taxpayer. When I speak to a lot of the younger taxpayers today, it surprises me to hear them say: 'Yes, I agree that so-and-so could well afford to do without the pension; however, he has paid his taxes all his life and surely he is justly entitled to it'. I am sorry but I am afraid that I do not agree with that concept. I feel that taxes in this particular field should not go to other than the truly needy.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to veterans' affairs. I have a very soft spot for the veterans of Australia. I feel that none of us would be in this Parliament or in the surrounds of this Parliament had it not been for the veterans of Australia, the men and women who were caught up in those horrible wars-whichever one one would like to think of; there was a whole series of them. As I say, I have a very soft spot for these veterans. I am pleased to see that there have been some improvements in benefits for veterans. I feel that this is one area in which the Government can show even more compassion. In the field of health, we see a complete change in the Government's policy. I personally like the scheme except for one particular area and that is the cut-off point between the disadvantaged person and the person who is outside government support. I feel that the Government could well have had a graduated carry-over system beyond the $96 per week for a single person without children or the $160 per week for the married couple. I feel that the cut-off point is just too sharp and it certainly has created a great deal of antagonism throughout Australia.

There is one small area of concern in the health program that I have struck and it concerns the large number of people who are involved in casual employment. These people are very worried about whether they will be within the disadvantaged person category this week and outside it the next. I am assured by the Department of Social Security that it does an average over four weeks and that it will be sympathetic to every case. I hope this is so because there are a large number of people throughout Australia today who are relying on casual work to be workers; who are not prepared to go on unemployment relief and who will keep battling for the job. Some weeks they will be in luck, some weeks they will not. I instance the case of Awol Meats Pty Ltd in my electorate which has had to close down. I know there are men at that works who are battling to get casual work.

I have been particularly interested in the International Year of Disabled Persons program. Unfortunately, we have only $2.43m available out of the Budget for this program. It is an ambitious program which, in my opinion, has not really got off the ground. I might be open to criticism. It may have got off the ground in certain areas but not, I feel, in the country areas, and particularly the country areas that I represent. The program includes a whole series of things: The modification of homes, the provision of wheelchairs, the provision of such things as oxygen equipment, wigs, mammary prostheses, electrolarynxes, aids for incontinence, walking aids and a whole series of equipment for disabled people, such as crockery, cutlery, cooking utensils and toilets.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds like the Senate.

—Maybe one day the honourable member will take advantage of this program, and maybe it will not be too far away. However, I feel that carrying the program on for only 12 months is not long enough. There was the International Year of the Child and now the International Year of Disabled Persons. One year really is not long enough for a program-even though it is world wide-to get rolling. It should be ongoing, and certainly it should have a two-year impact period and then a rolling continuation.

SPEECH.PARA: I now refer to the subject of employment, and youth affairs in particular. I have been very interested in the Community Youth Support Scheme projects in my electorate. In a rural electorate, those projects have been a rip-roaring success. However, on 31 October they are to be closed. I am most disappointed. I am the first to admit that they might not have been the complete answer and they might not have been as successful in many areas as one would have hoped. However, they were a start. They were a community effort. Participating citizens all made a contribution. However, the scheme is to be terminated on 31 October and it appears that we will not change our minds in that regard.

I admire the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown). I think he is doing a very good job in very difficult circumstances. I hope that he pursues the line that he has pronounced several times recently and will look at the problem of the young person who will not fit into the quite extensive training for the work force schemes that are being made available by the Government. There is certainly an element of young people who are not able to take advantage of those schemes. I wish to comment on just one of those training schemes, and that is SYETP, the Special Youth Employment Training Program. Unfortunately, some employers are taking advantage of that scheme as a way of subsidising their work force. I condemn that. Some employers have employed a young person for 17 weeks at a subsidies rate of $55 per week and have then sacked them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then they turn around and vote Liberal.

—Some employ young people under the extended scheme of 34 weeks. That provides for $80 for the first 17 weeks and $55 for the next 17 weeks. Whether they vote Liberal or whether they vote Labor, they are human beings and they are abusing the system. That is not good, and it is something we have to tighten up on. One scheme in my electorate at Tallangatta was approved by the former Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. It was a one-off. It is a work pool or a job shop scheme which is starting to develop very well.
—Where is that?

—In Tallangatta in the electorate of Indi. I would like to see that scheme and the possibility of its being extended into certain selected areas looked at closely by the Department. I think it lends itself to the bigger country town. The School to Work Transition Program is working well in many States. I am afraid that it does not appear to be getting off the ground in Victoria. I know the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) is concerned about it but I ask him to pursue discussions about this program with the Victorian Minister of Education in an endeavour to reach a solution so that that program can swing into action in full force.

SPEECH.PARA: More than $302m will be provided by the Commonwealth this year for the construction and maintenance of national highways and the development of roads throughout Australia. In Victoria, out of a total $52.87m for national highways, more than $23m will be provided for work on the Hume Highway, including major expenditure on the Seymour-Avenel by-pass, and about $6m on the Wallace-Bungaree by-pass on the Western Highway, and some $9m on a by-pass and duplicate projects on the Princes Highway between Dandenong and Traralgon. All these highways are vitally important for Victoria. However, throughout our nation there is a series of arterial roads and local roads that, whilst receiving funding, are not receiving enough funding in many cases even to maintain them, let alone improve them for the modern motor car. This, I feel, is an area in which government will have to be very cautious and make sure that funding is provided certainly to maintain them at a high standard, if not improve it.

I shall make just a brief comment on housing. I thought the answer given by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) this morning in answer to a question regarding an analysis of housing in Australia by the Reserve Bank of Australia research department was most significant. I think there was one paragraph in an article from the Department of Housing and Construction 'News Summary' which the Treasurer did not enunciate and which I should. It states:
. . . the level of home ownership in Australia remains at probably the highest in the western world and has actually picked up since the mid-1970s-
That is very significant. Since 1975 it has picked up. The article further states:
and is again close to an all-time peak. Further, more than one-third of Australian households fully-own their homes . . .

I think that is significant. I do not think there is much more I should say about housing. Naturally, we would like to be able to provide more funds for welfare housing. The cake has to be shared right across the board. Naturally, if one's interest is in one sector one can make a lot of noise about that sector. That is being done in regard to welfare housing.

I refer now to education. Certain allowances have been made for isolated students. The Secondary Allowances Scheme will increase from 10 per cent from $660 to $726 a year the special supplementary allowance under the Isolated Children's Assistance Scheme. Under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme the level of family income for eligibility for maximum benefit will be increased from $10,312 to $11,334 a year. It may not sound a lot but it will be very significant to a large number of parents.

In primary industry it is very significant that we appear to be making further progress in the beef classification system, and $1.1m will be made available for that. I hope that we can make some real progress in this program, which has been dragging its feet. The other area I mention is meat inspection. I am sure the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) will be looking closely-he has assured us that he is-at the duplication of meat inspection.

Finally, I would like to touch rapidly on energy and research and to point out the funds committed over a period for technology. It covers a whole series of areas, but I pick out particularly solar and wind energy. An amount of $5.9m has been committed to the investigation of solar and wind energy. This is an area about which I am often asked whether we are doing any work. I assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the Government is. The only other thing I would like to refer to is liquefied petroleum gas which, as an alternative fuel, would be a major area of attention by the Government. We intend to convert 9,000 Commonwealth vehicles over the next three years. Three thousand of those will be vehicles of Commonwealth Government Departments and 6,000 will be vehicles of self-financing government instrumentalities. This has to be a positive step forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget, as a financial planning document embodying the social and economic concepts of this Government, does not, in the view of the Opposition, meet the needs of the Australian people. As an economic document it represents the worst aspects of the monetarist doctrine so dearly beloved of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). It perpetuates and endeavours to sustain a series of economic myths that have been perpetrated by this Government over the years. As a social document it is a disaster. It compounds the social inequality in our community. It imposes heavier burdens on those sections of our community who are least able to bear them. It entrenches social class division within Australian society and it compounds many of the divisions already existing at other levels of our community.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me deal first with it as an economic document. It should not be forgotten by this Parliament that this Prime Minister has been in power longer than any Prime Minister in our history since the late Sir Robert Gordon Menzies-longer than Gorton, longer than McMahon and longer than Whitlam. This Prime Minister has had all the time that any government could reasonably expect to secure the basic aspects of his economic policies. The main thrust of this economic doctrine has been to control inflation. How real is that promise? How real is that objective in terms of this Budget? In 1975-76 inflation was 13 per cent. In 1980-81 it was reduced to 9.4 per cent. On the Budget indicators within this document it is conceded by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) that in the financial year 1981-82 the present Budget estimate is an inflation figure of 11 per cent. If one looks at that economic objective of the Prime Minister in terms of the time span he has had to control inflation, on the standards of his own Budget that objective has not been obtained.

Another major problem that confronts this community and haunts this Government is the problem of unemployment. Employment growth, as projected in this Budget, is likely to be 2 per cent or less. With an annual growth in the work force in excess of 2 per cent, it has to be conceded by the Treasurer, the Prime Minister and all save the most politically jaundiced that this Budget will not solve the problems of unemployment in this community. I remind the House and the people of Australia that the Prime Minister, who was going to turn the lights on, after a record period in government now presides over the highest unemployment level in our history. Of course, this was the Prime Minister, this was the government, that was pledged to lift the burden of taxation from the shoulders of the Australian people. It was a simple economic doctrine: He would take from the public sector, he would transfer to the private sector; smaller government meant smaller taxation. It would have been an appropriate doctrine with which to write a story like Alice in Wonderland, and one begins to wonder whether this Government and this Treasurer do not permanently live in a wonderland surrounded by economic advisers who only sustain their somewhat mystical economic doctrines.

This is the reality of this Budget document: No member on the Government side of the House-not the Treasurer, not the Prime Minister-can deny that one of the results of this Budget is to take taxation to the highest ever level as a percentage of gross domestic product, especially for pay-as-you-earn taxpayers. It will be still higher in the current financial year. Increased tax burdens are now the lot of wage and salary earners. Neither the Treasurer nor any member of this House can deny that, although tax has become an increasing burden on wage and salary earners, the tax evasion industry in Australia under this Prime Minister has been one of the few industries that could truly be described as a growth industry. For the very rich in Australian society it is no longer a question of what level of tax they pay. They go along to an eminent lawyer, they get into a whole range of agreements with accountants and they do not pay any tax at all. Is anything to be done about that in this Budget? No, the Budget indicates that that sort of financial rip-off will continue at approximately the same level.

How does the Treasurer, how does any honourable member opposite, reconcile the introduction of a broadly based sales tax which will affect the living standards of every family in Australian society-the kid who buys a can of dog meat for his pet dog will find himself confronted with the greedy hands of the Treasurer of this Government-with the Prime Minister's pledge in 1975, on behalf of every honourable member opposite, to end taxation by stealth. The Government said not a word about sales tax increases prior to the 1980 election. In November last year the Prime Minister went on record and rejected as idle and false rumour, as untrue Labor propaganda, the very suggestion that he or his Goverment was planning to introduce a value added tax or any similar broad-based tax. I would like to hear from any of the honourable gentlemen opposite how they now justify the promises freely made by them to the Australian people in 1980 in terms of this Budget doctrine.

My colleagues earlier in this debate described in detail the doubling of sales tax on furniture, floor coverings, white goods and bedding. They illustrated the tax impost on clothing, shoes, books and newspapers, the tax increase on cars-the tax on every level of consumption by the average Australian family. At the end of six years of Fraser tax policy 98 per cent of taxpayers are paying a higher proportion of their incomes in tax than they were during the last year of the Whitlam Government. The average Australian family is now more highly taxed than at any time in our history. Since this Government came to office pay-as-you-earn tax collections have risen by 144 per cent, compared with a growth in total wages and salaries paid of 98 per cent. One can add to this burden the costs that come from increased charges under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, increased health insurance charges under the fifth Fraser health scheme, increased interest charges on home loans and increased education charges. People in my State, Victoria, can add the very significant increases imposed by the State Liberal Government under a Premier who was once-I doubt whether he is any longer-an enthusiastic exponent of Fraser federalism. There were very substantial increases in gas and electricity charges in Victoria.

In the light of all those increases in tax and in charges and in the light of the evidence I gave to the House, which showed that tax collections had risen by 144 per cent but real wages and salaries paid had only grown by 98 per cent, it is not possible for anyone to argue seriously in this Parliament or anywhere else that Fraser federalism and Fraser monetarist policies have not severely eroded the living standards of every Australian family. Do the practical men opposite-there are a few-or anybody else believe that when confronted with reduced living standards white collar workers and blue collar workers at every level of our society, locked in as many of them are to a scale of minimum payments, can avoid them? If one is paying for a house and one is caught with increased interest charges there is no way in which one can avoid them. If one is caught in a range of payments for hire purchase goods there is no way that one can avoid them. If one is educating two or three children who need clothing, feeding and all of the things that go with sending children to school, there is no way of avoiding those costs. If any of those children are sick and one is caught with doctors' and health care bills there is no way of avoiding those payments. It is not easy for the Australian citizen to tighten his belt.

I suppose one can forgive the Prime Minister, the squatter from Nareen, for not really being able to comprehend that problem. He has never had to experience it. Does anybody seriously believe that in this situation wage and salary earners at every level will not seek increases in their wages and salaries in order simply to maintain their existing living standards? Of course they will. Of course they will rely on their trade union organisations to maintain those standards. So within this Budget there is a formula that will inevitably lead to industrial confrontation, strikes and further occasions when Ministers opposite will say what a monstrous and terrible thing it is for the average Australian wage and salary earner to try, by industrial action, to maintain his living standards.

Perhaps these taxation increases could have been justified if there were a corresponding increase in the standards of public service, that should be being provided in this community, or an increase in assistance to the largest number of Australians in our history who are living below the poverty line. Who could seriously complain if there were a significant increase for pensioners in this Budget? For single pensioners the proportion of average weekly earnings represented by the pension will fall to 22 per cent this year as compared with 23 per cent last year and 25 per cent under the Whitlam Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It never got to 25 per cent.

—Who would seriously argue against an increase in unemployment benefits? Would the honourable member who just interjected? Would the honourable gentleman argue that 18-year-olds receiving only $36 a week, $37 a week below the poverty line, have not some claim on the conscience of even the honourable gentleman opposite? Who in this Parliament, apart from the Prime Minister and his Ministerial colleagues, would seriously argue about a paltry $11m that is gained by this Government by abolishing Community Youth Support Scheme programs, by abandoning some 56,000 young people who were being assisted by CYSS projects, and by placing 800 CYSS project officers into the dole queue? Who would seriously argue in terms of the priorities of this Government? If one were to be candid with the Australian people one would say: 'Of course it is a proper, honourable and decent thing to maintain those projects'. If given a real choice as to whether to maintain those projects or to put up with the Prime Minister hawking himself around Melbourne posing as a great international statesman and spending upwards of $14m on the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, who amongst the Australian people would not say: 'It might be perfectly proper to host CHOGM but do you have to do it at such a cost? Do you have to do it at the expense of thousands of young Australians and thousands of Australian pensioners?'.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a question of what are the social priorities of this Government at a time when we have record unemployment of young Australians. Teenage unemployment rose from 91,000 to 131,000 in the five years to 1980. At a time when government should be expanding its role in education, confronted with the enormity of those figures, given the tasks of transition education, the need to educate young people for technological change, to deal with the problems of migrant and special education and adult retraining programs, education at every level in Australian society except in the private school system so dearly beloved amongst the old boys who sit on ministerial benches, is being attacked. Funding to colleges of advanced education has been cut by 11.7 per cent in real terms. The number of Victorian teacher trainees will be cut to half what it was when the Fraser Government took office. More and more parents are being forced out of the State education system to pay for a private education in order to provide their children with equal educational opportunities.

At every level Australians are paying more in tax but getting less back in public service. The rhetoric of diminishing the public sector for the private sector is economic nonsense. What is occuring in Australia is that the control of our economic destiny is not being transferred from the public sector to the private sector, which has some degree of responsibility to the Australian elector, to transnational corporations. I do not cavil with any argument that says that there ought to be a reduction in the level of Australian bureaucracy but I would prefer an Australian bureaucrat any day of the week to a nameless, faceless, company director sitting in London, Detroit or Tokyo who is able to control the economic destiny of this nation.

Canada is the country most penetrated by transnational corporations but Australia, under the Fraser Government, has the dubious reputation of being second. About 40 per cent of all the large companies and their assets in Australia are foreign controlled and in some key sectors of the economy that figure is 100 per cent. Conservatively, 40 to 50 per cent of the Australian corporate economy is now under the control of transnational corporations. The capacity of this Government in its attacks upon its public sector to deal with that problem to see that Australians have some say and some control over their economic future, is being increasingly diminished.

This Budget will increase inflation not reduce it. It will increase unemployment not reduce it. It will compound social inequality already existing in Australian society. It will reduce equal educational opportunity for the great majority of Australian children. It will impose the highest tax burdens on wage and salary earners in our history and in reducing their living standards it will produce industrial confrontation as wage and salary earners struggle and strive to maintain those standards. It will leave the tax evasion industry and its rich clientele comparatively unscathed. It will continue to attack and diminish, at every level, public services that ought to be a necessary and vital part of the functioning of any democracy. It is a wretched Budget, a dishonest Budget and a Budget lacking in compassion and imagination. It is a tribute to a Treasurer who does not know and a Prime Minister who does not care.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in support of the Budget and its general priority of economic restraint. Obviously there are parts of it which I am not so happy to support. These refer to tax, the Community Youth Support Scheme, roads and Telecom Australia. But I also want to refer to what I consider to be an interesting initiative in the Budget and that is the establishment of an Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I will refer to tax. It must be acknowledged that there is an increase in tax in this Budget when one considers sales tax, income tax and fiscal drag. Therefore it is important that the promised personal income tax relief, as the offset for the sales tax increases, comes quickly. To me a good starting point would be to lift the tax thresholds for the different levels of income tax, particularly the initial threshold which determines when a person commences paying tax. This would help all taxpayers but assist particularly low income groups and pensioners who earn additional income. The latter reason is important not only in itself but because it is a necessary prerequisite for updating the $20 permissible earnings. That figure has not been altered since 1972. But if one increases the permissible earnings limit without altering the tax threshold it would add insult to injury to the pensioners of Australia because all of them would automatically be liable for taxation.

The second grouch that I have relates to the decision to end the Community Youth Support Scheme. I think it is a particularly sad decision for rural and regional areas where the scheme has been the most successful. Nine of these groups are in the Murray electorate. I think it has the most of any electorate in Australia. I believe there are three reasons why CYSS should continue. The first is that the group that is assisted by the Community Youth Support Scheme consists of young unemployed who are below the training program level. The expansion of training programs-which is one of the features of this Budget-will not really help this group of young people. To my mind, $14m out of a total Budget allocation of over $200m for young persons training programs is not an untoward expenditure. The second point I want to make in support of CYSS is that it has allowed small communities to participate and that is very rare for a government program. Most government programs require the structures, technical colleges and so forth of larger cities. The third point is that it has provided an equally rare opportunity for the communities to become involved. One of the features of the success in country areas has been the way in which the communities have become involved.

I wish to commend the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) for the way in which he has gone around and met many CYSS groups and discussed the Government's decision with them. As soon as the Commonwealth Employment Service interviews with the CYSS groups are concluded and the ideas are collated I urge the Minister to make a statement which will provide additional flexible criteria to the already extended and enlarged training programs to allow at least some CYSS type or CYSS related schemes to continue in these small rural and regional areas.

My next complaint concerns roads. There is a declining federal government allocation for roads. The 9 per cent increase for this year is less than the 11 per cent increase for last year and it will be followed by an even smaller amount-as promised at this stage-of 7 per cent next year. The 9 per cent increase for this year will not be as high as the projected inflation rate as indicated in the Budget Papers, and is far below what is considered to be the road construction and maintenance rate of about 16 per cent. I believe that for 1982-83 the 7 per cent increase in federal government funds that is promised at the moment will have to be doubled to provide an adequate amount for the road system of this country.

The record of the States is even worse. This morning in answer to a question the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) referred to Victoria as being one of the better-off States. I point out to him that last year Victoria matched the amount of money provided for roads with that of the Commonwealth-as it had to under the roads agreement at that time-but this year it has reduced its increase in expenditure to under 5 per cent. Last night's Victorian Budget, which increased petrol and diesel taxes, may allow the Victorian Government to provide more money for it. But the roads in my electorate are visibly deteriorating. There is no sealing program for local roads and resurfacing of existing sealed roads is falling behind. More money is desperately needed, particularly for local roads. The local road system is the base of our national road system. It is fine to have great national highways. I do not knock them but they do not go through too many electorates and they do not assist the great bulk of people who live in country areas. I believe that it is important for this Government, with its concern for country and regional people, to dramatically increase the amount of money available for roads, particularly local roads, in the next Budget.

My next and final grouch concerns Telecom Australia and trunk call charges. Telecom deserves commendation for the pause between 1975 and January 1982 for any increases in charges. In that time there have been significant reductions in almost all of the eight call charge zones. At the same time Telecom has been required to finance a significant percentage of its capital expenditure from profits. However, I must protest on behalf of the hundreds of thousands of Australians who live in the 165 kilometre to 325 kilometre zone and who suffer the unique disadvantage of being the only group in the community not to receive a reduction in the 1975-1982 period or after January 1982, when some charges will be increased and then reduced. I am referring to the business hour time call period for trunk call charges when business within the capital cities is done. Every other group-seven in total-has had or will receive a reduction for business hour calls. Furthermore, as from January 1982, in this zone there will be an increase from $1.35 to $1.44 for a three minute telephone call. So Telecom is not even holding the present rate, as will at least be the case for the next zone, the 325 kilometre to 485 kilometre zone. This 165 kilometre to 325 kilometre zone is the heartland of decentralised regional industry in Australia and it is not receiving its fair share of the benefits of the new technology which have been passed on to all other telephone subscribers in this nation. I believe the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) should instruct Telecom at the least to maintain the present rate beyond 25 January 1982 when many of the charges will change.

I now refer to the Australian Centre for International Agriculture Research or ACIAR. I will commend, discuss and question the announcement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) that the Government will establish an international agricultural research centre in Australia concerned with the needs of developing countries. An amount of $25m has been provided for the first four years of that centre. I understand that legislation will be introduced in the near future to establish the centre as a statutory authority. It will be responsible to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The legislation will limit the life of the authority to 12 years and provide for an evaluation in the tenth year. A policy advisory council of distinguished Australian and overseas agricultural research scientists will set the priorities for the research to be conducted in and out of Australia. There will be a director and a small staff to implement those priorities. The centre will not actually be a research institute of facility in the ordinary meaning of the word, as is the case with the 13 internationally recognised agricultural research institutions. The centre will contract research work mainly in Australia to existing instititutions, with some research of a joint or collaborative nature being done overseas with the Australian centre being part of the venture. At all times this work will be for the benefit of agriculture in developing countries. I understand that Canada has a similar type of research centre.

The overall aim, I am told, is to mobilise Australian agricultural research expertise to a greater degree than is presently possible for the benefit of agriculture in developing countries. This is a sensible and laudible initiative. Australia has particular expertise in legumes, for both tropical and temperate climates, as a replacement for nitrogenous fertilisers, and for grazing. There is expertise in tropical and arid grazing generally and in arid and semi-arid agriculture. Tropical and arid conditions are common features of developing country agriculture, as is grazing and I hope the avoidance of high cost nitrogenous fertilisers.

However, there are several questions which I want to pose. The first relates to the Australian Development Assistance Bureau and agricultural foreign aid provided by this country. The second concerns the relationship to the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research, known as CGIAR. The third relates to the gap in international agricultural research in island states, particularly tropical islands in the Pacific and Indian Oceans. Because of our proximity to the emerging nations in this category I believe we have a special responsibility. The next question concerns the relationship to the Asian Vegetable Research Development Centre in Taiwan and its relationship to CGIAR. The next question relates to the ability of the centre, when most of its research work will be done in Australia, to make its research relevant to developing countries, given all the differences that exist in soils, climates, formal structures, societies, et cetera. The final question relates to how successfully the centre will be able to communicate the results of its research to the beneficiary countries.

The first point concerns ADAB. I have been advised that there will be close co-ordination between the Development Assistance Bureau and ACIAR, the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. The more applied agricultural research and management consultancy-type of foreign aid which has been the basis of this type of foreign aid so far will continue, and the recommendations for that work will continue to be made through the Consultative Committee on Research and Development. This provides an opportunity for that level of foreign aid through ADAB to spread some of the work that will be done by the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research.

The second point concerns the relationship to CGIAR or the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research. That is one of the more uncertain aspects at this stage. This question of relationship was first raised in this House by the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher) when commenting on a statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street).

TALK.START.PARA: —A good member too.

—Yes, very perceptive. The Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research was established in 1971 to support 13 international agricultural research institutions. It was established on a joint basis by the Food and Agriculture Organisation, the World Bank and the United Nations Development Program. The 13 supported centres are located in the following countries: Colombia, Peru, Mexico, Italy, Lebanon, India, the United States of America, Nigeria, Kenya, Ethiopia, the Philippines, the Netherlands and Liberia. The two most famous centres are the International Rice Research Institute in the Philippines and CIMMYT in Mexico, both initially developed with Ford and Rockefeller foundation money. That is where dramatic breakthroughs in hybrid rice and semi-dwarf wheat have been made to the great benefit of feeding the people of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1980, 35 countries contributed $120m to the work of these 13 centres. Australia's contribution was $3m to 12 of the 13. I submit that Australia must maintain its level of support for these existing institutions. It should also support the admission to full membership of the CGIAR supported centre, the Asian Research and Development Centre in Taiwan, which is at present an associate member.

I refer briefly to the work of the vegetable centre in Taiwan, where pioneering work has been carried out in the development of six vegetables to provide needed protein and vitamins for people in the less developed countries in tropical and semi-tropical areas. Those six vegetables are tomatoes, chinese cabbage, sweet potato, white potato, mung bean and soya bean. More particularly, the majority of the 13 centres that I have referred to plus Taiwan are in tropical and arid areas of the world. So it appears to be important that work at these centres which is already being done is not duplicated by work in Australia; otherwise there would be a waste of money having the centre established here. I refer again to the great need for agricultural research particularly centred on tropical island agriculture, which is in need of international support for research in the Pacific and Indian Oceans. I commend the Government for its initiative in establishing this centre. I will watch its development with interest and question its performance from time to time. I support the Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Budget is one of the most regressive pieces--
—And despicable.

—Yes. It is one of the most regressive and despicable documents that this House has seen for many years. It shows no care for the main ingredient of Australia, its people. The people of Australia are once again totally ignored and depressed by many parts of the Budget. The elderly, the young and the family unit I have spoken about in this House on many occasions are all under the hammer in this Budget. The youth of Australia have been callously disregarded with the abandonment of the Community Youth Support Scheme. Many thousands of letters have poured in to honourable members from around Australia. I have received many letters, as I know you have, Mr Deputy Speaker. Many other members have received them also.
