DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Death of Charles John Harris-League of Home Help for Sick and Aged, Perth-Economic Policy-Shipping Dispute-Education Funding-National Superannuation Scheme

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight very sadly to talk very briefly about a great unionist-the late Charles John Harris or, as he was called, Charlie Harris-who died yesterday week at 85 years of age. He was a great person and a great unionist. He was a member of the union movement for over half a century and all that time a member of the Australian Theatrical and Amusement Employees Association. He worked in many fields in the theatre, including as spruiker some 40 or 50 years ago. He had many jobs in the theatrical and cinema areas. He was delegate to the Victorian Trades Hall Council for over 40 years. Until recently, when he had an accident, he had in those 40 years on only a handful of occasions missed a meeting of the Trades Hall Council. I believe he was a person who really dedicated his life to the union and the union movement and to the betterment of the people whom he loved and whom he was trying to help throughout his entire life-the little man, the family man, the person who needed assistance. They will all be very saddened to hear of his passing. I think Charlie was one of the greatest unionists. On behalf of every unionist and everyone who knew him I thank him for all the wonderful things he did and the wonderful times we had. I think the Trades Hall Council in Victoria will sadly miss him after his 40 years of wonderful service. I just say these few words tonight on his behalf. He was a great unionist. I feel very sad, as do the members of the Australian Theatrical and Amusement Employees Association, at the passing of one of that union's all time great unionists. I believe the union will, in fact, name a benevolent fund after Charlie. I think that will be a tribute to him for a long time to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I pay tribute to a magnificent organisation in my electorate which has been providing invaluable services to the aged in the Perth metropolitan area since 1954. I refer to the League of Home Help for the Sick and Aged. Last Sunday I had the privilege, together with the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), of jointly opening Tormey House-a hostel built by the League with the assistance of substantial Commonwealth funding of more than $350,000. This hostel consists of 24 hostel beds, 12 of which were funded under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act and the remaining 12 under the Aged Persons Hostels Act. This new accommodation for the aged, provided under the auspices of the League, is additional to other Commonwealth subsidised residential accommodation previously established by the League in Leederville and West Perth.

SPEECH.PARA: The League commenced operations in 1954 to provide domiciliary services to the aged as a top priority. Its beneficial influence has spread right throughout the metropolitan area of Perth. It has been a pioneer in the development of the Meals on Wheels service. Some 325 meals are delivered daily by a large voluntary band of helpers over a wide geographical area. A wide range of home help services and chiropody and hairdressing services are provided to many elderly people in the community. Through its domiciliary services the League is assisting aged people, not by removing them from the community but by enabling them to continue as far as possible to lead independent lives in the community. This principle is carried through even for those elderly people who find they need the kind of support that hostel accommodation can give by the close linking of the hostels with other social activities managed by this League. The League's accommodation facilities incorporate social centres for non-resident aged people which provide a most important focal point socially in the lives of all who enjoy the League's activities.

Perhaps the most important aspect of the League's work is the way in which it mobilises voluntary help involving hundreds of people in the community. I think this is the greatest commendation that a community organisation such as this League can receive, that so many people are prepared to put their resources, whether of time or money, into supporting its work. This level of community support shows that the League not only commands a great deal of respect for the work it is doing but also is seen as providing services that are really meeting community needs. This gives to its work also I think a very special quality of sincere concern which cannot pertain to government administered organisations. Those whom I have met in this organisation over the years work selflessly, voluntarily and with great dedication and concern for all the aged people who benefit from the wide range of services and activities provided by the League. The League's actions are, in my opinion, the epitome of how welfare sevices should be provided in the community if they are to have special meaning to both the recipients and the providers of these services and if the true integrity of a free society and its people is to be upheld.

Tonight I place on record in this Parliament my congratulations to all who are associated with the work of the League: Major A. F. W. Shaw, who has been the League's president for many years and who is a tireless worker for the League; Mr B. Pears, the League's administrator; the members of the League's Council and its executive committee; and also, very importantly, the very many men and women who do so much wonderful work throughout the metropolitan area of Perth in a voluntary capacity on behalf of the elderly in that area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) is in the House during this adjournment debate. Only last week the honourable member for Macarthur took issue with an indicator which I chose to adopt to provide evidence of the fact that, despite their claims to the contrary, the coalition parties are not, in fact, small government parties. The point that the honourable member indicated concern about related to a speech which I had made previously. In that speech I gave evidence of the fact that the coalition parties not only were not small government parties but also were high taxing parties, again despite their protestations and claims to the contrary. I looked in vain through the speech that was made by the honourable member for Macarthur to find any reference to the question of the present Government being a high tax government. No such reference was found. No attempt was made by the honourable member for Macarthur to refute that point because it cannot be refuted.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Macarthur suggested that, rather than take as an indicator for the size of government the indicator which I chose-that was one concerning government taxation-we should take the proportion of gross domestic product which makes up government expenditure. I am quite happy to move to that ground. I have made reference on previous occasions to the fact that the honourable member for Macarthur cooks figures. What I will do now is prove that that claim I have made on previous occasions is correct and can be substantiated.

If anyone were trying to refute the position I adopted, what he would do, for example, would be to take the highest proportion of gross domestic product represented by total Budget outlays under the Labor Government and then take the lowest proportion under the present Government. If a person wanted to cook the figures, present shonky figures, that is what he would do. That is precisely what the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) did. Let me indicate the evidence for that. During the three years we were in government the highest figure for the proportion of gross domestic product represented by Budget outlays was 30.1 per cent. The lowest during the term of the present Government has been 27.6 per cent. Those are the two figures to which the honourable member for Macarthur made reference.

If it had been his intention to be objective and honest-both personally and politically honest-in relation to the figures he was going to use, a more appropriate and more indicative figure surely would have been the average figure during the period of the Labor Government and the average figure during the period of the Liberal Government. Let us take those averages and see how they come out. During the three years of the Labor Government the average figure was 27.6 per cent. During the six years of this Government the average figure has been 28.4 per cent. So the percentage has been higher during the period in which the Government benches have been occupied by the coalition parties. It has taken this Government six years to reach a figure equal to the average figure which applied during the three years of the Labor Government. We are not in the business of competing against coalition parties in relation to statistics of this kind. We did not create the argument in the first place. The coalition parties have maintained that they have small government objectives. The figures I have given, on the grounds chosen by the honourable member for Macarthur, indicate that, contrary to the claims the coalition parties have made, that simply is not correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr F.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —At present we have one of the worst strike hold-ups of all time on our eastern seaboard. Ships are idle off the ports of Newcastle, Sydney and Port Kembla, waiting to load valuable cargoes of Australian commodities for overseas, particularly our coal, our grain and our iron ore. I was speaking last night to the President of the Australian Coal Association, who is also President of the New South Wales body. He expressed great concern at the hold-up in the loading of these ships and the effect it was having on Australia's trade overseas. A total of 60 ships are waiting off the coast at present and, with demurrage at rates from $10,000 to $15,000 per day, the hold-up is costing $2m a day. That is a great loss to this country which has to be met by the coal companies and the shipping companies, not by the overseas authorities. It can be seen that this great shipping problem is causing disruption to the trade and economy of this country. Overseas buyers are now looking to other countries. We are not the only country where coal, iron ore and grain is produced. They cannot rely on Australia as a reliable shipping source.

SPEECH.PARA: Three weeks ago three men had a fight on a tug and one of them was stood down. What happened? We had a strike on our eastern seaboard for three weeks. We got that settled, and now we have another strike with a marine union. This has tied up shipping in all our ports. Not only overseas ships but also Australian ships are held up, and this is causing great problems in the supply of fuel throughout our eastern seaboard. Northern New South Wales, the south coast and South Australia are having great difficulty in securing fuel. Ships coming from Bass Strait to the Australian Oil Refining Pty Ltd refinery in Sydney and to the Shell company's refinery at Clyde are tied up. Overseas ships coming in with crude oil to be refined in our refineries are having exactly the same problems. If we cannot get fuel into the northern wheat belt and to industrial concerns and transport in that area, we will have great problems.

The Kurnell refinery in Sydney, of course, provides two-thirds of the fuel for New South Wales, and there is no fuel in the port of Newcastle at the present time. Getting the little fuel that is in Sydney into the country areas is costly and is causing great problems. Kurnell has five days supply of fuel left, and unless the strike is settled immediately transport will come to a complete standstill. A total of 66 shipping days have been lost this year. This would not happen in any other port in the world. The chief officer of the Alioth which arrived off the port of Newcastle on 2 July to load coal for Japan, said that this is the worst port in the world. Ships will get their coal from somewhere else. As I mentioned a while ago, we are not the only country in the world that is producing coal. Marine engineers are claiming a 10 per cent pay increase, and increased leave and sick leave provisions. Surely some sanity can be brought to these people. Surely they must realise the damage they are doing to the economy of this country, the work force, and everybody in it. I understand that representations have been made to the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt). I hope that this Government can take some action and bring sanity into the situation which exists in our ports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's education policies are damaging Australia's future technological and educational advancement as well as depriving young people of opportunities at a time when youth unemployment is at a critical level. Educationists from schools, colleges of advanced education and universities both inside and outside my electorate have approached me with their deep concern about the Government's changes to education and the haste with which they are being introduced. It is my opinion that Australia is facing a watershed in its education history and that without proper planning our future educational advancement and, therefore, advancement in every other sphere, will be threatened. The position of colleges of advanced education is of particular concern. They are being subjected to cuts in funding and thus the number of student places they are able to offer. They are also being forced to amalgamate. Existing courses will suffer and the lack of funds will mean that no initiatives in new courses will be taken in response to the needs of the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Rusden State College, on the border of my electorate, which has been described by the Advanced Education Council as a centre of excellence, has told me that its amalgamation and the resulting reduction in funding of $487 per student from 1981 to 1982 will mean that existing courses will have to be cut back drastically. The amalgamation of colleges of advanced education was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on 30 April this year. He said:

Arising from the recommendations of the Tertiary Education Commission, the Government will promote a major rationalisation and reallocation of resources in higher education. This will involve consolidation into larger units of 30 existing colleges of advanced education, for which teacher education is the main activity, by their incorporation into multi-purpose or multi-campus colleges with a single governing body or by integration with neighbouring universities.

Not a word was then said by the Prime Minister of his intention to cut the college's funds. Is it any wonder that no one in his right mind trusts the Prime Minister any longer? The most damning thing about the Government's education policy is that the prime criterion determining it is the crazy obsession to cut costs. No consideration has been given to maintaining and improving the level of education.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to put up tax.

—Whoever is interjecting on the Government side could do with some education. He is lacking some. No consideration has been given to maintaining and improving the level of education as it exists or to our ability to respond to future technological change. The inordinate haste with which the changes have been made is evidence of this lack of proper consideration. Cost cutting measures have been introduced to CAEs with such speed that even the savings to be made must be questioned. We have not yet had the Government's assessment of what the savings will amount to. A rational look--
—You are going on.
—The honourable member is not rational after the few drinks he has had. A rational look at the CAEs will show that it will not be much, if anything at all.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order.
—Oh shut up! The honourable member is taking a flippant point of order. He wants to stop me from speaking.
—Order! The honourable member for Hotham will resume his seat.
—I ask the honourable member to withdraw that statement. I ask for an apology.
—Because of the interjections the Chair did not pick up the remark but on the premise that the honourable member for Hotham made it I call on him to withdraw.
—I was provoked by the honourable member's interjection. I smelled alcohol on him even though he is so far away.
—The honourable member will withdraw.
—I withdraw.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am quite distressed by the accusation. It is absolutely false. I will sit down if I get an apology.

—Order! In consultation with the Clerk I am led to the view that the honourable member for Hotham made less than an unqualified withdrawal of the remark. Indeed, he may have compounded it subsequently. I suggest to the honourable member that to clear the decks he withdraw without qualification.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been some recent editorial comment on the advantages of the Government introducing a national superannuation scheme. I speak this evening in support of the establishment of a wide-ranging, in-depth study of this proposal. I emphasise that there are no easy options facing the community in the funding of future social welfare benefits. Those who wish to provide for national superannuation must be willing to pay for it. The need for this study rests upon the following facts: The number of people relying on the Government for income support payments is continuing to grow as an increasing percentage of the working age population. There is a potentially significant increase in the welfare needs of the aging population which must be exacerbated as the community's life expectancy tends to increase. The percentage of taxpayers relative to the number of recipients is tending to fall and there is growing taxpayer resistance to an increase in the real burden of taxation to support those who may not be in the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: There can be no doubt that a government's social and welfare policies must take into account population trends within the economy, in particular the impact of an aging population. Obviously, a younger population is able to create more economic growth than an aging one. Trends in the Australian age structure suggest that there has been a significant decline in the net reproduction rate since 1976, and it is still falling. I table the appropriate graphs on this matter. Unless there is a continuous and significant growth in the rate of productivity there will be an increasing burden on fewer people to pay for the social services of a growing population. (Quorum formed). The number of people over the age of 65 years will increase by two-thirds by the end of the century. Those aged 75 and over will double. The current ratio of workers to dependants is three to one. By the year 2010, on the basis of present expected trends, this ratio could be as low as two to one. Accordingly, unless those in the work force are prepared to pay additional taxation to support those who are not the present level of social security entitlements will be under extreme pressure.

The time has come for the community to consider seriously how we can continue to pay on an annual basis from revenue a total pension bill which is currently 28 cents in every dollar of taxation. The alternatives we are facing are twofold. Firstly, we may continue the present system of funding social welfare out of consolidated revenue and watch a growing percentage of the Budget going in that direction or, secondly, we can develop and introduce a universal occupational superannuation program which would involve all in the work force being members of superannuation funds managed by employers or institutions to which they would make a percentage contribution of salary supplemented by an employer contribution. However, for a long transition period, probably 15 years, the working population would have to contribute to existing pension funding through taxation as well as contributing to superannuation. A viable national superannuation program would require flexibility between employment and preferably the right to change funds. Contributions would attract a tax rebate similar to that for basic health cover.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—Having listened to the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) misquote in an extraordinary way some statistics on the Budget, I thought it appropriate to take a minute or two to correct him. He seems to have forgotten that by taking a simple average he is showing not only a simple approach but also a simple-minded approach to the realities of Budget statistics. Perhaps it is a little late for him to be educated but I will try to do something to help him now. He may have noticed that in the 1973-74 Budget government expenditure as a proportion of gross domestic product was 23.8 per cent.
—How is Patrick Partners?

—That is the sort of stupid interjection I would expect from the honourable member. This figure rose by 1975-76 to 30.1 per cent, an increase of 6.3 per cent. The trend was up in terms of big government under Labor. Under the present Government the figure has fallen from Labor's 30.1 per cent to 27.6 per cent. For anyone to pretend in this House that a rise under Labor is better than a fall in terms of big government under the present Government shows not only a curious approach but also, as I suggested, a simple-minded approach to economics. It demonstrates what kind of economic management we would have if the fellows opposite ever got back on the Treasury benches.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Quarantine: Importation of Animals and Insects

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many monkeys were imported into Australia for research purposes during 1979-80, where did they come from, and to which States and Territories were they consigned.
(2) Were other animals or insects imported for research purposes in that year; if so, what types, how many and what was their country of origin.
(3) What quarantine procedures are set down for importation of monkeys and other animals or insects for research purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) One hundred and fifty-three monkeys were imported for research purposes during 1979-80; they were imported from Malaysia; they were consigned to Victoria (100) and New South Wales (53).
United States of America, United Kingdom and Switzerland
United States of America, United Kingdom, France and Holland
India, Japan, New Zealand, United States of America and West Germany
(3) Primates may be imported to scientific institutions subject to prior written permission of the Minister for Health and subject to the following conditions:
(a) the environment of the monkeys during the previous 6 months is stated;
(b) the animal has not been in contact with any animal suffering from disease while under owner's control;
(c) the animal has not been on premises where rabies has occurred during the past 12 months;
(d) during the previous 3 months, the animal has not been in Africa or a yellow fever area of South America;
(e) at the time of export, the animal shows no sign of infectious or contagious disease; and
(f) the animal has been subjected to a tuberculin test with negative results within 30 days prior to export or immediately after arrival in Australia.

All importations of insects for research purposes are subject, under quarantine legislation, to the prior permission of the Director of Quarantine. Permission for each importation is based on strict compliance with requirements specified individually to ensure quarantine security. These depend, inter alia, upon the species concerned, its origin, destination and its intended usage.

Specific conditions are set out in quarantine legislation for the importation of a number of animal species other than primates. Other animal species may be imported for research purposes subject to Ministerial approval. This approval is based on strict compliance with requirements specified individually to ensure quarantine security and once again depend, inter alia, upon species, origin and the purpose and institution for which it is intended.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Controls on Domestic Pet Traffic Between Australia and New Zealand

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to allegations widely accepted in Western Samoa that a cat from Western Samoa, owned by a New Zealand national, was admitted to New Zealand without passing through the regular quarantine procedures.
(2) If so, will he raise the matter with the New Zealand authorities with the view to tightening controls on domestic pet traffic between Australia and New Zealand.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I was unaware of the allegations until my attention was drawn to the matter by the honourable member's question.

My Department has sought information from the New Zealand authorities who have advised that dogs and cats may not be imported into New Zealand direct from Western Samoa. They have no knowledge of illegal importations from that country.

In the past the New Zealand authorities have permitted a small number of pets on yachts to be imported following an authenticated history of complete isolation aboard the yacht for at least 9 months. It would have been possible for a cat from Western Samoa to have entered New Zealand by this means. My Department has been advised that this practice has now ceased and that New Zealand only imports dogs and cats from Australia, Ireland and the United Kingdom in accordance with their standard quarantine conditions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the article entitled 'Burying Caesar: an Analysis of the Laetrile Problem' by Mark McCarty in the Triton Times, University of California, San Diego, United States of America, of 24 and 26 November 1975.
(2) If so, does the article throw doubt on the motives of both Ernest Krebs Jr, Ph.D., and the United States of America authorities declaring Laetrile ineffective.
(3) Has his attention been drawn to the article entitled Laetrile Works by the same author in Cancer Control Journal, Vol. 4, No. 3/4, 1976, written after a survey of patients and their records.
(4) Will he direct that properly controlled clinical statistical studies of Laetrile be conducted urgently.
(5) Has he decided that Mr McCarty is wrong; if so, which controlled studies have led him to this conclusion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) I would not wish to draw any conclusions regarding the motives of either Ernest Krebs Jnr. or the United States of America authorities based on this one article.

(4) My Department does not have the facilities or the resources to conduct properly controlled clinical statistical studies nor can it direct that such studies be undertaken. I am advised however that in 1978 the National Cancer Institute in the United States filed an Investigational New Drug application with the Food and Drug Administration for testing Laetrile in patients with cancer. The trial commenced in July 1980 when one hundred and seventy-eight patients were enrolled in the study which was undertaken at four cancer research centres. The trial was co-ordinated by the Mayo Clinic and the results presented at the American Society of Clinical Oncology meeting in Washington on 30 April 1981. The results indicated that Laetrile was ineffective as a treatment for cancer.

(5) One cannot conclude from Mr McCarty's articles that he is either right or wrong. However in his second article printed in 1976 he insisted that fair controlled clinical trials of Laetrile be permitted and encouraged in the United States of America. These have now been carried out with the result indicated above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will transition education programs be promoted by the Government.
(2) Are funds for transition education programs increasing in real terms from 1980-81.
(3) Is funding for these programs to be limited to fixed periods; if so, why.
(4) If funding is to be limited, does this indicate that the programs will be terminated.

(5) Has his attention been drawn to the research report for the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, entitled 'A Case Study Evaluation'; if so, will he ensure that funds are made available to continue the transition education program 'Move on', being conducted by Narrabundah College, Australian Capital Territory, without jeopardising other programs in the Australian Capital Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Transition education programs are being promoted by the Government. Under the Transition from School to Work Program in 1980, a total of $17m was advanced to the six States, the Northern Territory and Australian Capital Territory for transition programs in government and non-government schools and Technical and Further Education institutions. In 1981, $26.9m has already been approved for transition programs. On 4 June 1981 I informed Parliament of Government decisions which will have the effect of increasing funds available for transition education and training programs to up to $75.4m in 1982.
(2) As indicated in reply to (1), funding for transition programs is increasing substantially in real terms and, under policies announced by the Commonwealth, will continue to do so until 1984.

(3) The Commonwealth's offer to the States in November 1979 in respect of the Transition Program provided for specified financial arrangements for the years 1980 to 1984. It is not usual for the Commonwealth to specify for a period as long as five years the amounts it is willing to contribute under such a program, but it was considered that this arrangement would assist forward planning by education authorities in an area of particular concern to both the Commonwealth and the States.

(4) The Commonwealth has informed the States that arrangements for transition education beyond 1984 will be reviewed with the States in 1983 prior to agreement with them on the 1984 program. That the Commonwealth's offer of November 1979 covers the year 1980-1984 does not imply that programs would be terminated. Consideration of longer term arrangements will take place well before the time when the current arrangements expire.

(5) The research report for the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, entitled 'A Case Study Evaluation' has been drawn to my notice. This report shows that a promising start has been made to the Transition Program in the Australian Capital Territory and that a number of worthwhile projects have been supported under this Program including the project at Narrabundah College. Narrabundah College received funding in 1980 under the Transition Program for the provision of an alternative program for students at risk in making the transition to employment, and has received further funding in Term 1 of 1981 to continue this project. Allocation of funds for 1982 under the Transition Program to Australian Capital Territory schools and colleges has not yet been decided, but the needs of Narrabundah College will be considered along with those of other Australian Capital Territory schools and colleges involved in transition activities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government's plan to explore with State Governments the appropriateness and feasibility of transferring to the States the remaining Commonwealth operational elements of the quarantine administration, based on its commitment to an efficient quarantine service which must continue to play an effective and major role in Australia's social and economic well-being (Hansard, 9 April 1981, page 1566).
(2) If so, how will the transfer of these powers to the States contribute to the greater efficiency of Australia's quarantine service.

(3) Has the Government weighed up the costs associated with a major disease outbreak in Australia's livestock industries against the amount it could save by the transfer of responsibility to the States.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Government is committed to a strong and effective quarantine service and is concerned to explore possible avenues for increased efficiency, including an extension of Commonwealth/State arrangements in quarantine matters.

(2) The States have a long-standing history of effective animal and plant quarantine operations undertaken on the Commonwealth's behalf. The exploratory talks with the States would include appropriate considerations of efficiency. No decisions would be made by Government which would weaken the quarantine service or compromise the quarantine controls on which Australia relies.

(3) The Government is well aware of the costs and implications of a major disease outbreak in Australia's livestock industries and would not adopt any measures which might reduce the efficacy of the quarantine system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the Prime Minister's statement to the Parliament on 30 April 1981, as part of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, that responsibilities for the regulation and control of nuclear activities are to be implemented as far as possible by the States and Northern Territory, with the Commonwealth maintaining a co-ordinating role (Hansard, page 1837) which responsibilities for the regulation and control of nuclear activities within his portfolio will no longer be implemented by the Commonwealth.
(2) Have assurances been sought from the States that they will now implement these responsibilities; if so, what replies have been forthcoming.
(3) What arrangements exist or are proposed for the Commonwealth to play a co-ordinating role.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My portfolio responsibilities in relation to the assessment of environmental impact statements and the development of uniform nuclear codes of practice will not be reduced as a consequence of the Government's decision that responsibility for the regulation and control of nuclear activities will be implemented as far as possible by the States and the Northern Territory, with the Commonwealth maintaining a co-ordinating role. This decision confirms the Government's policy that implementation of nuclear codes of practice should in general be the responsibility of State and Northern Territory Governments. The Commonwealth Government will continue to assess environmentally significant uranium mining proposals for which Commonwealth decisions are required under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and to develop codes of practice under the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act 1978 in close consultation with the States and the Northern Territory.

In the case of uranium mining operations in the Alligator Rivers Region of the Northern Territory, the funding of environmental regulatory services is now the responsibility of the Northern Territory Government. Discussions are being held by Commonwealth and Northern Territory officials on the form of an independent environmental regulatory agency as referred to in the Government's decision on the Review of Commonwealth Functions. The Supervising Scientist continues to carry out the research, standard development, co-ordination, supervisory and reporting responsibilities laid down in the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act 1978.

(2) and (3) The Commonwealth and the States have agreed arrangements for the environmental assessment of proposals, including uranium mining proposals, where joint responsibilities are involved. Similar arrangements are being prepared between the Commonwealth and Northern Territory Governments. The States and the Northern Territory are closely consulted on the formulation of nuclear codes of practice under the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) As records of all medical research projects being undertaken in Australia are not available to my Department, the precise number of research projects concerning Herpes Simplex II currently being conducted cannot be ascertained. However, the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH & MRC) is supporting one project at the University of Adelaide which is investigating the factors controlling transformation in vitro of human cervical epithelium by Herpes Simplex virus, and the relationship of these events to the progression of human cervical neoplasms. Funding for this project, which commenced in 1980, will total $75,000 over a three year period.

(3) No. However one application for a Public Health Travelling Fellowship to study sexually transmitted diseases, including research into Herpes Simplex virus infection, is currently under consideration by the NH & MRC.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the current controversy surrounding the use of the pour-on sheep dip known as Clout manufactured by the Wellcome company; if so, when did he first become aware of the controversy.
(2) Does he intend to take any action to protect Australia's multi-million dollar trade in sheep skins from any adverse effects stemming from the use of Clout; if not, why not.

(3) What action does he intend to take to ensure that farmers are in a position to make informed decisions on whether or not to use Clout, and if they are to use it, to ensure that they understand what the implications are for their marketing decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The possibility of adverse effects on tanned sheepskins first came to my attention during May 1981.

(2) The Commonwealth's involvement in this matter is restricted to providing the Chairman and Secretariat for the Technical Committee on Veterinary Drugs (TCVD), which is a subsidiary of the Australian Agricultural Council and the Standing Committee on Agriculture. The TCVD has a co-ordinating role in the evaluation of veterinary drugs but the registration and control of agricultural chemicals in Australia is the responsibility of the States.

(3) Information brought to my attention was referred to the TCVD for urgent consideration. TCVD has now evaluated the new information placed before it and has agreed upon additional interim measures. These have been brought to the attention of the State registration authorities and the manufacturer. It is expected that the States will take prompt action to implement the TCVD recommendations which propose more detailed labelling to enable farmers to make informed decisions. The proposed measures are of an interim nature and the matter is being kept under constant review by TCVD.
